Spice Garden is a take away only Indian kitchen that focuses on Kerala style South Indian cuisine. It didn't have to change much of its operation to adjust to the pandemic. On the end of an old commercial strip near the bottom of Bustleton Avenue just a few blocks before Grant Avenue, it is designed to accept your phone order for pick up 30 - 40 minutes later. That was our plan after grocery shopping at the large Asian supermarket on St. Vincent's Street @ Roosevelt Avenue. We called from the parking lot, arriving about 15 minutes later because of light Memorial Day Weekend traffic.

Now, I've had much better curries, masalas and garlic naans than are offered at Spice Garden, but on the other hand there is a trade-off of larger quantities and cheaper prices than available at standard Hindi houses, although the online menu states that recent cost of ingredient increases necessitated higher prices. That's just reality given these harsh times, and we didn't object to absorbing a couple of more bucks. 

Of course, by the time we reached home the blush was off the rose. Reheating was required to reanimated each dish. We found each was tasty and very well spiced. The two chicken plates led the way, with the Kerala Chicken Curry in a dark thick sauce and the Chicken Pepper Fry bone in and the hottest of the lot. It was a finger food delight. The Channa Masala was lighter cream colored mildly sweet veggie dish that was a good sop for the Garlic Naan. The other diced mixed veggie bowl was a strong counterpoint to the rest of the tongue challenging heat packed into the two plastic take home bags.

The only real downside to the experience was the cleanliness of the small anteroom when I waited for the food. There were several insulated containers sitting on the floor, each more schmutzidick than the other. Clearly used for moving cooked food, there was no way they would pass a health department inspection. They left me wondering about the condition of the kitchen on the other side of that swinging door. 

I'll let you know if I experience any side effects from this meal, which appears to be enough for three dinners.

While KO Modern Korean Cuisine does a tasty new take on traditional dishes from the peninsula, you must keep in mind that they call themselves a fusion restaurant that covers Japanese, Thai and even a pinch of Chinese in their kitchen. If traditional is what you want, then this is not the place for you. Try Mirim or the cafe inside of H Mart on Woodbourne Road for the real McCoy. It is only fair to judge based on their stated intentions, not on what they do not claim to be. 

To my tongue they do a very good job on creative contemporary Korean food. I thoroughly enjoyed the small plate KFC (Korean Fried Chicken) and BBQ Pork Belly Bao. The extra spicy wings were just that. Messy and delicious. The Buns a tempting pile of belly and greens atop a soft round pinchable white rice bun. Had I stopped there I would have been seeing multi stars. 

The Sushi and Bento Dinner from the Japan side of the menu were a different matter. Our Rainbow Roll ordered for a sushi neophyte, was less than inspiring. It appeared lifeless on the platter, and tasted less than brand new. When sushi is truly fresh, it has an inner glow. This did not. Perhaps, the use of dyed pink ginger was a tell, but it was less than optimal. I would like to see what they do with Gimbap, the seaweed and rice street food that most closely resembles sushi. I suspect it would have been superior. 

The Bento options chosen were teriyaki salmon,  Dynamite Chicken and a similar shrimp offering (tiny deep fried crustaceans in a gloopy sticky sweet sauce). Again, this Japanese combo plate missed the mark. The salmon was good, but slightly overcooked. The chicken was barely above room temperature, and the shrimp was lost in the heavy batter shell and thick clingy sauce. Just not what we expected from this kitchen. 

We agreed we would try again, but focus only on the Korean possibilities. This night, fusion could only be interpreted as confusion.

Decent enough small diner on York Road in Warminster, PA, where breakfast was had this morning. My third post-vaccine meal in a restaurant as the world crawls out of its collective cave to taste life again. 

The Vegetarian Omelet was a substantial plate load of 3 eggs, broccoli, onion, mushroom and spinach, with a shovel full of home fried potatoes for balance and good measure. Rye toast was a crunch and a half. Very filling, but required extra black pepper for taste on both the eggs and taters. 

I was surprised and concerned that the server was not masked, when we were required to be, and the owner was covered as well. Even with two jabs I would have felt more secure had she considered the reality that she was in contact with everyone in the dining room and kitchen and close proximity with every customers' food.  There is something to be said for keeping up appearances, especially in a food service business. 

Maybe management will see this review and reevaluate its policy on proper social distancing protocols even in the improving circumstance of an almost safe, nearly post Covid world.

Can't say I was impressed with this Iron Hill Brewery in Abington, PA. 

While the Pumpkin Ale was tasty and refreshing, our menu choices were fair to middling at best. We ordered their Calamari appetizer, Asian Salmon Burger and Country Schnitzel as main courses. The Calamari was all small rings (no tentacles) and overly oily from deep frying. Our guess was that these little things came from a large bag of frozen seafood. Nice to have slivers of hot peppers mixed in, but the ranch dressing dip really didn't contribute to the experience. 

My dining mate didn't offer a taste of the Asian Salmon after she took a bite and put it aside. "Too much garlic," she explained. Those fries were quite crisp and crunchified, however, and I had a free hand with them. 

The pork fillet Schnitzel was good; nice breading, pan fried with chunky Andouille Sausage white gravy over top. We ended up sharing that after she turned aside her salmon. I found the cutlets to be better without the gravy, and was able to push most of it off the entree. The sides (fresh spinach sautéed in garlic and oil, and the mashed sweet potato) were very colorful and also tasty strong contributors. Fair to say this plate was our dinner's salvation. 

The space felt somewhat worn out. I don't like carpeted dining rooms, as they tend to hide the accumulated dirt that collects in the fibers. This wall to wall definitely had been down too long. 

This was my third Iron Hill in the past month. Overall, unless very new, these breweries just don't seem to maintain high class facilities and appear worse for wear compared to their competition.

Three STARS is as far as I can go.

Phi Vietnamese opened its doors three weeks ago in the Crossroads Shopping Center off Rt. 313 in Doylestown.  It is the first shop to offer primarily Vietnamese food in the area, and for that they are worthy of appreciation.  Welcome to the hood.

The store is nicely appointed with black tables and chairs and burnt orange painted walls.  Looks good.  The staff is mostly indigenous to VN, and are quite attentive to their customers.  The menu offers what would be expected from this ethnic kitchen - Pho, Broken Rice, Summer Rolls, etc., at price points that while higher than in their siblings in less upscale environs, reflect the rent structure of the area.  $10 may be more than we are accustomed to paying for a large bowl of noodle soup, but it is a fact of life that things cost more in better communities.  

Son and I stopped in for Pho Ga (Chicken Pho) and Bun Bo Hue (Beef Noodle Soup from the former royal capital of Hue in Central VN).  Service was fast, although belied by slower delivery of the side plate of Thai Basil, Jalapeno Slices, Sprouts and Lime Wedges.  They also forget to bring the Hoisin and Sriracha Sauces for customization.  No biggie. I went to get them myself. 

The Chicken Pho was basic, but a solid presentation. It was steaming hot, with enough sliced white meat to keep son satisfied.  The Bun Bo Hue was another matter.  The spicing was off.  When right, it has a balance of Lemongrass, Fermented Shrimp Sauce, Chili Pepper and Sugar, to represent the major spice groups.  When joined with the amply simmered Beef Broth, and loads of thin sliced steak and brisket, it becomes a powerful combination that attacks the eyes, nose and mouth at the same time.  It can literally take your breath away until you adjust to its flavors and begin to taste how great they are together.  Phi's version was unbalanced with weak Lemongrass presence, and no sweet undertone.  Too, the table lacked the Vietnamese Coriander that adds to the complexity.  While it was hot and possessed some kick, it could not duplicate the burst of flavors a true BBH puts out.  

Phi Vietnamese is certainly good enough for a second visit and hopefully they will get their spice legs beneath them and start to BRING IT!  They shouldn't underestimate the sophistication of the local pallets, or they risk losing face to the suburban houses that can do it right, like House of Pho in Southampton and Pho Palace in Feasterville.

While Gay Street in downtown West Chester, PA, is way cool, with outdoor cafes, taverns and breweries competing with pedestrians for sidewalk space, this Iron Hill Brewery & Restaurant seems a bit out of sync with its very popular competition. Perhaps because it is older than many, the overall impression is drab and worn. 

We were a small group celebrating a new member of the firm. Staff put a few tables together for us, giving us complete command of the main dining room late in the afternoon. We ordered drinks and a few appetizers and smoozed for a couple of hours. We had good conversation as we consumed a plate of hummus/pita, sweet potato fries w dipping sauces and roasted Brussel sprouts in balsamic (?) dressing. 

The drinks were fine, if unimaginative; the same being true for the food. We consumed everything with a couple rounds of booze, and had no complaints, but it could have been so much more to keep us interested in their dark auburn atmosphere.

This Iron Hill just felt tired compared to other of their siblings I have visited and enjoyed. They occupy a key corner in town and it was easy to imagine how much more interesting and inviting it could be. How about an outdoor presence like everyone else? How about better marking of the main entrance door? How about better lighting around the bar to accentuate the back bar display?

Just saying...

The facility is very nice with dark wood tones and adequate spacing of tables.  The sushi area is to the side and kept very clean.  The service is adequate, if not overly warm or informative.  Definitely, a nice space to eat and socialize.

The Hibachi is not much to my liking, as whether beef, chicken, shrimp or lobster, they all taste almost the same coming off the grill due to the heavy dosing with soy sauce.  The flipping of food morsels from the spatula into the diners mouth is funny the first dozen or so times it is experienced, but gets old (and messy) after a while.  This is not the place I would chose to have a delicious steak, as it is far from a Ruth Chris, Capitol Grille, or Walensky's experience.  

The rest of the menu is diverse and generally decent, but not outstanding enough to want to return more than sporadically.  The presentation is done well, and the staff is prompt if not overly engaging with the customers.   I have tried the Udon/Soba Noodles with Chicken or Beef and enjoyed them, although they were less spicy that I generally prefer.  The Bento Boxes and lunch are a solid meal with Shumai, Tempura Veggies, and Haru Maki or other light roll as accompaniment. 

For me, Mt. Fuji is a good alternative place for local lunch or dinner, but I would not drive far out of my way for the opportunity.  Thus, 3 Stars.

Honey Baked Ham is the non-kosher name for a chain of primarily sandwich places where you can order a combination of sandwich, bread, drink, side and cookie for a prix fix.  You can also order a full ham. This one is in the Village of Newtown section anchored by the Pier 1 store. 

The few times I have been there I have gone with Turkey Breast, Swiss Cheese with lettuce and mustard, Cole Slaw side, Snapple Ice Tea and a Peanut Butter Cookie. It comes in a cute box.  They taste good, if not outstanding.  The service has been friendly, but when I am there it seems the owner is there alone and doing all the work.  This makes for a feeling that he is rushing around, for which he has my sympathy.  

I have also been a regular of another HBH in the Mercer Mall in Lawrenceville, New Jersey.  That shop seems better organized, and the food is somehow more enjoyable. 

Still, when I need to eat at my desk or want to be in Tyler Park for an hour of nature, HBH offers a great solution.

Olive Garden "Italian" Restaurant is one of those places designed for compromise.  In my case, it was a reasonable place to go with family given the limitations of each member.  My son loves cheese, but hates veggies, and said he was not very hungry.  His mother (my ex) is a vegetarian who loves the unlimited Salad and Breadstick deal offered by the chain.  Me?  I love Italian cuisine, but also want to keep the peace and make it through a Mother's Day dinner without stress.  Given all the variables, Olive Garden was the obvious choice.  

Surprisingly, the wait was not long when we arrived around 7:30.  We were seated within 10 minutes and our server was on us quickly for our drink and app requests. They arrived promptly, along with the first bowl of Salad without olives nor croutons, but with extra Red Onion, Tomato and Cheese.  I didn't know the salad could be special ordered, but it was a good idea.  The veggies were freshly cut and the Oil and Vinegar dressing was decent.  The Bread Sticks were hot and a little crispy on the bottom, which I liked.  

I was the only one having an actual dinner, having skipped lunch, and went with the new light Garlic Rosemary Chicken.  It arrived with two smallish chicken breasts well grilled, but without any grill marks, on a bed of Fresh Spinach, a few Caramelized Garlic Cloves (needed more), and a nice plop of Garlic Mashed Potatoes.  The Rosemary was not visible, but the chicken did taste of it.  

Overall, I was satisfied with the meal, although the sauce was thin and a bit salty.  For a "light" meal it was filling.  At $13.99 it seemed a reasonable value.  Would I order the same dish again?  Probably not, as the trade off in flavor for the lack of calories was not a winning hand.  It could be that I am comparing my experiences in many more authentic Italian restos, but I did not feel excited by the meal.  It was adequate.   

As no one complained and we were able to have a low key dinner, Olive Garden did its job, and met my decidedly selfish expectations.

We walked in during a birthday party for a young child.  The store was loud with kiddos shouting and running around.  Not bad if you like that helter-skelter ambiance.  But, not the place to find a quiet corner and enjoy a fresh baked and salted mini pretzel or three.  So, we took advantage of their special of 12 minis for $5., and boogied out to the car to continue on to Philly and munch in the voiture. 

The pretzels were fresh and okay, but far short of spectacular.  Chewy.  Salty. Carb City. Definitely needed a washdown to keep the pipes clear.  

The hot dog pretzels did look interesting.

I've picked up food from JC Teriyaki two days in a row to try a few of their main dishes to see what was happening there.  I've eaten their Fried Chicken and Hibachi Chicken, along with sides of Lima Beans, Potato Salad, Corn Bread and the Cabbage/Carrots combo that comes with the Hibachi offerings.  

JCT sits on Parkside Avenue just north of Olden Avenue Extension in a somewhat rundown retail strip center which also has a Chinese takeout joint and an Italian pizzeria. Nice to have options. 

While I enjoyed the entertainment of watching these three guys preparing the food, the actual finished products were only average.  The Fried Chicken combo of breast and wing was nicely meaty and never frozen, however the coating did not have very much flavor compared to the standards we all know.  It lacked sufficient spices to really stand out.  The white meat was plump and juicy and would have really shined with the right flour mix.  The accompanying Potato Salad was nicely sweet, but the Lima Beans were supersized and mushy.  The Corn Bread was pretty good. 

The Hibachi Chicken order was large and with the Veggies really weighed down the container.  It was cut into small strips and doused well with Hibachi Sauce throughout grilling.  It was interesting to see the American short order grill used for a Japanese dish.  I had not thought of that before, but it was cool to put those two cultural icons together. The chicken was tender and had a nice flavor.  The veggies of Steamed Cabbage and Carrots were a little boring; lacking much taste.  

JC Teriyaki is a mixed bag.  I like the concept demonstrating the cross-cultural bonds between Southern American cooking and Japanese grilling, but had higher expectations for the actual results.  Perhaps, the pricing of the meals (quite low) interferes with the ability to really pull out the stops and make the meals memorable. 

3.5 Stars is probably the right place to be here, but I want to encourage an upgrade in performance quality which won't happen without a little mild criticism.

I am in the minority on this one, but to me the name misrepresents the products and atmosphere of the 2 Paris Baguettes that I have visited.  

While the shop here is smallish and in the basement of the H Mart building, it is clean and has good service.  Yet, the selection here is not as varied as in the plant in Edison, New Jersey, and the seating arrangements not as comfortable.  

Most important is that while all the baked goods I have tried are fresh and soft, they bear no relation to the boulangerie found in its namesake, Paris, France.  There, the taste and texture of each of the pastries is unique, while here they are uniform and provide little differentiation.  Yes. They are all sweet and tender, but are not anything like a French bakery.  Perhaps, I was spoiled living in France and enjoying the pleasure of great croissant and other delights on a daily basis, but as "nice" as these offerings are, they do not approach the amazing flavors and surprises found on every corner in Paris.  

Paris Baguette?  C'est nes pas vrai.

Sport's Pizza is located at the end of Makefield Road, just before it reaches Woolston Avenue in Morrisville, Pa.  It is far off the street in a dated strip center behind a gas station. It is very easy to miss, as I did the first time through.  It is a small shop with 6 booths, and clearly deals primarily in take away.  They have a wall of pizza boxes at the ready.  

I was there for a light meal to replace the dinner I was too late to prepare at home.  I saw a handwritten sign that they had chicken noodle soup as a special, which piqued my interest on a chilly night.  Walking in and chatting with the woman at the register, I learned that the Brooklyn Pie was a new item.  There were a couple of squares left in the display, and I went for the corner slice to maximize the crunchy crust.  I also asked for a bowl of the soup.  Both were under $5.  

I like my tomato pie well done, and asked for that.  It arrived on paper plate before the soup (?), not as hot as it should have been, but still warm enough to satisfy my desire for a hot meal.  I don't understand why some places can't handle requests for well done (reheated) pizza, and insist that everyone wants it the same less than optimal temperature.  Still, I recognized that the crust was done decently, and the sauce/cheese ratio was fine.  Nice touch to see a sprig of basil.  I've had better. 

The soup was another matter.  It was very hot (microwave reheat), with lots of chicken, veggies and a few noodles, in a nice mild bird bouillon. A shake of black pepper and I was in business.  I liked it a lot. Enough to remember to order it again when in the vicinity. 

I enjoyed sitting down next to a poster of Allen Iverson.  I would love a real meal with him to talk about his election to the Basketball Hall of Fame and what an awesome basketball warrior he was.

Dominick's has been the pizza standard bearer in Washington Crossing for decades, but I had not stopped to sample their pies for a very long time.  After a dinner at their sister ship in Richboro a few weeks ago, I was tempted to return here to see if the magic was carried from oven to oven.  I went in for lunch earlier this week to find out.

First thing I noticed was that the once smallish primarily take out pizza parlor had expanded considerably.  It how had a dining room and a bar!  The rear area was dressed up a la a street scene in Napoli and the side barroom designed for those desirous of libations and wide screen TV with their Italian meal.  This room felt a little unfinished as things were stored in plain sight, and the quality of the furnishings did not match the richer feel of the wooden and mirrored bar.  

I ordered two slices of regular Tomato Pie and took my seat in the barroom to await the call to get them after reheating.  That call never came, so I walked back into the central area to inquire.  The slices in the oven had been forgotten and were now two charred triangles ready for dumping.  Honest apologies were forthcoming.  They put in two more slices and promptly called me when ready.  

They held their points when lifted, and had a pleasing crunch to the last bite.  The sauce was mildly sweet as I prefer, and the mozza still white after the furnace indicating it had begun that morning as a fresh cheese.  Nice.  Thin ribbons of basil lay on top of both, adding another texture and taste dimension.  

These were good slices, but far from the best I have had in the past year.  Yet, the price with a Snapple came to under $6., which was a good deal.  

To be a fan, I have to feel a desire to return for more in a short time.  Short of that, it is fairest to say that the pie is decent, but not memorable enough for me to put it on the short list of favorite places, let alone the pizza pantheon of great pies. 

By way of comparison, I found the Richboro location to be more comfortable, with better service and more compelling food.  This proved that carrying the same name and pedigree does not guarantee the same experience from place to place.

Crowded to near over capacity this New Year's Eve Day, but we managed a table, ordered, and were served within 15 minutes.  

Everything (French Toast, Corned Beef Hash, and Sausage, Egg & Cheese Sandwich) were decent, solid breakfasts.  No complaints.  

Service was as good as it could be given the cramped conditions.  Had to bring the bill to the cashier in the back for payment.  Unusual, but no big deal. 

Aunt Judy's has its charm as a morning get together joint.  It is one of those places where who you know there is more important than what you eat.
AUGUST 5, 2016 UPDATE - HoneyBaked Ham has moved from The Village at Newtown to Taylorsville, a/k/a Washington Crossing.

TWO SLICE REVIEW 

Average pizza from this small shop in a rundown commercial 3 store strip on Pennington Road, Ewing, NJ.  

The crusts are thin enough, and the red sauce has a mildly salty taste on the regular pie and a basil-sweet flavor on the other one I tried, that looks something like a tomato pie. Both held up their points when picked up from the exposed crust, but both also had oil drip and a somewhat soft slice center despite asking for the reheat to be well done. 

They private label their soda, and I liked the pineapple pop.  

There are three tables in house, so this is primarily a takeout joint.  However, reading the complaints from customers waiting for delivery, going there to eat their stuff seemed the better course.  

It was just okay. Nothing more.

This Taco Bell sits at the Route 206/Broad Street circle in Hamilton, NJ. It is a small shop with wrap around drive thru and low use dining area. It has been there for a few years and maintains a clean fresh look. This was my first visit despite the fact that my former law office was less than a half mile away. I really like Mexican food and this area has a lot of excellent cocinas Mexicanas, so "The Belch" was never high on my list of bookmarks. Still, its day had finally come.

I went for a chicken quesadilla - something simple, well known by me, and not overloaded with cheese to ramp up unwanted calories. It arrived about ten minutes later in a paper and glassine bag on top of a tray. I pulled it from the bag and placed the four quandrants on top of it (no plate provided). It was very thin with a little cheese melted and hardening at the edges. It was very hot. 

The taste and texture were fine, although not brimming with chicken. It could have been spicier throughout, but I found that all the chili powder was in only one piece of the pie. Not a major complaint, but how hard is it to spread the spice across the entire tortilla while on the grill? 

Given how good the authentic Central American restaurants in the region are, Taco Bell will remain far down the list of choices, but at least their stuff is okay.

Wang's Garden in the Village Shires Shopping Center off Buck Road in Holland, PA, is a family run Chinese/American house that has been wokking and rolling menu standards for a generation at this location. Mama runs the front of the shop, while dad is master chef. Prices are on the lower end of reasonable, reflecting the rent paid over the years. 

My roast pork egg foo young was two smallish pancakes, full of pork and veggies and melded together with two eggs.  The brown sauce seemed fresh, and the accompanying fried rice was also above average, with plenty of pork, peas, shoots and more egg. A pretty decent lunch platter. The weak link was the hot & sour soup, which lacked fresh mushrooms,  had little tofu, and was dominated by its vinegar. It seemed past its prime.  

Service was friendly and accommodating. They offer hot tea at no extra charge, which was appreciated.

This is the same place as Original Dominick's Pizza Shoppe, and that page has more reviews.  

My review is posted there, but for those who prefer one stop reviewing, here goes:

The place has expanded over the years and now boasts a nice back dining room, and a side barroom.  One is very nice, while the other could use some work in putting things out of sight and matching the bar with the furnishings.  

My experience at a recent lunch was likely an anomaly, but the two slices of tomato pie I ordered were forgotten in the oven and ended up in the trash when I returned to check on them.  The two I did eat were pretty good, with chunky red sauce, fresh melted mozza and a little basil.  I had eaten at their shop in Richboro the week before, and found the pizza there slightly better.  Why? I don't know, but it seemed a bit thicker and saucier.  I did not have dinner in this place as I did in Richboro, but at some point I will return to try it.

I appreciate the success of a family business, and Dominick's is a story of humble beginnings becoming auspicious rewards.  

Washington Crossing doesn't have many offerings, but Dom's has been holding the fort there for decades.

From high restaurant prices great things are expected.

No doubt, Macaroni is a high end Italian house just off Old Bustleton Avenue in Northeast Philly, with cool dim lighting, modern appointments, black and white service and outdoor pergola for al fresco drinks and dining. Atmosphere is hushed and romantic. Settling in comes with a full plate of hopeful excitement that a special moment is on the way. 

And, it almost is. 

Our sauteed long hot pepper table tapas was great, but the bread past its prime, and dry. The calamari fritti was excellent with perfect deep frying and plenty of sliced hot peppers. The chicken parmesan was hugh and delicious, while the cavatelli and crab used shellfish no longer fresh and sweet, but fishy like it was a day too old. Finally, the bronzino special was two whole fish fillets in skin that was soft and tender, but plated with a bland mushroom accompaniment and too mild tawny sauce that left the tongue wanting more flavor. At $37, it was a deep water disappointment. 

Most of us work hard for our money and don't like giving it away for a mezza mezza meal. With as many ups and downs as experienced at Macaroni, someone needs to call them on their "emperor's new clothes" reality. If they want to be special and charge premium dollars for the privilege of a table, they need alot more consistency and a bit less pretension.

Erwin's Country Kitchen is along the strip of Brownsville Road in Trevose that helps you understand what commercial development without zoning looks like. Ugly. So, don't be too discouraged as you drive down the street looking for 4059.  There it is on the south side of the street with the small white sign hanging high above the front door.  Rest assured that once you come inside you will be relieved to find yourself smack in the middle of 1959, greeted by a black and white poster of Marilyn Monroe and another of a more colorful James Dean.  

Rebel Without A Cause.

But, this time warping is a good thing.  The spacious dining room relaxes and helps recollect a time when things were good in grandma's home.  The wait people were lovely and straight from central casting.  They were in perpetual motion, bringing fresh coffee and large white plates full of grub to the starving masses.  When I came in, a group of ladies were in a breakfast meeting, and it looked like they might have been there for several years.  They showed no inclination to leave, and remained after I departed.  I wondered about their agenda.  

The deuce along the wall in the back space near the kitchen was a great place to watch the play unfolding.  The coffee came quickly in an odd mug, and with large half/half cupettes.  It was constantly refreshed before I reached the bottom, and it was not difficult to maintain the proper proportion of java to cream with small pours from the creamers. 

 I ordered the French Toast (as I usually do), and was asked for the first time in my life whether I wanted thick or thin sliced bread.  Astute question.  While the intuitive decision is to get more and go with the thick cut, I have the contrary opinion.  Too often the thicker Texas/Challah Style leaves the bread eggless in its heart, and thus dry.  I prefer the thinner option as it tends to be moist to the center, thoroughly cooked, and better carmelized on the surface.  Those burn points provide the crunch I desire. 

When the plate arrived, it had six half slices of toast, well grilled, and heavily sprinkled with powdered sugar.  A small paper cup of butter allowed for a light application of lubricant and additional subtle flavoring.  The syrup came in an old spring load top pitcher, which I promptly lifted over the plate for a healthy pour.  

The French Toast was quite good, but not attaining the pantheon of the gods. It needed another minute on the hot grill, and a drop of vanilla in the egg mix for soft  mellow unique sweetness.  

I will return to see Erwin again.  The menu looked to hold other secrets worth exploring, and it is not every day that I can slip in and out of the 50's without getting the bends.

In the best tradition of Black Friday we stopped in at Tio Juan's for late lunch and a few inebriants to succour us after the retail battles of the day. Traffic getting there was like swimming against a riptide, but once parked and inside things slowed down nicely.

The entrance foyer was large and empty, but for a solitary women behind a counter who directed us to either the lounge or dining room. We chose to be closer to the bar, and found our way to a clean booth on the far side. No one in uniform noticed our arrival, as we sat for several minutes with staff walking by without capturing their attention. I finally flagged down a server, who brought us menus and said someone would be with us shortly. She was, and we ordered our first margarita and Modelo Negro while reading the menu. 

We chose the Steak Fajitas and Fish Tacos del Mar from the Lunch Specials. Chips & Salsa were good and spicy. The steak was plentiful and nicely pink within, while well blackened without. The side of fixings - lettuce, salsa, crema fresca, onions and guacamole, and 4 hot tortillas, allowed for alot of handiwork. We both liked the platter. 

The fish tacos were okay, but not what was ordered. They were not the del mar version, but the straight fish tacos.  Thus, they lacked the proper sauce, cilantro and avocado; but had an aioli cream and red cabbage finish. Not even the roasted corn relish described on the menu for this dish was present. This was the more disappointing given that our server had recommended the del mar, but didn't recognize that she didn't have it in her hands. 

Honestly, it wasn't until I read the menu again online in preparation for this review that I realized what happened. Retroactive annoyance. 

This was not a bad experience, but for this. While not authentic Mexican cuisine, it knows how to make what we gringos like. Too, the bar lubricated us well.

Down towards the bottom of North Union Street in Lambertville, NJ, sits Thai Nida (Thai Daughter). It is a one room restaurant with exposed beam cathedral ceiling, orange wash walls and a few Buddhist hangings. The western exposure made for strong afternoon sunlight through the windows, so I moved to the other side of my table to cut down the glare. 

The was a large party at one end of the room keeping the one server occupied most of the time, but she kept her cool and managed to help me and another couple with our orders. She had skills and pleasant disposition. 

There was no lunch menu on Sunday, so I went with their Pad Kee Mao (veggie drunken noodles), which I have had an addiction to for the past few months. I love those wide rice noodles, hot spice and heavy brown sauce, and each of the versions I have tried were distinct from each other, despite the same ingredients. Some have been amazing, while others have not. 

Today's were toward the bottom of the spectrum to date. The noodles were plentiful, but aside from the bell peppers, onion and basil that come standard with the dish, there were only a few slim carrot slices and broccoli  florets to represent the vegetable kingdom. Not a mushroom, sprout nor stringbean in the lot. The spicing was not what I expected, neither chili nor lemongrass, but more a salt, black and/or white ground pepper with something else I couldn't identify. It was barely okay, and far from my favorite. 

It wasn't a great effort. Maybe they were saving the rest of the produce for that big party across the room.

2.5 STARS

Gold Garden is a middle of the road Chinese/American shop in the Homestead Plaza II, in Columbus, NJ.  It has 5 tables for those choosing to eat in.  The front of the house is a large counter where the wife of this H & W team holds court with efficiency and a smile.  The menu is what you would expect.  

My Sesame Chicken was served on a plate (rather than in Styrofoam), with Fried/White/Brown rice options, as well as soup or soda.  At $5.65 it was one of the better prices I have seen for this luncheon combo.  Taste-wise, it was okay, with a nice pile of chicken breaded, fried, and smothered in semi-sweet goo.  You know ... the way you have seen it a million times.  Plenty of rice made earlier in the day.  

The plaza where it is located also has ice cream and cupcake stores right next door, for those seeking things from all the nutritious food groups.  Luckily, the cupcake shop is closed Monday and Tuesday.  

Temptation is everywhere.

The Peter J. Camiel Travel Plaza is a smaller scale rest stop along the Pa turnpike.  While all the plazas are being redesigned and modernized for the new century, this one, while clean and efficient, and provisioned with the expected vendors from Starbucks to Roy Rogers and the ever-present Wawa like shop, this one lacks the comfort of the others on a busy day.  The lines tend to knot with each other.  

Still, it generally does what is supposed to do; provide plumbing and victuals for the road weary traveler, and help them on their way to their ultimate destinations.  

It is functional and an improvement over its predecessor.

Who was Peter J. Camiel?  A Philly politician of the Rizzo era who was prosecuted for corruption in office, convicted, and ultimately vindicated on appeal to the higher courts. As his legacy he had this rest stop named after him.

On a recent return visit I sampled their cronut and macaroons.  
Both were pretty good.  Sweet, but not overly so.  Textured well, so that the pleasure came from a combination of senses. 

While still not close to a Boulangerie Parisienne, at least it is a reasonable facsimile of one, especially for those with sweet teeth, who have never been to Paris.

This Denny's on Old Lincoln Highway (Business Rt. 1), Langhorne, PA, is an older, bigger version of "America's Diner." It has large windows facing its southern exposure, making for a warm seating area even on cold days. It was so bright at my booth that I had to close the shades to keep from sweating. 

There were only four other tables occupied when I arrived. I was greeted promptly and escorted to my booth. Coffee and menu arrived moments later. I hadn't been inside a Denny's in years, and my memory of Country Fried Steak was dominant in my head. I ordered that. It included two eggs (scrambled wet), and rye toast, in addition to the unlimited java. Service was friendly and timely. I was approached every few minutes as to my satisfaction and needs. Never felt neglected. 

My tastes have changed since the last time I had this breakfast in my early twenties. I remembered the crunch and meatiness of the steak, but had forgotten how heavily cloying the gravy was. I was able to remove a lot of it, but it was still a strong element of the meal, making for a salty and overly caloric feast. Still, the eggs were done perfectly, and their home fries were nicely crisp. With the three mugs of coffee I drank, it was a filling meal. 

Not sure there will be a next time, as, obviously, I seldom have the urge for Denny's. Yet, it was a decent, if salty, breakfast. It briefly connected me to my earlier life, and alerted me to how my tastes have changed. If there were to be a next time, I would lean to the french toast or pancakes, which they offer in abundant varieties. Prices are still quite reasonable.

I read the few reviews while waiting for my Turkey and Swiss Hoagie to be served in the back room dining area. I admit to feeling some restaurant remorse imagining what I was about to get with a Snapple for my $9. (hair sandwich with attitude played in my head). 

Instead, I received a very decent fresh soft Hoagie roll stuffed with my selections, including copious hot and sweet peppers, and a nice smile and "enjoy your lunch," from my server. I enjoyed the sandwich, and put the trepidation to rest. Nothing wrong with the meal. I am not in downtown Trenton that often these days, but I would certainly consider adding City Deli Hoagie Shop to the list of alternatives along Willow Street.

It has been a long while since I last visited an old world Wawa convenience store - the ones without gas stations attached. They are so busy building the latest version that when I walked in for a snack and coffee I thought I was in a Seven Eleven. It was that disconcerting. 

Still, it had the snacks and it had plenty of coffee, so I got what I came for. Although, I regretted it later when the food purchased (1/4 Lb beef hot dog) was so processed that I suffered with heartburn all night long. Won't be looking for that again. The coffee was fine. 

I don't actually use the gas pumps at Wawa, as they don't identify the refiner, nor distributor of the fuel, and thus there is no assurance of the quality of the gasoline, nor the additives that may/may not have been added. That being so, I would go to this chain more often if I didn't have to deal with the gas station aspect of the operation. 

On the other hand, assure me of the content of the gas and list it's pedigree, and I would be more willing to take advantage of the convenience once in a while, especially when away from my local friendly businessman and neighbor traditional gas station.

A few years ago I noticed that Mill Street, Bristol, PA, was experiencing a rebirth of vital commerce with many new stores, restaurants, cafes and even a classy bakery with a beautiful dining room and sugar coma inducing display of cookies, cakes, danish and donuts. That shop, Angelina's, was the subject of my breakfast explorations last week. 

First impressions were tremendous. Everything was whitewashed and had a Victoriana vibe. There were a dozen or so tables, and counter/highchairs in the two window bays on either side of the front door. Further back, the baked goods sat shelved and lit like colorful jewels and crystals waiting to be bagged and consumed. So seductive. 

I sat close by the front and checked the front of the two sided breakfast/lunch menu. I went with the "Thin French Toast," over the "Thick" alternative. I figured I was in a bakery, and it had to know about the proper approach to this traditional dish. Well, perhaps I was overconfident about that. 

The first clue of what was to come was the delivery of the FT accessories - butter and Smuckers syrup. The spread was fine, but that amber colloidal suspension was all high fructose corn syrup, about the worst thing for a human body. Luckily when the plate arrived, the four pieces of bread were sprinkled with powdered sugar, so I could skip the drip. Regular sugar is a better choice than artificial or high fructose sweetener.

When the finished platter arrived it looked good. I spread the butter to melt on the surface and cut a small wedge. It was obvious that it had spent little time in the egg/sugar/cinnamon/vanilla extract mix. The outside was nicely grilled, but the inside was dry. It had not been dredged in the mixing bowl long enough to permit absorption, but put too quickly on the grill. The chef needs find a better recipe.

 Oh, well. This wasn't going to be my best morning. *%It happens. 

I'll be back to check out those georgeous pastries. I suspect that is where I should have begun this adventure.

The Olde Worlde Bakerye & Café has 30 foot ceilings and suggests an old villa in Tuscany, with faux stone and large bread racks showing their attractive wares.  It does seem a little out of place sitting on Smithville Road in Eastampton, NJ, but that does not detract from its pleasant scale.  Outdoor patio seating for nice days is a definite upgrade from the ordinary java joint.  

I stopped in around 10 am for a light breakfast and coffee.  The large menu is suspended from the ceiling behind the cashiers.  Only brekkie sandwiches are available during the week, although a full brunch operation happens on weekends.  No sweat.  I wasn't looking or a big and hearty meal.  The unmistakable aroma of baked bread permeated the room, although they were not baking anything when I was there. The racks behind the counter were loaded to make a bread lover swoon.  All shapes and sizes demonstrated the artistry of the baker. Impressive.

My Sausage, Egg & Cheese on a Roll was okay, but not more. Their bread was fresh, but lacked the texture and yeastiness I expected from a homemade offering. The sausage patty was about the thinnest I have encountered, but still tasty.  The fried eggs and cheese were ample, and clearly cooked/melted on the grill.  At under $6 for the whole shebang I was ultimately satisfied with the value, if not the exuberance of the sandwich. 

Maybe their brunches have more of a "Wow!" factor.

Maybe if I hadn't just returned from a trip to southern Virginia where BBQ is a daily part of existence, I would have been more overcome with smoke ring lust for the meat factory that is Sweet Lucy's Smokehouse, but it was that travel into the near South that had me wanting more Q, and Lucy's was getting all the local accolades. It was the natural place to go.  

The adaptive reuse of an old industrial brick and mortar was well done, and the layout of the plant was well conceived with nice "country" dining area, new bar with very good brew list, and an efficient order and table delivery system.  Yet, their efficiencies cut some corners that should have been left in place.  

As first timers not knowing the lay of the land, the order and sit down process had to be explained, and the ability to have Q & A with someone about the menu important.  That was not really provided with pressure on the cashier to take orders as people stood before them and then accept payment.  It was hard to ask about the various options and receive comprehensive answers.  We ordered the BBQ Pulled Pork Platter, Half Rotisserie Chicken Platter and the Double the Fun (Ribs & Pulled Pork) Platter; all with Cornbread and a cross section of the many side dishes.  The prices were reasonable, and the wait not too long.  Going over to the bar in the dining room was easy enough, but required a second payment.  Unless you knew you would have room for desert and ordered with the entre, another queue-up was required.  Easier for the business, perhaps, but not for the customer.  

Then, everything arrived in styro and plastic wrap - a turnoff for both comfort and ecological reasons.  Open your white foam package with someone sitting across from you, and the top of each was overlapping and in the way of the other.  Awkward.  

There was plenty of meat and ample sides.  Yet, rather than using a confident dry rub in the smoker that would let the meat speak for itself, and allow a choice of saucy finishes, the plate arrived already covered in Kansas City style thick and somewhat salty/sour dark amber glaze. This one size fits all approach denied a choice of flavors that is so elemental to the full BBQ experience.  Personally, I prefer a sweet/tangy bite and chew that comes from a St. Louis, Memphis or even Carolina smokehouse, but there were no table rockets with these options, and I was unaware of any sauce alternatives as a newbie.  My Ribs were smoked well with pink ring, and it easily pulled off the bone.  Still, I would have been happier with a different sauce encasing the experience.  The Pulled Pork was soft and pleasantly chewy, but had a vinegar taste that was not my cup of tea.  Again, allow me to mix in what my tastebuds prefer, and I would have been a happier camper.  

The sides were all pretty good without any of them being standouts.  On the other hand, the Cornbread was excellent.  

Given the great beer choices and the generous portions, this could have been a full fledged BBQ riot with the ability to elect how I wanted the meal to cross my palette. I would gladly pay a bit more, or gorge a bit less, if given free choice (and be pleased with the meal arriving on a large swatch of paper rather than plastic). 

So near, but yet so far.

Eagle Diner on Street Road, Warminster, PA, is a traditional Greek food emporium with broad multi-page menu covering all three meals, plus a significant salad bar. It is open 24/7.  The only thing missing is a counter with stools for those who prefer that old line dining experience, like me. 

I stopped in for diner last weekend, hoping for a good meal for this solitary traveler. I had to wait about 15 minutes for a table, as the place was SRO when I arrived around 6 pm. A stool at a counter would have eliminated the wait, but I did not mind standing in the entrance area and observing all the scurry from the staff. It also gave me the chance to check out the cakes, pies and other bakery goods made on premises. Certainly did not hurt my appetite. 

I was eventually shown to a table in the back, and handed the short novelette menu. So much food; so little time. I chose their meatloaf mini dinner, with mashed and cup of soup or salad bar. I grazed over the greens for a while and returned with a full plate of various salad components. It wasn't a stunningly broad spread, and a lot of it was processed and not fresh, but it still provided many colors and flavors that worked well on top of a lettuce base. Three bean salad, beets, red onion, macaroni and potato salad, baby spinach, pickled everything, cheesebread and 1,000 Island dressing, kept me munching while waiting for the mains. 

When my entre arrived, I was confronted by two huge slices of baked/grilled beef loaf and a dish of white mashed, with brown gravy on the side. The meat was tender and tasty, but better with a jet of ketchup, than the brown sauce (a bit salty). The slices were about 1.5 inches thick. I couldn't finish the meal. Absolutely no room for the luscious looking desserts.

At a price around $10., the value was evident in every bite. 

I'm told Eagle does a good job for breakfast, too. Next time I'm in the area that time of day, I'll stop in again to check it out.

Golden Dragon at the corner of Liberty & Franklin, Trenton, NJ., looks like a new entry in the Chinese Take Out Wars.  The shop is cleaner than many, with room for four tables for those who prefer to eat in (like me).  The young family that runs the show seem to know what they're doing, with the wife at the counter taking orders and money, and hubby wok and rolling in the kitchen.  The third wheel, perhaps a brother, helps out and does deliveries.  

The lunch specials are the standard pork, chicken and shrimp in a variety of overlapping goopy sauces.  The fried rice is made in one large batch and has the yellow dye of most other chicken broth based steamers.  Unlike many of the other houses, this one is full of chunks of pork, peas, onion and carrots.  It actually tasted good.  My Pork Egg Foo Young was two pancakes, crisped edges, and loaded with meat, veggies and spouts.  The brown sauce was decent and packaged separately to keep things firm and able to be used at will.  It was a decent version of this old time dish.  

Service was as limited as you would expect a basic take away store to be.  No accommodation for customers wanting to eat at a table.  Everything packaged in styro and plastic, with thin fork and spoon to handle the mouth shovels. 

Still, at under $6., with soup or soda, it was a good deal.   

Nice quality for a take out joint, even if they don't really want you eating there.  Offer hot tea in addition to soda, and put the food on a real plate with better plasticware for those who eat in, and Golden Dragon could easily be a four star experience in take out cuisine.

UPDATE: MAY 3, 2017 -  Have to say that my second visit to Golden Dragon has put me in a generous mood about the quality of their food. Today I sampled their Hot & Sour Soup and General Tso's Chicken.  

The soup was surprisingly good.  It contained fresh cut mushrooms floating on top, and two types of soft tofu beneath.  The vinegar quotient was just right, and with the other veggies within, was about the best Chinese take out hot & sour I can remember tasting. Sucked all of that plastic container's contents dry.  The Chicken was also mostly meat and less shell, with a nicely balance spicy/sweet dark brown topaz sauce. The fried rice was plentiful, and although mass produced, still granular and full of pork, pea, carrot, etc. chunks.  

Overall, an impressive lunch from this far flung outpost of the Chinese Empire at the corner of Franklin and Liberty.  

Do it again, and you could find yourself the recipient of a full forth star.  But, for now...

3.5 Stars, with a bullet!

I've driven around the block on various occasions trying for a parking spot within hailing distance of Trenton Bagel Shop on South Broad Street in Trenton, just one block south of State Street.  Never found one and thus was never able to walk into the shop until last Friday when I was at the NJ Motor Vehicle Commission over on Stockton Street.  After our appeals hearing was over (successfully), I decided this was the best chance to get over there.  It was about a quarter mile away, but it was a nice day for a walk. 

The store was larger than expected, with a big kitchen area and several tables around the perimeter.  The bagel selection was depleted at 10:30, but I ordered an Everything Bagel, Butter and Swiss and Java from the pleasant women behind the counter.  The $3.50 price for all this was a pleasant surprise.  Left the balance of my fin in the tip jar.  

On first bite it was obvious that my bagel was no longer fresh from the oven, and had been around at least since early in the morning.  It wasn't bad, it just wasn't at its apex texture and taste.  Looking toward the rear of the space I tried to find evidence of baking on premises, but could neither see, hear nor smell anything like hot dough in the air.  Could well be that the bagels were created elsewhere and delivered.  Not a problem when the bread is fresh, but tends to staleness before a round hole baked only a few feet away.  

The coffee was that "Law" company product.  Not the best brew for take out as it drifts into bitterness as it cools.  

Glad I finally checked out Trenton Bagel, but given the difficulty of approaching the shop via auto, and the step below first quality of both its namesake and the Joe, there is no urge to return anytime soon.

Pretty much a standard Pennsylvania roadside diner down on Street Road, Bensalem. It is well maintained, has friendly professional staff, large menu and reasonable prices. 

I stopped in for breakfast recently, and sat on a stool at the traditional counter. Coffee was immediately available from the Bunn-O-Matic, and my request for milk over creamer was met with a small glass of moo juice. The daily special omelette was described well, and server and I agreed quietly that ham, bacon and sausage was just too much meat for three eggs to handle. Opted instead for short stack french toast and java only. Lately, it seems I am not as hungry in the morning, which helps explain the increased bagginess of my pants. 

The thick white load was good with adequate saturation of the egg/vanilla/sugar mix into the heart of both slices. The soft butter and Smuckers table syrup finished off the plate. It was all grilled well, but providing a pour of pure Grade B maple would have been so much more satisfying. I would pay a buck or two extra for that sweet smokiness soaked into my bread. The cuppa joe was decent and refilled frequently. 

I departed $10 the poorer, including gratuity. Not bad for this part of Street Road, right down the street from Parx Casino.

As part of my discovery of the western burbs around Philly now that I find myself on the turnpike twice a month, I stopped in at Pho Thai Nam last weekend. 

The space is brightly decorated from top to bottom.  This must be how a marriage between Thai and Vietnamese looks.  Glistening stars against a black night sky, and warm sunset tones from wall to wall.  Very attractive.  The only issue I have comes from their apparent success.  The place is excessively loud, making normal conversation across the table difficult.  

But, who talks while slurping Pho?  I ordered the Steak and Brisket Pho (Pho Tai Chin), and it arrived promptly, a steaming large bowl of Beef Broth, Noodles, lots of thin sliced Beef, with a nice plate of Thai Basil, Bamboo Shoots, Jalapeno Slices, Lime Wedges, with Hoisin and Sriracha on the side to add zest where needed.  

It was very good - rich, savory, subtle undertones and long untamed noodles waiting to uncoil like a nest of vipers.  I enjoyed every slurping spoonful and chopstick clasp of it.  The only reservation would be he $9.95 cost, which is a couple of bucks more than other places I frequent.  I guess you pay for the popularity, because the place was crowded.  

While I wouldn't rush back to Pho Thai Nam as it was no better than similar places closer to home, and there are other highly recommended joints nearby, I certainly would not hesitate to return should someone desire the experience.

Corner joint on Brownsville Road, Trevose, Pa., Peppe's Mexican Grill is a family run kitchen turning out good South of the Border plates. Owners appear bilingual, adding a splash of interest and authenticity to a shop that is full of local schoolgirls behind the counter. 

The menu is small compared to the casas Latinas in the Hispanic community in Trenton where I normally indulge my love for this cuisine, but what they do, they do well. Our burritos (chicken & shrimp) were stuffed to the max, and the two young guys devouring them barely came up for air. My flautas de carnitas were nicely rolled, stuffed and grilled tortillas full of roast pork, chilies, cheese, with bright red salsa, avocado, shredded lettuce and drizzled crema on top. Looked and tasted good. 

Although we ate in, the food was brought to us as if it was to go. Plastic plates and utensils, wrapped in foil, etc. I prefer to be treated like a dine in customer when electing to eat while the food is hot, and would pay a little more for the pleasure. Too, the environment would benefit from less throw away stuff. 

I liked Peppe's, understood it's neighborhood, but it could make a few moves to be a lot better. They do make their own horchata, which is a great sign of the possibilities.

I've been on a bit of a bagel kick recently, bringing me to Redhouse Bagels in the Salem Center, Bensalem, PA. It is a large, comfortable shop with Kids Playroom (currently closed due to Covid), fire pit with worn easy chairs around it, and large self-serve coffee station with several java options. The vibe was welcoming and service friendly. 

I ordered an Onion Bagel with Veggie Cream Cheese, one of my standards. It was ready in minutes, packed neatly in a white paper sack. I drove home and dove in. 

The dough wheel was regular size and there was enough spread for a balanced chew. First glance, the color of the bagel appeared pale white compared to others I have eaten in recent months. The toasted onion flakes were larger than most bagelries, and were only on the top crown, with none on the side nor bottom. Too, the texture was denser than I prefer, indicating more kneading than necessary for a lighter, airier center. All in all, it left the impression that this was really a plain bagel with onion flakes added later on. My guess is that they also bake with bleached flour, rather than unbleached, which provides more color and flavor.

The bagel was okay, but would have been so much better with more attention to right ingredients, technique, and finish. A bagel school refresher course would likely do the trick.

While the tuna hoagie was prepared with the requested ingredients through Subway's app, the proportions weren't quite right, and as a result it was about the messiest sandwich I had consumed in several years. 

Plenty of tuna, lettuce, tomato, green pepper, banana pepper, and sweet pepper hash loaded into their signature "footlong" roll, but also way too much squirt from the sweet onion sauce rocket, leaving the bread saturated and too weak to hold the entire package together. The result being a soggy, but tasty, mess, adding far too much sugar and unwanted calories to an otherwise simple creation. The flavor of the tuna was drowned out, and I had to find extra paper hand towels to keep the fallout under control. 

The shop itself was exceptionally clean, and the counter person friendly as she completed my order after my arrival. She was generous with the accoutrements, and therein lay the problem. There was so much being stuffed into the torpedo that in wrapping up in waxed sandwich paper, I could see it starting to leak around the edges. Upon unwrapping at my desk, the excess moisture was escaping, and rivulets of sauce were flowing everywhere. With each bite food was evacuating out the back door, and my hands were getting drenched. The supply of thin non-absorbent napkins was quickly exhausted, and my fingers dripping and sticky. 

Just not the kind of thing designed for a tidy working lunch. Yes, it tasted pretty good, but I had to wash my hands and face before touching anything else. If there is a next time, I will be better prepared, or better yet, get the superior Primo hoagies on the other side of town with that special sesame seeded roll.

This Chick Fil A wannabe does a decent job of frying chicken strips into a reasonably good signature sandwich.  Fresh chicken, crisp breading, and not overly oily.  

The fries are average, and the corn is sweet. 

As good a choice as any if you find yourself needing sustenance while at Oxford Valley Mall.

Gyro Express is an Afghan gyro shop on the old pedestrian mall section of West State Street, Trenton, NJ.  It has a menu limited to about a dozen items all related to beef, lamb, chicken and falafel pita wraps or open platters with basic salads.  The primary owner is the face of the business, and he has a warm and polite persona. He is a great salesman. 

I went with a combo plate of grilled chicken, beef and falafel, that included a small iceberg based salad and a bed of yellow rice. It was covered in a nice white dipping sauce and small side cups of a spicy green colloid that added a hot dimension to the meats. 

The lunch was okay. There was ample protein, well grilled and tasty when mixed with the sauces and rice. Didn't see the spits that they may have been cooked on, and didn't smell that savory aroma that is so pleasantly addictive. I left most of the rice behind to avoid unwanted carbs, but enjoyed the small slices of meat and crushed falafel. 

Gyro Express is a worthy option in the State Street food carnival, but not nearly the excellent Afghani delights found just across the Delaware in Morrisville, PA, where Afghan Kabob holds court in the Morrisville Shopping Center. Worth a long lunch hour walk over the Calhoun Street Bridge to sample ethnic dishes on a different order of magnitude.

Poppy's Pizzeria sits alone on a desolate stretch of Woods Lane, Langhorne, Pa. I didn't even know it was there for a dozen years until a detour took me past it recently.

 It was Friday night - Pizza Night - so,what the heck?!

The layout was casual with three sections in the dining area. Tight booths and tables all around. HDTVs mounted high in the corners. We seated ourselves. Our server arrived quickly and introduced herself with menus in hand. We ordered a round pie half mushrooms, half sausage; a dozen Buffalo wings and cheesesteak calzone. 

Everything was okay. The wings were hot from the hot sauce bath, but arrived looking overdone with several bones exposed and charred, but tasty. The pie had the right ingredients, if less than a full complement of shrooms and meat and lacking a crisp crust. The calzones was stuffed to the gills with steak, but could have used more onion and pepper within for added flavor. Took most of that home. 

Poppy's has promise, and with a more skilled hand in the kitchen could find themselves in a more elevated zone.

Aside from the dude hanging up without an answer when I called to see if The Sticky Wicket was open for lunch, the joint itself isn't a bad place for a dive bar with adequate kitchen.  

Located in a desolate part of Trenton that at one time attempted to be a modern commercial area, it now is one of the few remaining tenants in Independence Square. The space is large, with an attached liquor store and a large rectangular bar with room to sit and have a meal.  The atmosphere is dark and wood paneled, giving the feeling that there are things in the corners you might not want to know about.  With a few hunting trophies on the walls, TSW could be a Western dive bar, as it has the feel of a large cabin.  

I ordered a medium patty melt burger, fries and a cold Angry Orchard Apple Cider.  The prices were pretty good, with the food under $8., and the coldie at $5.50.  Good, friendly staff, and many regulars who seemed to know each other and kept the repartee moving along.  My patty melt was half medium as requested, but the other half was well done, no doubt from pushing it to the side of the grill to give it lower heat, but failing to turn it to keep the cooking balanced.  Although the menu claims the patties were never frozen, I have doubts about that given the crumbly nature of the finished puck.  It was an okay sandwich, but could have been much more given the copious fried onions, and melty cheese. I liked that it was on marble rye.  

It is nice to know that Sticky Wicket is open and keeping busy.  It is a cool place to hang out over lunch.  If they served up a better burger I would become a fan.

Stumbled upon Zeeno's the other day after a stop at Oxford Valley Mall to pick up something at Sears.  I just needed a snack to keep my hunger at bay.  

I went it to find a brightly lit pizza joint with 8 to 10 tables along one wall, and the work area/cashier on the other.  Kitchen in the back.  It seemed fairly clean.  World Cup on the HD hanging from the wall.  I ordered two plain slices to test the water.  

The chef came out of the kitchen to deliver my lunch.  The slices were smaller than normal, and the outer crust smooth rather than textured.  This was a cheese over sauce pie, where the sauce hides beneath the melted mozza.  This maintains the heat better than exposing the gravy, but also adds a lot of extra cheese to accomplish this approach.  I prefer a balance with less cheese so I can taste the sauce distinctly.  I would call this a Middle Eastern Pizza, rather than Italian.  Not bad, but not in the mainstream of East Coast tomato pie.  

While it was not my favorite pizza, it was adequate for what it was.  The ingredients were fine; just not the style I like. The rest of the menu looked intriguing, especially if the kitchen was consistently eastern Mediterranean.  The gyro options might be the way to go here.

This is a Tale of Two Cities kind of review. 

The shop sits on a concrete island on Business Rt. 1 in Penndel, Pa.  It's the kind of location where the only green you can see is the crabgrass in the cracks in the sidewalk. Not a pretty place.  Yet, the inner space is not bad - bright, lots of glass, and an open kitchen where you can see food being prepared if you care to do that in fast food joints.  

The food we tried was schizophrenic.  The Western Burger (w/ A1 Sauce and large Onion Ring) was a frozen patty that was lifeless and too well done when it reached the table.  The crinkle cut fries were plentifully boring. Never do that again.

Yet, the Pressure Fried Chicken was another story all together.  The breasts were large and juicy.  The skin crisp and nicely spiced.  This seemed to be a clucker that had never been frozen.  It was among the best fried chicken I have had in the area during my recent obsession with this cuisine.  

The menu is large, but it mostly revolved around deep fryer, pressure cooker and grill.  They do BBQ, Hoagies, Panini, Wraps, Soup and Salads.  Some of those choices looked pretty good as other folks wolfed them down.  

The Tummy Yummies is a name that is cringeworthy, but they may just do enough things right to make it worth the occasional stop.

La Morena (The Brunette), sits on East Moreland Avenue just off the intersection with S. York Road in Hatboro, PA. It is a very small casa Mexicana, with about six tables with kitchen in the rear. It offers no parking, making for a difficult time for a vehicle if not familiar with this area. Apparently, there is an unmarked public lot across the street and down the block, but it is hard to see at night. 

The menu is fairly much standard South of the Border fare, with somewhat higher than average prices, particularly in the dinner section. Service is provided by a very pleasant woman who I took to be La Morena, herself. She seems to be doing everything, including cooking, bussing, cleaning and greeting. There is one other person in the kitchen. 

I ordered the chili relleno (stuffed pablano pepper) dinner, including rice, refried beans and side container of fairly fresh tortillas. The pepper was a fatty, with room for diced chicken in addition to the queso and crema. Decent red salsa poured over the top. It was good and filling, but not outstanding. Actually, the refried beans were the best part of the platter, with interesting flavor. I thought it should have been better for the $14 charge, especially since I had a similar dinner a few weeks before at a nearby Mexican restaurant for several dollars less, with much more compelling taste. The tortillas were clearly reheat jobs, as part of each was hot, while the rest was cold. 

Given the dearth of parking, and the less than stellar performance of my dinner, the conglomerated experience was just okay. I think the kitchen is capable of better, but I may have missed the right selection to discover its greatness.

Westampton Family Diner sits at the outskirts of downtown Mt. Holly, standing sentry for all the traffic entering or leaving that historic burg.  In the middle of the last century it was about the only place to enjoy a sit down meal that wasn't grandma's house.  Those days have come and gone, and WFD has definitely seen its heyday pass it by.  Now, the center of town is coming back to life with new money and better ideas, while the old diner has yet to catch on to the new energy at the core of the city.  

Really hope it can take its cues from the newer places nearby that are reinventing themselves and becoming pleasant and interesting joints for drinking and eating.  It would be a cultural shame to lose its place as the purveyor of huge plates of hash, flash and dash for the masses that it once was, and could be again with some new ideas.  

When I was there earlier in the week for a quick breakfast, the first impression was of a place full of old folks both customers and staff.  It felt downright geriatric.  The countertop formica was worn and exhausted.  The equipment was several generations behind state of the art.  Dust and grime collected in the corners.  I felt a wave of fatigue overcome me before reaching the counter stool.  Coffee was required immediately.

Despite the aging optics, my simple breakfast of Coffee and toasted Corn Muffin was quite satisfying.  The java was hot and brewed with decent enough beans to alert my buds to an awakening.  The Muffin was homemade and the largest I had seen in many years.  Yes. It was fresh and very tasty.  

Its location is across Rt. 541 from the court, and thus very convenient for my early arrival to beat traffic approach to work.  I will return on occasion, and hope that they can examine the new places opening up in town and adopt new style and menu to keep up with the changing tastes of the new age.

Hong Luck is a traditional Chinese American restaurant on New Rogers Road, Levittown, PA. The same family has run the shop for over two decades. Bamboo screens and petrified blowfish are the most noticeable decor accents. 

I was there for lunch earlier in the week on a first visit. My order was taken by the husband, although his wife was also out front at times. They were both friendly, if not loquacious. The menu was large, with a backpage of luncheon special combo plates. I went with the Hunan Beef, which included cup of soup (wonton) and pork fried rice. 

In my experience, Hunan style is a spicy cuisine that gets it heat from a fermented black bean sauce and secondarily, Szechuan chili peppers. This dish had neither, but instead seemed to be overloaded with straight black/white pepper and salt. It made me thirsty instantly. Although the beef was thinly sliced and tender, the sauce made it difficult to enjoy. On the other hand the beef stock in the wonton soup was better than average, the dumpling not too thick skinned and the meat filling, decent. The fried rice was a bit on the hard side and had seen better days. 

This isn't in my neighborhood, and it is doubtful I would return given my first taste impressions. Obviously, they have succeeded all this time without my involvement, and they will no doubt continue to do so hereafter.

Ariana's Pizzeria & Italian Restaurant on Levittown Parkway is a basic pizza parlor with booths and tables that seems primarily to toss and bake tomato pies and related sandwiches, calzones, wraps, etc., that can be found in most red sauce establishments. They also have a short list of dinners and entrees that looked appealing on the menu. 

We were all hungry and took the chance on the bigger (more expensive) meals, rather than the safer sandwich route. To some extent we regretted that decision. Each came with small side salad, heated torpedo rolls and butter, and a bed of pasta under the chicken offerings. Salad was fine. Bread hot and crusty, and spaghetti copious. 

Problem was that while the marsala was decent with a nice load of fresh mushrooms in a sauce closely resembling what it should be, the Ricci and Abbruzzio chicken dishes were not quite right.  The Ricci lacked much flavor despite the load of sauce and melted mozza, and a corner of the pasta was much cooler than the rest of the platter, like it had been sitting too long far from the stove. A little red and black pepper in the mix while cooking would have made a big difference. The Abbruzzio with the large bore pasta looked great, but the chicken was overcooked and tough, and the sauce flavor, AWOL.

I was overall content with my dinner, but the fact that my family ate so little of their's reflected the reviews they would write if asked. We took the leftovers home to see with we could improve them with a little doctoring. Yet, at more than $15 per dish, we were unhappy with our choices and the abilities in the kitchen. 

Teaches us to go out to eat hungry. Definitely clouded our judgment on how to attack the menu. 

2.5 STARS

If you enjoy throwback mid-twentieth century breakfasts and lunches, you really should give Sneddon's Luncheonette a visit. In the middle of Bridge Street in the Jersey Delaware River town of Lambertville, it is an excellent example of counter centered food service just as it was 70 years ago.  Formica countertop, a dozen spinners, open grill kitchen, and lovely ladies pouring joe and slinging hash up and down the line. Sneddon's is one of those places where you really can eat the atmosphere. 

My morning stop to break my fast included several cups of hot java from the Bunn-O-Matic, and a short stack of french toast, served in tandem by two women who were straight from central casting. No extra charge for the charming small talk. There were three egg toast alternatives on the board, and I chose the standard white bread dipper, so to start with the basics and hopefully work my way up the list.  

Gotta say, that the FT was the weakest element of the experience. I watched as the cook put the bread in a bowl of whipped egg and dropped them onto the hot steel.  He was multi-tasking and could have been more attentive to my space on the grill. What I received were two very eggy slices of Wonder Bread, where a lot of the egg was still on the surface, and had not completely absorbed into the center of the bread.  Given how thin they were, the absence of moist egg in the core was surprising (and a disappointment). It wasn't bad, and the melted butter and syrup certainly made the experience okay, but it could have been much more with a little more TLC in the preparation. 

Still, I enjoyed the experience of finally getting to this institution.  Service was fun, the coffee was hot and ample, and the room itself like eating in a museum.  I was told the breakfast sandwiches and corn beef hash were stars, and will give them both a try on my next visit.

I remember the uproar when Applebees and another fast food shop were permitted to enter Newtown.  It was the beginning of the end to life as we knew it! 

Not.

Applebees has taken its place as a well utilized restaurant in the Village of Newtown Shopping Center.  It follows the national formula and does not deviate beyond the mean.  It is busy for lunch, dinner and late night, and fits the need for a modestly priced option among all the high end restos in the area.  

I don't go often, but I am glad it is there.  When I do, I stick with the ample fresh salads, and an occasional burger.  I sit at the bar when I dine alone, or one of the booths when with family.  I have not had a bad experience, nor ever felt it was misplaced here.  

Go. Enjoy. Have a good time. This shop is locally owned by The Rose Group, and even if you prefer to avoid chains that expropriate your money out of the community, this particular franchise does not.  You can have a clear conscience.

Meat. Meat. And, more meat. 

This is heaven if home cooked roast beef, roast pork, meatballs, sausage sandwiches/platters in any combination (read, pepperoni), is your dietary preference.  If it's not, then you're plumb out of luck.  

Sandy's is an unabashedly meaty place, in a dark tavern with HDTVs on every wall.  It sits in the middle of that small strip center out front of Oxford Valley Mall, facing Route 1.  The unique part of the experience here is that the meats are actually cooking and prepared for serving at the bar.  You can sit almost anywhere in the house and watch the steam table being opened and your order being set up in a torpedo roll or on a plate.  That's pretty cool.  

They also give you a ton of meat with every dish.  Our roast pork sandwich was overflowing the loaf and spilling onto the plate.  The meatball sub had four nice sized spheres topped with a good tomato sauce.  Both were totally cooked into submissive tenderness, and had good taste.  The pork needed a little kicker if a more spicy finish was desired.  The meatballs were good just as they were.  The only real weakness was the quality of the roll.  They lacked any body and were quickly overcome by the moisture of the meat, turning soggy and difficult to handle fairly quickly.  The fork was invented for just such circumstances, and ours were put to good use.  The positive was that were ended up eating most of the meat without the bread, and saved those calories. 

Used them up on the dark, cold, slow Guinness. Ahhh....perfect complement. 

Sandy's is CASH ONLY, with a captive ATM on the premises.

BBQ Chicken PA is a Korean Fried chicken stall in the Assi Market, Welsh Road, North Wales. It is in the small food court on the right side of the warehouse-sized store. I was looking for a late lunch of double deep fried wings, plus some to take home to the family. 

I thought I ordered enough with Secret Spicy sauce, but turned out the order taker put in the order for half my request, despite my double checking with him. That bleach job must have turned his brains blond in addition to his hair. Yet, maybe he was doing me a favor.

Eating the first one let me know that these guys were not the super crisp wings I've had elsewhere. Nope. These were slathered in the garnet red goop with good flavor, but the skin was not crunchy as anticipated. Plenty of meat in the bone, but lacking the corresponding bite. 

Suddenly, the dude's inattentiveness was a small blessing as it cut my disappointment in half. Ten okay wings were better than twenty less than optimal pieces. 

I'll be sure to thank him next time I'm in the neighborhood.
