Still love the colonial ambiance of the rear dining room and the tight squeeze of the front oval bar. The outdoor deck is also a cool place to hang out on a warm night. Yet, the kitchen remains inconsistent despite the more upscale menu and corresponding prices. 

My son and I stopped in earlier this week to enjoy some time together before he returned to school. We had alot to talk about. We were given the table right beneath the large blackboard specials menu where they were advertising Steak Night. That moved the young man to order a New York Strip and frite, medium rare. Nice move. I went with one of their burgers with Gouda and "Million $$$ Bacon," medium, with garlic mashed rather than fries. Pineville at its best had always been a great burger house and I imagined our reunion after several years would be best served by honoring that memory. 

It didn't quite work out that way this night. 

While the steak looked and smelled awesome and kept my son entertained from first to last red juicy bite, my classic puck arrived far closer to well done than medium that not even liberally spread ketchup could revive, and the mashed tasted more of salt than garlic. I managed to eat half knowing it would be devoured when my son regained his appetite in the morning. Still, there was no denying my disappointment. 

The dinner was saved by the spectacular homemade Rice Pudding (w whipped cream) that Pineville is also famous for. It hadn't lost any of its seductive taste - cool, chunky, mildly sweet with a nice cinnamon powdered finish. Served in a large coffee mug, it overran it's confines into the saucer beneath. We were careful to capture every last drop. Simply wonderful! 

The night would have been five star if we began and ended with dessert, but the road to that perfection was paved with poor execution. Three estrellas is as far as I can go despite the blazing last act.

Akai Japanese Fusion is a Chinese owned/operated fresh fish house at the top of Mill Street, Bristol, PA. It replaced an old luncheonette, and has done a decent renovation to give it a darker ambient feel. Perhaps, too much narrow gauge siding and flooring, but don't blame them for saving money where they could. 

The menu is long on sushi, sashimi and rolls, with a tip of the cap to Chinese and Thai cuisine. So, it's not really a fusion house, but wants to appeal to the fish phobes with a little something more palatable to them. Problem is, that seldom works, and those few offerings are poor relations to the primary actors. That appears to be the case here. More confusion than fusion. 

So, I went with the salmon teriyaki bento box - 2 small pink fish fillets in a good sauce, 2 gyoza, 6 piece California roll and white rice. The salmon was pleasantly crunchy, the gaozi fried with a chicken filling, and ordinary Cali's. All reasonably satisfying, but nothing more spectacular. It would have been nice to be provided with enough ginger for all the roll nuggets, and more wasabi to mix with soy for dipping. Showed a lack of attention to detail that recommended against a return visit. 

2.5 STARS

Pizza Express on South Olden Avenue, Trenton, is one of several Spanish houses dressed up like pizzerias around the city.  Most of the menu looks and tastes Italian, but in the heart of the kitchen, hot Latin blood flows like the Rio Grande.  It is almost exclusively a take away shop, but there are two hightops for those few who prefer to eat while the food is at is apex of flavor and texture - right off the grill, or out of the oven.  

Orders are taken across a high counter for defensive measures in the neighborhood.  The woman on the other side was pleasant and knowledgeable.  I asked about the best things on their Mexi-Rican list, and was given a few suggestions.  Well, maybe next time, but for now I was taken by the empanadas, of which I chose queso and papas (cheese & potato).  

They arrived in their take out container, packaged neatly in a brown bag, stapled perfectly across the top.  I ripped it open and pulled out the styro box and little plastic cups of fresh, chunky salsa.  I dumped them on top of the two dough pockets.  They looked very nice together.  Still, it would have been nice if they gave me a fork or other utensil with which to consume my lunch.  Fingers would have to suffice.  

Both were very good.  The cheese was melted and gooey, and the outer shell firm and crisp.  Same for the potato bag.  The contents were well mashed and spiced, with only small pieces of whole spud for a little texture.  Liked them both, and would certainly expand my horizons by sampling the other stuffings.  

Should they see fit to serve their eat-in customers with a bit more hospitality, by throwing in real plates and functional flatware and even a few more tables and chairs to eat in house, Pizza Express could find itself in a fortunate cycle of improved ratings.  Right now, the priority is take out. Understandable, but the value of folks finding and sticking to your place is only enhanced when they can hang around to enjoy their grub.

DELIVERED LUNCH REVIEW :

Once a month I go to Norristown, PA, for an office meeting. Lunch is eaten in the conference room as we talk. It is routinely ordered from Rocco's the morning of the get together. The entire menu is in play. To date, I have gone with two of their salads and a hot eggplant Parmesan sandwich. The others around the table have sampled other things, with personal size pizza a standard option. 

Now, it is not fair to rate take out or delivered meals the same way you do for those eaten in the restaurant. They can't be as good after packaging, cooling, crushing and sitting around for a while. (Yelp should consider a check off that makes this clear.) Still, this is part of the dining experience and should be part of learning about the vendor. 

After these three experiences, I no longer order salads because I find them too past their prime upon consumption, even with the salad dressing applied just before eating. Just not very enjoyable. However, the grinder wrapped in foil and paper, although somewhat diminished in transport, retained its heat and flavor to a large extent. Yes, the torpedo roll had already lost its verve, but it kept its structural integrity, and was a solid handhold throughout the meal. The condensation as it cools has to go somewhere, and the bread is the only absorbing surface. It was a fair trade off for a tasty sammy, although I wouldn't say the same for the limp pizzas I have seen falling apart on the way to the bocca. 

Obviously, I am not a delivery fan, but sometimes it is necessary. Rocco's does what it can to make everyone happy with what arrives from their shop. I suspect cold hoagies are the way to go, and I will order one next month, and report back to you. 

Mangia bene!

Oaks Family Restaurant in Pipersville, PA, is a roadside café specializing in breakfast/brunch/lunch for the folks of upper Bucks County. It sits on Easton Road (Rt. 611) about ten miles north of Doylestown. It has a country vibe, with small counter with half dozen spinners, and a dining room to one side with about a dozen tables. 

When I arrived earlier this week, the place was buzzing mostly with guys shooting the s*^t about local and current events. I found a stool at the end of the counter next to the cash register and plopped down for my morning meal. The servers were friendly and engaging; handing me a menu and taking my drink order promptly. Coffee with milk, por favor. I chose french toast based on the recommendation of the lady taking my order.

I won't hold that against her, but the egged fry bread left much to be desired. Although a thin sliced loaf, the center of the bread was dry because it had not been dipped long enough in the egg mix before frying. Too, I couldn't taste any vanilla or cinnamon, nor was there any caramelization of sugar from the hot steel. It seemed each slice had an egg skirt around it from where the mix had splashed down with the bread on the grill. I'm not a forensic chef, but there was evidence of lack of attentiveness in the kitchen. The result, a disappointing performance, and a lost opportunity to make a strong positive first impression. 

The coffee was fine, and service, sterling. Still, when the star of the show doesn't come through for the audience, it is hard to give a standing ovation.

2.5 STARS

I did Thai takeout at South Seas on York Road, Abington, PA, today, and gotta say I was somewhat disappointed. No issue negotiating the narrow driveway alongside the orange faced shop to reach the small parking lot in the rear, nor dealing with the staff inside picking up my order of Tom Kha Soup and Drunken Noodles (veggie). No, the problem was strictly the content of the food when I got home to consume it.

Neatly packed in leak proof containers and brown paper handled bag, it was fun to unload and helped build anticipation. The coconut soup had all the right ingredients and was as spicy as desired. Fresh mushrooms floating on top with carrot, string bean, broccoli, tofu and  chunks of ginger and long fibrous lemongrass lurking beneath the surface like gators in a muddy milky river.

 Therein lay the problem. Love the bite of lemongrass and the tartness of ginger, but not when there is so much of it that it outweighs the edibles in the bowl. I tried chewing them to extract the flavor since there was so much of it, but the tough hard texture proved daunting, and I surrendered before putting a splinter in my gums or cracking a tooth. 

Aside from that, the taste of the actual soup was good. 

The Drunken was a large portion, but of middle width, rather than the broad rice pasta it is supposed to be. Narrower gauge means less surface area to hold the essential spicy sauce, and much less chew, which is key to the tactile experience of this dish. Too, the exact same veggies in the soup were in this melange, but not very much of them. The proportion of noodles to greens was off, with far too little of the crunchys, and way too heavy on the carbs, making the ensemble denser and drier than it should have been, without the joy of hot noodles glistening from the devilish sauce.

Thai Spicy, yes. Thai balanced, 'fraid not. 

It just didn't work very well, and had me questioning who was cooking behind the Covid masks. Maybe that was why the shop looked like Chinese takeout, without any element of Siam decor. Nary a Buddha nor elephant in sight. 

2.5 STARS

Gianni's Pizza is a backdoor walkout Italian house on the bottom floor of an much larger and older building on Bustleton Pike in Richboro, Pa.  The fit out is smallish, and has the feel of a nicely finished basement.  The menu has the usual suspects of most pizza parlors, the service is friendly, and the prices amazingly low.  

We sat in a booth in the newly painted dining area.  It was comfortable, if a bit tight.  We ordered the Old Fashioned Tomato Pie with Mushrooms and the Chicken Parm dinner, with the intention of sharing both.  No problem getting them served at the same time.  The dinner came with a house salad and pasta.  The greens were a basic romaine mix with a few red onion shavings, cherry tomatoes, cukes, and a standard balsamic.  It was cool and refreshing.  

The Chicken Parm plate at $10.99 was what the cost implied.  Prefab chicken breast patties covered in sauce and mozza.  Not bad, but not all that tasty.  The side of penne with aglio olio was better, but needed more garlic to really announce itself.  The Tomato Pie had a thicker airy crust, perhaps to hold the weight of the too loose sauce topside. The wetness above caused the bottom layer to get soggy, and impossible to pick up without a tomato slide.  It was a situation where less would have been more.  Keep the sauce thicker and chunkier, and the moisture would not have been an issue.  In fact, we brought most of it home and re-baked it the next day, and produced the right texture and flavor.  

This place has some nice things going for it with location, ambiance and service, but our sampling of the food suggested that perhaps in the attempt to keep prices low they sacrificed some of the finer points of Italian cooking.  

There are better choices around if looking for good food from the boot.

Made a return visit after an hiatus of almost 2 years, and was pleasantly surprised to find the house redecorated with more comfortable seating and brighter lights. 

Accompanied by a teenager and his mom, I again realized that American fast burgers are very popular.  I tried one of their discount double burgers and fries, and found that while they were no match for Five Guys or that ilk, they were still decent and satisfying.  Watching the young guy wolf down his Double Baconator was eye opening. He was totally into it.  Oh, and the fries was ample and crispy.  

Time for an upgrade. 

No apologies!

I guess I did not do Yardley Pizza any favors by going to DeLorenzo's Tomato Pies last Saturday night. By my taste, DeLo's has one of the best pies I have eaten, and I have been a fan of theirs for more than 30 years. So, coming to Yardley Pizza for the next slices really puts them in a bad place.  Apologies before I go any further.

Anyway, the floor plan is quite nice. Bigger than expected inside, and comfortably casual with sufficient space between tables for a private conversation.  The staff is friendly and helpful.  Tuesday is Dollar Slice Day (I didn't know), so the price was right! The two plain slices I had were fairly typical of the American Pizzeria.  Triangular cuts with decent, if thin, sauce and mass produced cheese.  A little oil on the surface, but not enough for a big drip. 

Alas, the slices were quite ordinary in every respect. Nothing to sit up and take notice about, but certainly a better than average competent American slice of pizza.  The crust held up well, and did not droop under the weight of the toppings.  The bite held its crunch to the very last.  It was only the sauce and cheese that missed the mark.  Again, not bad, but not eye-opening. 

As I said, DeLo's is a very difficult act to follow.

The Pineville Tavern is worth a try just for the historic structure and ambiance in the older rooms.  Someone once said you can't eat the atmosphere, but here it is possible to almost taste it.  The institution is worthy of respect.
The latest changes have been both good and bad.  Read the other reviews to understand the complaints and disappointments. For me, this place has always been about beer, wings, burgers, and rice puddling.  The other stuff designed to attract a wider audience may not float everyone's boat.  
Stick with what they do best, and you will leave happy and full.

Finally made it to Dim Sum Garden. 

Located mid-street on Race, it is a deep and narrow space with a step up half way back at the kitchen and mini-bar area.  One wall is slate, and the other smooth with the image of a huge dumpling adorning the wall.  That same design is emblazoned on the black T's worn by the wait staff.  I wouldn't mind wearing one of those.  

Entering solo around 7:30, the tables were buzzing, but not SRO.  I was pointed to a deuce in the front window, and quickly choose to look inward rather than out toward the street.  If I was in a metaphorical mood that might mean something.  It seems natural to want to enjoy the floorshow.  The menu arrived promptly with a glass of water (cold, not hot), and a few minutes later the server returned to direct me through the offerings.  I knew I wanted the Xiao Long Bao (#1) because that what was most people raved about, but I also wanted a second dish - selecting Eggplant with Garlic Sauce as counterpoint.    

Part of the schtick here is the servers offer to show you how to eat XLB.  For the uninitiated there is a learning curve and the risk of spraying scalding broth onto your neighbors, so there is some reason for caution.  Mild dexterity in the use of chopsticks and flat bottom spoon in tandem is required, but once mastered the manipulation becomes part of the fun.  Even life long experts can be seen chasing escaped dumplings across the table, so there is no fear of lost face.  

I was surprised that the XLB were not as good as I expected.  Their dough was thicker than I have had in the famous Shanghai dumpling shops.  True, the pork filling was substantial and decent, and the steaming soup within pretty good, but they were disappointing nonetheless. Even the "Dumpling Sauce" on the tables was not quite right to my palate.  It used a vinegar that too strongly neutralized the flavor of the broth.  There was no ginger to mix with the vinegar. I had to mix the hot chili oil with the sauce on the plate to get to the heat I wanted to supplement the taste.  The second dish was good Eggplant with Garlic Sauce.  I asked for it "hot," and upon arrival it glistened from the oil it cooked in.  I liked it, but added still more chili to bring up the burn.  

I will certainly return to Dim Sum Garden as there is much more coming out of the kitchen that looks interesting, and because so many of my friends love the place.  It calls itself, "Philly's Premier Authentic Shanghai Soup Dumpling Restaurant."  Who am I to question a marketing slogan, but if you say it, you should be able to back it up.  

I don't think it did.

Not the best bagel experience in the area, and not the worst. 

The store is spacious enough for a number of tables and a long line waiting for service. Bins full of rounders appear smaller than my last Manhattan visit a few years ago (Clearly not real Manhattan Island bagels that are often larger than a saucer in diameter.) Still, my onion, butter and swiss had decent texture, loads of onion flakes and a good bite. Their coffee could stand a better bean roaster and more choices. 

Service suffered from understaffing. There was one woman taking orders and working the griddle, making for a hectic burnout shift for her, and growing queue. When the owner/manager came out from the back, and put on plastic gloves, things got better, but he was not well trained in food prep, so the butter spread was uneven, and only a single slice of cheese was placed within - where a minimum of two is the normal allocation, and often more. Too, the transection did not completely separate the halves, so when one side was lifted, the other tagged along and fell apart. 

I attributed that to having a bad morning.

Sitting in the strip commercial center at the corner of Columbus Boulevard and Washington Avenue, Pho Saigon is a typical looking large roomed pho house that gives the feeling of a cafeteria.  Service is friendly and efficient.  Apologies were sincere when advised that they were out of Bun Bo Hue before 8 pm.  I settled on another option (Pho Tai), and was very satisfied with that large bowl.  Superior broth, strong noodle mound properly cooked, and plenty of beef and accoutrements. Definitely on the high end of the satisfaction scale.

Yet, the Summer Rolls were a bit disappointing.  The Shrimp appeared to be sliced so thin that they could not be tasted along with the other ingredients.  That, and the cool skin of the wrap was too close to room temp, thus deprived of the coolness of the app.  The Peanut Sauce was adequate, but thinner than most.  

The house was three quarters full this Saturday evening, and the HDTVs were showing college football games.  

The Pho hit the spot, but everything else seemed a step below top quality, and exhausting the Bun Bo Hue so early was certainly a strategic blunder.  

With all the other excellent options for Vietnamese cuisine in the area, there is no compulsion to return to Pho Saigon anytime soon.

Stopped in 30 minutes before the listed closing time.  A few customers remained, but the waiter who greeted me did not hesitate to seat me at a booth, and take my drink order. Mexican? Corona will do nicely, thank you. 

The space was a rainbow of colored walls and furniture.  The carved wood backs of the dinner chairs were painted brightly, and the distressed wood tables felt like those I had sat at throughout the southwest and Mexico.  The atmosphere transported me out of Bucks and into Santa Fe, Tucson or maybe, Cancun.  It was an easy trip. 

The chips and salsa arrived promptly and I had a quick taste. Hard and crisp shovels for spicy chunky sauce.  Satisfactory, but perhaps not the best I've had.  I was content to wait for the Chicken Flautas, which arrived with a light melted cheesy cover over three stuffed flutes.  Rice and Refried Beans on a separate plate worked well together. I poured the remaining salsa over the flautas to achieve max flavor, and dug in.  

The tubes were full of large chunks of white meat chicken, beans, cheese, and a few sliced poblanos.  Everything was well cooked and placed in the oven to bring everything to melting temperature.  Very tasty and filling.  Totally enjoyable. 

Why only 3 Stars?  Well, I had to ask for slices of lime for the Corona.  The Salsa was decent, but tasted ubiquitously the same as most store bought varieties, when a homemade approach might have offered something more uniquely their own.  The melted white cheese sauce was a bit too mild, and poured too freely over everything, where  more "kick" would have been more distinguishing.  These are not serious shortcomings, as the dish remained enjoyable. Still, to be fan-worthy or more, there should be something original or memorable about the experience. 

I will definitely return to look for that special something, and when I find it, the stars will shine brightly.

Tabora Farm Market is primarily a bakery with a lot of home baked choices from cookies to fruit pies to my fave Jewish Apple Cake. There is a small changing offering of farm grown veggies and a deli counter in back if sandwiches and sides are your passion. It is all authentically rustic, and has seen better (cleaner) days. Prices are a bit ridiculous, with postage stamp lemon squares demanding $1.49 per. Expensive at half the price. 

Yet, the donuts, apple cake and country grain bread are worthy, so the occasional indulgence is justifiable. 

The best part may be the country road drive up county from Newtown on narrow two lane blacktop that twists and turns over hill and dale; even providing a romantic covered bridge or two to stop, walk through and admire. 

Was a time not long ago when people reaching into bins to pick out pastries with bare hands would not have disturbed me in the least. Those days, like our innocence, are gone. Now, when I see a thoughtless sloven reach in touching several before grabbing his choice and then carrying it to the cashier, it makes me change direction to avoid his potential viral trail, and find something less compromised. A few signs with gentle reminders to "Keep Your Hands to Yourself," would go a long way.

INCOMPLETE

I have stopped at Priori's on three occasions when their sign says they are open for business over the past few months, and each time the shop was locked up tight without notice nor explanation. I even called while parked in front of the building, without answer. 

This is a recommendation that you call before you go, so you don't waste time like I did. 

Wishing them the best, whatever is going on.

Ben & Irv's Delicatessen began it's Jewish-style restaurant adventure in the Mt. Airy section of Philadelphia in 1955, and has remained in the same family as it expanded into the spreading diaspora of Montgomery and Bucks Counties, PA.  The house in Huntington Valley on County Line Road looks like most other dineresque large menu emporiums, with the important distinction that although not kosher in the kitchen, it still offers many ethnic dishes for Jewish tastebuds that easily remind we of that faith of our nanny's cooking. Matzo ball soup, potato pancakes, blintzes, pastrami, knishes, pumpernickel sandwiches, white fish salad, salami, borscht and my personal favorite, matzo brie.  Every once in a while it feels good to visit our heritage and taste our history. 

Portions are huge, and the prices reflect that. It wouldn't be fair to compare B & I's quality to what I ate as a child, but I suspect that without a Yiddisha hand on the pots and pans in the kitchen, the intense flavor of memory cannot be duplicated. Still, my matzo brie was pretty good, and I was glad I asked the server to add sautéed onions to the mix. It arrived a huge platter of jumbled matzo pieces, egg and onion, scrambled to a semi-dry state.  My partners in crime seemed to enjoy their egg/potato/toast dishes, but spoke more of the quantity than the quality. I tasted a bit of everything. It was all very okay. 

While I wouldn't rush back to Ben & Irv's, it is good to know it is there when I need a quick Jewish fix to connect me to my people via traditional comfort food.

Actually in Wrightstown at 5 Points on Rt. 413. 

Primarily a take out place, but there are a few tables if eating the food piping hot out of the kitchen is important (it should be). 

The food is standard Americanized Chinese food. There must be one cookbook they all work out of, or a convention they all attend to get the same items on every menu around the continent. Still, Panda Garden is on the higher end of the quality spectrum even if the output is fairly much the ubiquitous fare we all know. I have had the Wonton Soup who's broth is above average; the various Chicken and Sauces, which are solid, but uninspired and sometimes overcooked; and the Noodle dishes and Foo Youngs, which are also acceptable. Just nothing to write home about unless you are having a very boring day and feel homesick. 

If you find yourself in this part of Bucks County this choice is as good as you are going to find. It is an A - Okay option.

Pho Ha Saigon is located in an as yet not redeveloped part of South Philly on Oregon Avenue.  It is part of a small strip commercial center attached to the old Oregon Market.  This location is a satellite of the primary Vietnamese area on Washington Avenue, and it was a smart move to get to this place before the big money arrived to gentrify the neighborhood.  

The house itself is very similar to most of the other Vietnamese kitchens, in that it has a large floor plan with basic amenities; designed more like a cafeteria than a comfortable hang around restaurant.  Tables and chairs are utilitarian and are appropriate for the speed service provided by the friendly staff.  The menu covers a broad cross section of VN cuisine, from Pho and Bun to Vermicelli and Broken Rice dishes.  Prices are reasonable in light of the probable rent on the property.  It is easy to get completely stuffed for less than $10.  

While I normally start an exploration of a new Vietnamese house with a bowl of Pho, I broke out of the mold by ordering Broken Rice with Grilled Chicken for a lunch entre, and an app of Summer Rolls.  My companion went with a Vermicelli plate that included a sampling of Shrimp, Pork, Beef, Tofu, and a Fried Spring Roll.  

Everything was good, but the most memorable pieces of our meals were the Grilled Pork and Shrimp, and the Spring Roll.  They were tasty and brought smiles to our faces.  The rest was decent, but no better than the fare offered by most other shops.  I found the butterflied Chicken Thigh to be a touch under marinated and undercooked.  Thus, the skin and thicker aspects of the meat were not right for consumption. A few more minutes on the grill would have solved this.  Copious squirts of Sriracha and Hoisin helped.  

I will come back to try the soups which have received praise.

This was my first visit to a Primo anywhere, and my initial impression is good.  This shop opened a few months ago, emerging from a fire that destroyed an earlier Italian deli/restaurant. "White" is the overall sense when walking in.  Everything appears clean, and the kitchen area is open for all to see, and everything appears orderly.
The Hoagies come in three sizes, but the middle range, 9"er is the most popular and has the sesame seeds on top.  The others are "signature wheat rolls."

My first bite was of a Turkey Schwartzie, which is Sliced Turkey Breast, Swiss Cheese, Cole Slaw & Russian Dressing.  It was very good.  The sesame could be tasted immediately, followed quickly by the turkey, cole slaw, Swiss cheese, with the sweetness of the Russian Dressing acting like a final note of completion. 

I thought I could handle the 9" for lunch, but I gave up at half time.  It was very filling.  So, it was really two lunches at a reasonable price. 

The menu has lots of interesting options.  Reading the other reviews, I know I want to return to try the "Diablos," and Cutlet Combos.

... All in good time, my friend. More stars to follow.

The results on China Boys Chinese/American restaurant depends on whether you are there for take out or eat in.  As a take away joint the place gets passing grades for consistency, speed, and quantity/quality.  The same cannot be said for dining in, where although there are 6 tables, the space is unattractive, poorly maintained, and without effective air conditioning on a hot summer day.  

The Wonton Soup I ordered with my lunch special was the same as in so many other houses of this ilk.  Chicken consume out of a can with thick skinned Wontons and some sort of meat-food within.  The Sesame Chicken was pretty average, but there was plenty for lunch.  The sauce while gloopy, still had the expected sweet taste that is used on almost all similar dishes.  The Fried Rice was made en mass in the morning (or the day before), and was dark from the beef stock it had absorbed, although it had a fair amount of veggies and pork chunks. 

For me it was what I expected - unimaginative and strictly by the numbers cooking.  If you like this style then no harm coming here.  However, if you prefer something more authentically Chinese, one of the best places in Mercer County is right up Nottingham Way at Szechuan House.  

These two places are as different as night and day.  What a difference a half mile makes.

While the companionship of fellow Yelpers was 5 Star, and the overall ambiance of Luna Café nearly so, there is no escaping the fact that my brunch (and that of others) was delivered at the wrong temperature.  

My pancakes, topped with fresh Blueberries, with a side a pure Maple Syrup, were no more than room temp. The dish would have been amazing if brought hot and steaming.  Apparently, the Blueberry Sauce and Maple Syrup were not heated before being poured over the pancakes, or placed on the table, and as a result cooled dramatically while awaiting transport by our server.  The ingredients were first rate, and even cooled had a wonderful taste.  Still, a cool pancake is not optimal for best experience. 

I took the opportunity to talk with the chef to explain what had happened, and suggested the sauces and syrups be heated before use to be sure everything arrived ready for peak consumption.  He was gracious and appreciative for the information. I believe this oversight will be easily corrected.  

Luna Café has a lot of promise.  It has history, charm, friendly service, and an interesting menu.  Fix the small glitches and it will take off.  

I will return soon to find out if the stars ascend.

The Bagel Zone?
Is that a veiled reference to The Twilight Zone?

I ask only because on a recent early morning visit there on my way to court in Mt. Holly, there were a group of men gathered there at pushed together tables that seemed like they were from another planet.  Men In Black kind of thing. They dispersed soon after I sat down with my bagel and coffee and opted to face them rather than the window behind me. Guess they didn't like the scrutiny. 

Anyway, this was my first visit there, and although the staff was friendly and the prices rock bottom, the primary product was only average.  My Onion Bagel was richly sprinkled with Onion Flakes, but the texture of the bagel was more the consistency of dinner roll rather than a thick skin encasing a chewy but air-pocketed inner body. It was fresh and completely edible, but lacked the "bagelessence" I sought. 

Coffee was decent, and with change from a Lincoln, the price was certainly right.

This is the TGI Fridays that is within the campus of Oxford Valley Mall, Langhorne (Middletown), Pa. It has the conventional layout of the older version of this national franchise, with a large bar and booths/tables all around.  The atmosphere is casual and bustling, and has the feel of the roadhouse it was meant to be. 

We chose this spot as representative of contemporary popular American cuisine for our friends who had just arrived from Asia. They wanted something traditionally American.  What is better than nachos, burgers, salad, fried chicken and chicken/shrimp combos on top of pasta?  

Don't answer that! 

We had about a 10 minute wait for seating on a busy Saturday night.  Service was friendly and acceptably prompt given the crowd.  Our server was patient as we perused, translated and sought direction from our guests.  The youngest had no problem finding the fried chicken sandwich.  The mother and grandmother were slower in understanding meals without rice, but ultimately selected a traditional cheeseburger, and a grilled chicken pasta dish.  Of course, there was also the issue about western utensils vs. chopsticks, but we worked through that with the help of the large wooden spikes used to hold things together.  We natives moved more quickly to the salads, sliders and shrimp/chicken plates. 

Everything was served together, and I watched as our friends took their first close up look at American food.  It was a cross between confusion and incredulousness. Big pieces. Nothing cut into small bite size morsels. Okay. They would just have to figure it out and dig in.  The rest of us went quickly to work on our Jack Sliders (very good), BBQ chicken salad (plentiful and tasty), chicken/shrimp combo (loved the shrimp, but left most of the chicken to take home). The fried chicken sandwich was devoured with relish.  So far. So good. Our second oldest guest just ate the fries around the burger.  She didn't seem to know where to begin.  I think she did not want to use her hands to pick up her food.  I asked if she would like to exchange a small slider for her half pounder, and she gratefully accepted.  She ate it with the spike holding the entire thing like a burger on a stick.  She liked it.  Her burger was pretty good, but a step below what I have sampled in places like Chilis or Applebees. It was not the medium finish requested, but far closer to well done. Granny was able to eat her pasta with the spike, but seemed tentative the whole way.  It wasn't the noodles she was accustomed to, but she was game. 

All in all, it was a fairly good introduction to fast casual, something almost totally lacking in their part of Asia. They were impressed by the size of the crowd, and its diversity.  

Welcome to America, sisters!  You aren't in homogenous Asia any more.  You'll love it once you figure it all out.

Mugshot Diner in Fishtown, Philadelphia, is a classic urban diner, open 24/7 for the people of this north of Center City community.  We stopped in after a show at Punch Line comedy club the other night. Laughing so much made us hungry. We cruised around the block for parking and found a spot on our second pass on York Street. Thank you parking angels!

We sat in a booth along the front windows, where the hostess placed two menus and a specials laminated card. Our server came along promptly, introduced himself, and told us to let him know when we were ready to order. 

At 10 it wasn't very busy. Decent music in the background. We ordered one of their burgers and eggplant parmesan on ciabatta, after our server warned us off other ideas. Gotta trust the guy. Both sandwiches were decent - the burger grilled to a juicy medium, and the eggplant tender with adequate red sauce and mozzarella. They weren't awesome, but neither was that expected for the place and price. We were satisfied with this late meal. 

Mugshot has a sister house in Mt. Holly, NJ, where I have had several good breakfasts. If you like either one, your bound to like the other.

Recently returned to Buffalo Wild Wings Langhorne plant for a family Friday night.  While I didn't walk in with fond memories of my past visit, my son was in the mood for hot wings, and BWW certainly had plenty of those.  

Truth be told, this experience was far improved.  The house was far from crowded.  All the other customers seemed to be families with teenage/early twenties boys who wanted the gorge on wings and watch sports on huge HDTVs.  We fit right in!  

Service was better than remembered.  Our guy was over the top solicitous of our satisfaction; so much so that I jokingly asked him to calm down or he wouldn't make it through the night with his hyperactivity.  He was not so far gone as to not appreciate that I noticed he was working hard.  Even a small glitch in the cooking of the Alaskan Cod sandwich was handled with aplomb, with the house manager stopping by to apologize for the delay in bring the fillet to proper temperature.  

Drinks were ample and fairly priced.  Can't object when a 12 oz. cocktail comes in at $6.50.  

The chickens who sacrificed their flight for us came to us both Blazin and Thai Curry.  They were meaty, deep fried, and bathed in some impressive chili mix.  The former took the enamel off my teeth (much to the merriment of young man), while the latter had great south Asian flavor. Liked them both, but would never be challenged to eat a extra hot one again.  The fish sandwich on brioche roll was surprisingly decent, with the fish large enough to withstand the cooking process and still be crispy and tasty with aioli mayo and melted cheese.  

Glad we decided to return to Buffalo Wild Wings on Rt. 1, Langhorne, Pa.  We enjoyed ourselves, and didn't feel the need to apologize to ourselves for going.  

Improvements noted.

After many good to great Mexican and Central American meals in and around Trenton, Burritos is a bit tame for my taste. 

What do I mean?

Well, the food is about as good as any average Casa Mexicana across the river, but the atmosphere is not from South of the Border.  It is rather staid.  The only Spanish I heard was from the television tuned to a futbol game.  I think I may have heard the friendly people behind the counter also habla algunas palabras. No music.  No Latin American art.  Neutral colors.  A dull environment. 

Yet, my chicken flautas were pretty good, loaded with chicken and cheese, and deep fried to a dark brown ultra crisp finish, that defied the plastic fork and knife effort to cut through them.  I could crush them, but the utensils were too weak to actually do much work. I ended up using my hands. Burritos does a nice job loading up the top of the dish with guacamole, lettuce, tomato, corn, salsas, and almost anything else they have on the work space in front of them. This in addition to the rice and black beans that tag along as accompaniment.  I found the mango salsa to be quite tasty.  They put a ton of food on the plate, and dare you to finish it all.  I couldn't, but I was so full I did not want to think about taking the rest home.

The servers are cool, but way different that the crews that serve me in Trenton.  Those folks barely speak any Ingles, and work with primarily Spanish speakers, while here the folks appear bilingual and geared for the Yardley crowd. 

Certainly better than Chipotle and Taco Belch, but not the full monty found across the river in the old Chambersburg part of Trenton City or Hamilton.

This was our first visit to The Irish Rover Station House in Langhorne, Pa, just across the street from the Septa train station (thus, the name). After being snowbound all day, we were looking forward to getting out for some grub, drinks and stimulation. 

We sat at a hightop along the glass wall next to the patio. It was a peaceful scene with the patio covered in untouched snow, and the trains stopping at the little station house. It was a near perfect setting, but for the incredibly loud ambient noise in the dining room. There was a large party having a good time, but that didn't account for the poor acoustics that amplified sound from the bar and the entire space, and made normal conversation nearly impossible. After the big group left it was better, but still louder than comfortable.  

They have a great beer list, with new specials every week. Impressive. They didn't have one of our first choices, but our server brought us two samples of similar beers he thought would satisfy. He was enterprising in this approach, and right that he had selected one that we liked and ordered. Nice job. In fact, he did a very good job with us all evening and we showed our appreciation. 

We ordered the Emerald Potatoes app to start. Lovely to look at in a huge platter of homemade chips loaded up with cheese and scallion with large dolup of sour cream. This was a cousin to nachos or poutine, and pretty good. A little bacon bits or spicy ground beef in the mix would have made it exemplary. 

The filet sandwich was tender and juicy on an excellent soft roll, sided with chips. Good. My two fish tacos were filled with a small breaded/fried frozen fish and aioli in soft tortillas. A small amount of salsa and shredded iceberg on the edge of the plate, and a small plastic cup of gaucamole. Multi colored tortilla chips filled half the plate. Not so good. For both dishes and the app there was no adjustment for the fact that we already had a large serving of chips in our meals and giving out more potato chips and corn chips was just overkill and boring. They were left behind. 

We brought home two burgers for our teenage sons who could not join us for dinner. They both said they were mediocre. 

Irish Rover seems more like a beer and wing sports bar, more than a full meal resto, with way better service than most. Reasonable prices.

It may be true what the other Yelpers say about the quality of the breakfasts here, but as I was here for lunch I can't comment on the morning sustenance. 

I can say that this looks to be a fairly recently renovated Jersey diner, very clean, friendly, and broadly diverse menu.  I sat at the small counter next to the hostess/manager as she was being mentored by the owner about ordering from purveyors.  He was calm, articulate, and seemed to appreciate his people.  Impressive.  Of course, the fact that he was dealing with a gorgeous employee may have had something to do with it.  

My lunch was ordinary.  The Chicken Salad on Rye Toast was just okay.  The toasting seemed to have taken the life out of the bread, as it was overly dry and brittle.  The Chicken Salad was ample, but lacked much flavor.  The cup of Chicken Noodle Soup was a nice touch, but too salty.  

Given the positive vibe of the place, I would certainly return for breakfast, but lunch, not so much.

Sycamore Grill is good if you know what you want and don't overstay the best parts of the experience.  

Especially in nice weather, the Back Deck offers a pleasant outdoor setting in the shade of the historic Sycamore Trees.  If you go for Happy Hour (4:30 - 6:30), and can find a seat on the deck, it is a very nice place to relax with a friendly conversation.  At other times, you have to go Monday thru Wednesday to avoid larger crowds that come on those evenings to listen to live music.  But, if tunes are what you like, you may enjoy that setting. Inside, the atmosphere is dark, cool and well appointed.  The Happy Hour menu is also decent.  

Otherwise, the better time to go is at lunch.  The Burgers, Chicken Salad and Turkey Club Sandwiches are above average, and there are good Soups (Onion, New England Clam) and Salads (Wedge and Caesar) available at prices that while higher than many other places, are much more in line with a lunch budget than the dinners that seem pricey.  I have had the Combination Lunch - Bowl of French Onion and a Salad.  Tasty and filling.  The Burger Tuesday is also a fair deal - Your favorite Burger and Beer for $10. 

The downside is that you have to know when to go.  If you prefer a more laid back moment, then you must be attentive to season, day and time.  If crowd and expense are not issues, than go anytime you wish and have a good time.

Hatboro Dish sits on York Road (Main Street) in Hatboro, PA.  It is a square room with black tables & chairs, but no counter.  It has the feel of a small café, without the emphasis on coffee.  Their breakfast menu is creative and offers a nice variety of morning choices.  I asked my very pleasant server which way to go - french toast or one of their skillets?  She unreservedly recommended the frenchie. Well, alright!

While waiting, I looked around the house. About one third full, with mostly locals who knew the staff well enough to have them sit a while to chat.  Nice vibe.  The coffee arrived in a thermos pitcher for unlimited refills, and the milk I requested, in a small stainless vessel.  It was decent java, but without pedigree. Nice to have all I wanted.

The main course was basically a thick cut cinnamon bread dipped in egg, and heated on the grill.  It was good, but because of its thickness, the egg did not penetrate deeply into the slices.  They were pretty dry, and the extra dose of their syrup (not maple) helped a bit, but, could not compensate for the lack of egg melding with the texture of the bread, which is what french toast is all about. So, it was okay, but not what it could have been given the excellent raw materials. 

Too bad, because the Dish could have been a real contender.

Difficult to find office complex cafe in Yardley (actually, Lower Makefield), off Stony Hill Road. It is in the 790 Building which is in the middle of this corporate center. Signage is minimal. The easiest path is to walk around the right end of the building, locate the outdoor patio dining area, and enter through that door. Otherwise, you will be walking down long hallways without assurance you will reach your destination. Obviously, The Weekday Cafe (nice alliteration), is meant primarily for the folk who work in the complex, but if I owned the business, I would want to cast a larger net. 

This is the third food operation at this location in about as many years, so they have their work cut out for them. Getting the word out beyond this small universe is critical. 

And, while the attractive shop is diminutive, it is worth discovering. They do a decent breakfast with a limited menu and good coffee. Service is friendly and efficient. My "Early Riser" sausage, egg and cheese on toasted English muffin was solid and cost only $2.95. The java flowed hot and strong. 

This morning, a few other office workers came in to pick up something to take to their desks, but not enough to make a success. Hopefully, their lunch trade carries them.  They do have two other similar locations in Ewing and Hamilton, NJ, that are larger and also require excellent tracking skills to find, but seem to be doing well. 

As this Weekday Cafe is closest to home, I wish them good luck and smart advertising.

La Casa di Lucia on the farthest end of Bustleton Avenue, in Northeast Philadelphia about a mile before reaching Bucks County, is another decent Italian restaurant slinging traditional dishes to the people of the nearby hoods. There is a big bar in the front of the house, and a small dining room behind it, with a larger banquet room to the side. It is clean and attractive. And, if you enjoy a cabaret feel with sultry smoky chanteuse, this house provides the entertainment several nights a week. 

We were there for a light supper after strong foot massage, and La Casa di Lucia fit the bill. Plenty of choices, solid service and reasonable prices. This is the case in many such restaurants in this neck of the woods. We ordered a Caesar salad and large pizza, half mushrooms, half plain.  Both arrived within ten minutes.  

It was a large salad with plenty of romaine, and good homemade dressing. We could even taste the anchovy paste. It was a strong accompaniment to the pizza. The pie was good, too, but not as crisp and balanced as I like, and as are available not very far away. Plenty of cheese (perhaps too much compared to the red sauce, garlic and basil elements).  The crust was still too moist making it impossible to pick up and hold its point. Had to fold it immediately to avoid a hot cheese slide onto the plate or lap. Taste was decent, but the texture needed a kick in the crotch to stiffen it up. Took half of it home for later consumption. 

I would try La Casa di Lucia again to see what their dinners were about, but would pass on the tomato pie.

Newly renovated Men's Warehouse opened recently in Lincoln Plaza, Langhorne, PA, close by Oxford Valley Mall. We stopped in looking for a suit for my stepson, who had secured a promotion at work and wanted to upgrade his wardrobe with new threads. 

Although the store is fairly large, the actual in store suit selection was meagre. Admittedly, the young man is tall and thin (6'3", 160 lbs.), but to have only two dark colored suits on the rack was disappointing to say the least. In fact, they had nothing in his size. Our salesperson did her best to make something work, by mixing and matching pants and jacket in one size larger to approximate his actual measurements. Ultimately, we were able to determine the right sizes, which then had to be ordered for shipping to our home. 

Luckily, I know a guy good with needle and thread. 

The shop seemed to have plenty of dress shirts and ties, as well as a reasonable supply of casual ware. Yet, they were bereft of more formal work clothes for the professionals in the crowd. Don't know if this is a decision by management based on actual marketing data, or just a supply chain issue, but given that this brand used to advertise to the well dressed male, it is hard to comprehend how far from that image Men's Warehouse has fallen. Perhaps, this is more evidence of new pandemic workplace realities, but some people still have to go to work and dress for success. 

It would appear Men's Warehouse has decided that those people are not enough to carry the business as it once did. It is hard to justify another visit. 

2.5 STARS

Nice Korean green grocery in the Morrisville Shopping Center on Old Trenton Road. Plenty to choose at prices better than the local supermarkets, but not as good as the true farmers' market at Tanners' Brothers in Richboro. Butcher and fishmonger, too. 

Interesting oddities, too, like Polish kielbasa and German Milka chocolates. 

Worth going to when a major veggie and fruit expedition is planned and you don't have time for Tanners' or the Bristol Amish Market.

Plenty to keep you curious, entertained and in the greens.

This DD franchise approximates the mean of all Dunkins.  

Decent Java, but too dependent on the water quality.  Bakery goods sweet and addicting. 

Biggest issue is the location in the Lalor Plaza down at the bottom of Lalor Street, just off Rt. 129.  No problem during the day, but a bit sketchy after dusk.  But, this strip houses one of my secret lunch houses, Perfetto Pizza; so I find myself in this hood at least once a month.  

Big plus - Bilingual staff!

"You can take the boy out of the city, but you can't take the city out of the boy " 

Very true. Perhaps this is why I always look forward to exploring Philly neighborhoods for cool places to eat. Today it was The New Olympia House on Castor Avenue that had my time and attention. A corner luncheonette that has been slinging hash for more than half a century, this little piece of Athens is well preserved, with long counter with about 10 spinners, booths behind that, and a large dining room behind the kitchen in this double wide row house neighborhood. The charm and cultural history were all in place, much as it has operated since 1960. I was very happy to have found the joint as I straddled the stool and was approached by the attractive server in black spandex pants.

The question at hand was - would the kitchen support the excited first impression, or no? 

The answer was discovered soon enough. For this breakfast at least, the rude awakening was in the negative - my anticipation was better than the reality this day. 

My french toast looked golden brown, and the old style syrup dispenser with slip down spring metal opening was way cool. However, the underside chassis had too much char, resulting in a burnt taste that required extra syrup to offset. That taste led me to think that the grill was not cleaned between orders, leaving burnt butter or other lubricant around to stick to the next food sizzling there. It also meant a lack of attention by the short order cook (not chef), and an attempt to hide the dark side from view. The three slices were ample, and had the decision been made to start afresh rather than hope I didn't notice, would have made me a true fan.

First impression dashed. 

The Cecilware drip coffee was fine. I love those old contraptions. Yet, despite all the help behind the counter, no one saw that my small cup was bereft of coffee and needed refilling, until I asked. Hard to understand such inattentiveness when I was the only customer sitting there. Chalk it up to my invisibility, sometimes not the best superpower to practice while dining. 

Still, I liked New Olympia House enough to regret this happenstance, and wish for a better experience. This could have been one of those true Philadelphia moments that only the city's profound indifference to perfection in the face of amazing potential, created the opportunity to transcend low expectations and truly hit the mark in miraculous laudation. 

That moment must await a more hopeful day.

A1 Japanese Steakhouse sits in the strip center anchored by IHOP at the intersection of RT. 1 and Oxford Valley Road, Fairless Hills. It is one of the older sushi/hibachi houses, run by Chinese ownership and because of location and age, one of the less expensive operations. While the quality of the experience is a step down from the more modern Mt. Fuji, Sakura, Oishi, Arirang, etc., joints found throughout lower Bucks County, the difference is not so great as to make it unworthy of your dining out dollar, but is noticeable. 

What do I mean? A1 is carpeted wall to wall. They doubtlessly hide the remains of years of food tossing by hibachi chefs entertaining customers with food flips aimed for your mouth. They would have to shampoo the floor weekly to keep the place with passing grade. They don't. With each grill housing its own grease trap, it is dubious that it is emptied and cleaned regularly. Yet, the health inspectors allow the business to remain open, so it is up to you to be vigilant.

Still, the food served looks and tastes good. Our salmon fillets (2 each) were fresh and presented well with sides of fried rice, mushroom soup (few in the small bowl) and grilled mixed veggies. Plenty to eat and even take home without ordering anything more. They even comp everyone 3 grilled shrimp. Nice touch. Their bar offers mostly national brand beers (Sam Adams Boston Lager) as well as some of those fancy ass fruity sweet things in hurricane glasses. So, if your policy on cleanliness is, "Don't ask, Don't Tell," you won't have a problem with A1. 

One suggestion, salt free soy sauce for the chefs as they squirt and cook. Standard soy sauce tends to make everything have a similar taste, detracting from the natural flavors that should predominate.

Old school Wawa in the center of Main Street, Yardley Boro. Small parking lot in front. Larger one in back, but you may not know its there unless your local. Small footprint that still manages to provide most of the products and services of the latest supersized versions. 

I was there to pick up a chicken salad hoagie before moving on to my next appointment. It had been a while since ordering with their touch screens and found the shear number of pages I had to endure to be somewhat daunting. How many screens just for mayo?! 

Still, the sandwich was good with fresh chicken salad, but perhaps less so for the torpedo roll. Enjoyable, nonetheless. 

Everyone there was well trained and friendly from front door welcome to cashier thank you for coming. Price was very appealing, with the customized sammy ten inch coming in at under $7. 

Little wonder why almost everyone wants a Wawa near their town.

This is strictly a 2 slices and a drink review. 

Amato's on Trenton Road in Fairless Hills, is an attractive space for a neighborhood Italian meal.  On this Monday evening, it was bustling.  I found a deuce in the front window after looking at the pizza-on-display under glass at the front of the kitchen/cashier area.  It all looked good, but I was most attracted to the square cut Brooklyn and Amato Pies, and ordered one of each, "well done."  

The point about "well done" reheated pizza is my attempt to awaken the previously baked pie's essence by making the cheese and sauce bubble again to bring out the original flavors.  There is little worse than a pie that has been sitting around for a while, and is only partially reanimated by inadequate oven exposure the second time around. If the oven master understands me, he knows that I don't mind a scorched undercarriage in my search for more taste.  

A friendly server brought the hot squares to my table on a small aluminum pizza pan.  It looked good as the steam hit my glasses.  I asked for knife and fork because there was little crust to gasp and I didn't want to burn my digits. 

First bite I realized that the crust had not been reheated sufficiently, while the topside was significantly hotter. The taste was okay, but the platform was soft and far from the more rigid structure I prefer.  The Tomato Sauce was dark thick red, and was nicely spiced.  As I looked around at the tables with fresh baked pies, I saw that those folks were able to lift their triangles without wilting, nor spillage.  They seemed quite happy with their food.

My wish is that all pizza parlors selling warmed over slices understand that those of us who can't handle a whole pie desire the same sensory experience as everyone else, and take the time to bring the fresh pizza "zing" to the rest of us.  I know it's a loss leader for many shops, but regardless of the price, failure to provide full participation only means they have a less than satisfied customer.

If you are up and about very early, go to Cramer to get fresh donuts, muffins and scones.  Too, if you can order a cake for a special occasion, you will probably be quite satisfied. Otherwise, despite the charm of an old fashioned bakery, and the butternut aroma, the products are inconsistent, and pricey. The bread, bagels, rolls are not worth the trip. There are much stronger options for them only minutes away.
To be a worthwhile destination everything must be good, available, and reasonably priced compared to the competition. Cramer is not quite all that.

Cha's Seafood sits in on Pennington Avenue, Trenton, NJ, in a small "L" shaped shopping plaza where an old factory used to be.  It is very clean inside, with a large selection of breaded fillets and semi prepared shellfish, crabs and king crab legs in various sauces for purchase by the pound or in platters to take out.  The space is large enough for a few tables, but that is not their business model.  

I stopped in for lunch this week around 1:30 pm, and I was just about the only customer there. I ordered a whiting lunch (3 fillets, fries, 2 slices of whole wheat, small cup of macaroni salad and a bottle of water for about $7.50, including tax.  The price was definitely right. 

The fish was sliced thin and breaded in corn meal before bathing in the deep fryer.  I could only eat two of the fillets made into a sandwich, and left most of the fries behind.  They were okay, but far to many to eat in a balanced meal.   

Strangely, they did not offer any mayo, tarter sauce, nor even ketchup with the take away lunch. Any of those would have added to the flavor of the fish and taters, which was sort of  plain as it was.  Next time, I will be sure to ask for those accessories.  

Overall, just a decent, but unexciting monochromatic lunch.  Those pre-seasoned crabs and other shellfish did look pretty good.  

Octavia did a good job taking care of me.  She was friendly and informative.

Pho Washington is the latest restaurant at this shopping center location at 6th and Washington. The menu is fairly limited to traditional street food of Vietnam - pho (noodle soup), com (broken rice dishes) and vermicelli (rice noodles bowls with choice of meat and greens). They also have a long list of beverages on the back page. 

We stopped in before grocery shopping at 1st Asian Supermarket across 6th St. We ordered Pho Tai (beef broth w thin ribeye steak slices) and Vermicelli w Grilled Pork, Spring Roll and Shredded Lettuce (w thin sweet dipping sauce on the side). We started with Summer Rolls with thick ground peanut brown sauce.

Everything was good to very good, without any knockouts. The appetizer rolls were loaded with sliced shrimp and cabbage in a cool, sticky rice wrap. The sauce stuck to what it touched, so it really dominated the taste of the dish. The wrap was quite chewy. It was okay. The small bowl of pho was more than we could finish after adding all the sprouts, Thai basil, jalapeno and squeezed lime juice. The steak was plentiful and cooked well in the beef broth. While the beef stock was good, it needed more simmering with pot spices to attain the right degree of subtle richness. We squirted some sirracha from the table rocket to boost the flavor, which helped alot.

 I liked the vermicelli plate the most. The pork was delicious with or without dipping in the accompanying sweet vinegar dip. It was tender and fully exposed with a few chews. The noodles were both warm and cool depending on where it was in the bowl in proximity to hot or cool food. Both temps were fine, and I found that pouring some of the sauce over everything enhanced the flavor of each element, but wasn't essential. I would definitely get that again, but probably go to Pho Ha across the parking lot for quality well cured pho. 

Service was fine and prices reasonable for the overall experience. 
 
The bakery next door looked like the right place to hang out over Vietnamese coffee with condensed milk and pastries. Next time for that!

This was my first visit to a Sonic Drive-In.  This one has been around on North Olden Avenue in Ewing for only a few years. The place has two rows of drive-in slots where you can enjoy their rollerskating, eat in the car, gimmick. With an outside temperature over 90 degrees, the better choice was to go inside and enjoy the air conditioning and stop polluting for a while. 

The place was clean and bright with Sonic Radio playing background muzak, and LED HD displays showing their standard menu and specials. There was no one in there but me when I arrived at 1:30.  The young woman at the single cashier post was friendly and seemed to enjoy having a little customer contact rather than talking to people all day long through headphones. 

The Carhop Classic for $3.99 was an irresistible deal.  Single burger loaded with cheese, mayo, mustard, ketchup, lettuce and tomato, it was a nice size. It came with a choice of onion rings, fries or tater tots.  I went with the later. The actual burger experience was pretty much average. Far from the best fast food burger I've ever had, but far from the worst, too.  Not all that much flavor, but the overall bitechew was okay.  At least it did not arrive crushed like at 5 Guys, nor cold as so often happens at the Burger Kings of the world. The price/quality proposition was decent given the special available on this combo. 

Would I rush back? No. Would I avoid Sonic all together? No. Aside from the drive in cultural history, it is really no more than middle of the pack. If it was nearby when I was hungry, I would gladly chow down. Inside or out.

This update is strictly for the breakfast this morning.

Their deli does prepare a limited breakfast menu, but unless you like microwaved eggs and sausage grilled between the cheeks of a pannini press, this might not be the place for you.  Absent a genuine grill they did a fairly good job on my sausage, egg and cheese sandy.  I do wonder if they clean that press before putting other breaded sandwiches inside.  

While the taste and price were decent, I prefer the use of a grill to prepare my eggs and melt the cheese.  Although the coffee was okay and the ambiance very much "from the barn," I will likely not return for breakfast. 

It remains a good place to buy farm fresh produce and enjoy the seasonal outdoor events.

Tried the Korean BBQ Chicken Sandwich thinking it would have the crunchy skin of those excellent Korean wings in the form of a deep fried breast. Well, it wasn't that as it lacked the texture, but the chicken itself was plump and a big chew. Similarly, the family enjoyed the Chipotle Melt, Nashville Hot and Mike's Hot Honey. All substantial. All entertaining with their various sauces. 

But, it became obvious that despite the overall quality of the sandwiches, they were wildly overpriced at $10 apiece including tax. They were smaller that Popeye's at nearly twice the cost. Given the comparison, Popeye, or even Chick-fil-A, are better. 

Beyond the merits, I found myself in a situation with a small sign on the door that said they would be closing at 7 temporarily. That was fine, but their website didn't alert the public to that fact, nor did Yelp nor Google. Besides, it was only 6:40, so why were the grills shut off leaving no burgers, no fries and no salad? In fact, they were out of everything but chicken, so I ordered four different sandwiches hoping my peeps would understand why they weren't getting what they wanted. 

I guess if you're plum out of supplies it's time to stop the grill, but it doesn't do much for the disappointment in the belly.

By now, Isaac Newtown's is one of the old places in a very old town. It's gotta be at least twenty years sitting back in the parking lot along Newtown Creek.  

Go for the incredible beer on tap or bottles, burgers, Caesar salads, quiche and calzone, but most of the rest of the menu is not as good as what they do best. Prices are decent, if a $10. burger does not scandalize you. 

The facility has charm and worn ambiance and the floor plan is comfortable and uncrowded.  The upstairs dining area is where they generally seat families, but with booths you can only hear the kids, and it does not get unpleasant. The best seat in the house is at or near the bar, and that room gets crowded Friday - Sunday nights. Still, you will find many knowledgeable beer lovers hanging out, so you can have a seminar about hops along with your Belgian or local craft brew. 

The bathrooms are in the basement, down a steep flight of stairs.  They can be a challenge after a few, and I have never been able to escape the sensation of descending into Dante's lair.  

Still, a good local pub with a long beer list and decent bar food. The dinners, not so much.

Another of the Super Wawa gas station/convenience stores that seem to have sprung up almost overnight in this part of South Jersey.  

The gasoline prices are competitive, but you never know who the real producer/distributor is for any of them.  So, it likely isn't wise to use it too often.  The convenience store takes its cues from the Sheetz, A Plus, Quik Cheks and turnpike service centers of the world. Every kind of sugar and quick energy drink is available.  In this case, the deli actually is capable to turning out decent sandwiches and soups.  

I am not a fan of these places, but understand their efficacy.  They serve their purpose, and even offer reasonably good java.

Cattycorner from Pete's Steakhouse Tavern, Jeppy's is as small as Pete's is big. 

It is primarily a take out joint with only a couple of tables in the closet sized space for guys like me who work near by, but don't want to eat at their desks.  I met the owner/manager who was friendly and had no problem fixing me up after 3:00 with their 2 Slice and a Drink Special at $4.95.  

The pie was okay, but could have been more if it had spent enough time back in the oven to totally reheat the triangles to the original temperature, rather than removing them when only lukewarm.  The flavor was right, but the crust texture was soft and doughy from failure to bring the crust to the near molten state required to make it firm and crunchy.  As this seems to be endemic to many places, it may be my job to ask for a "well done" slice so they are left to burn a bit longer.  

Otherwise, Jeppy's is a cool little place.  Much like the Little Engine That Could, Jeppy's sits across from Big Boy Pete's and with all its glare and attitude, repeating over and over, "I think I can. I think I can..." 

Until it becomes, "I know I can. I know I can...."

Hong Kong Pearl is a mixed bag.

The facility is dark and dreary at high noon, giving the sensation of being in a 1940's movie.  Yet, the service is prompt and attentive, somewhat anomalous for a Chinese house.  The main courses are well prepared, with some attention to detail, but it takes a few shortcuts that diminish the overall quality of the meal.  The broth for the Wonton Soup is chokingly salty and a brownish tint that suggests use of bouillon with prepackaged salt, dye and possibly MSG to cut costs.  In a similar manner, the Fried Rice arrives artificially colored a dark tawny cast from its mass production earlier in the day. Both soup and rice are vastly inferior to the prime attraction, but as they are served with practically every meal, the overall result is "mixed."  

On the other hand, the General Tso's Chicken was quite good in the context of a suburban Americanized Chinese shop.  It used chicken that had not been frozen long, if at all, a pleasant coating, and a sauce that used correct spices to attain the right sweet/hot spot that makes for a happy General. It even had whole chili peppers in the dish.  That was a big positive. 

While I would not rush back to Hong Kong Pearl, it was certainly a decent place for lunch.  If they would eliminate the problems with the soup and rice, and attempt to make them the right way - with a long simmering stock and just in time fried rice, it could be an exceptional experience for this part of the world.

While I generally like Red Robin Gourmet Burgers for the consistency of the food in all locations, I find that this particular restaurant being very close to Sesame Place has a noise level just on the other side of comfortable.  Given the choice I prefer the newer facility close by Neshaminy Mall, which although smaller, is more modern and offers a cozier roadhouse feel.  Too, perhaps because of so many kids eating grilled cheese sandwiches, the signature burgers often are not finished to the desired degree, and present in less than tantalizing form.  Last time I was here my server did not ask how I wanted my burger done. I volunteered that I like it medium, but it came out well done anyway.  Maybe that was why I wasn't asked.  I also was not offered the endless fries that are so heavily advertised. 

The burgers are okay in both places and the fries still better than average. The shakes are a bit underwhelming compared to their competition at Cheeburger Cheeburger, Nifty Fifty, and Jakes Wayback. Better to stick with the alternatives like bottomless limeaid or iced tea, where you can hydrate without the sugar rush, and even share the drink if one of you gets water.  

It is likely better to come to this shop after Sesame Place is closed for the season, and some quality control is reasserted.  This place is a gold mine usually filled to capacity. Sometimes that success goes to the bottom line, but gets lost in the kitchen and on the floor. 

See you in the winter.

"...Pulled into Plumsteadville, I was feelin' about half passed dead.
Just need some place where I can lay my head.
Say, sister, can you tell me where a man might find a bed? 
She just grinned, shook her head. 'No,' was all she said..."
(With apologies to Bob Dylan)

It may have been the heat of a near-100 degree day, or maybe the high humidity that seemed to choke the breath out of every living being, but here I was in Plumsteadville feeling slightly desert crazed and in need of hydration and restoration.  The Inn materialized in front of me, a shimmering apparition.  Real or not, I was stopping in for a drink and lunch.  

Perhaps, it was my gaunt appearance when I walked into the barroom, but it seemed no one saw me as I sat down on a corner stool.  I allowed the dim coolness to resuscitate me.  Finally, a bartender saw me there and came over to see what, "...it'll be."  

"Summer Shandy and a Bison Burger, medium, please."

"I didn't see you come in, stranger.  How long you been sittin' there?" 

"Since breakfast, but I blend in."  My wink let her off the hook.  From then on the service was first rate from all the black & white servers, complete with sides of small talk and Potato Salad. 

The Summer Shandy hit my thirsty spot dead center.  It was difficult not to just gulp it down it felt/tasted so good.  That squirt of lemon in the beer was an elixir. 

My Bison Burger Special came out closer to medium rare, but I was pleased with it, as it was full on juicy and a deep rose color.  The pile of Shaved Onion, Cheese, and BBQ Sauce on Brioche Roll made for an excellent sandwich.  Knife and fork was the only way to go, and allowed me to pay attention to every morsel.  It was quite good.  The scoop of Potato Salad was a cool change from fries.  

If not for the fact that I had a ways to go before the day was over, I might have lingered over a second or third drink, and become friends with the attractive keepers.  I had to face the withering heat regardless of my wish to avoid it.  Luckily, there was an ice cream barn right in the parking lot that was about it receive my dessert business.  More on that in another review.  

The lunch had an epic feel to it due to the surrounding circumstance, but based on the food alone I feel no urgency to visit again.  It was a solid meal, but it would have attained higher rank if the bar folk had been initially more attentive as they busied themselves with prep work for the evening crowd.  The invisibility may have been part of the existential void I felt coming in, but they played their part in extending that sense longer than necessary.  

Still, a worthy stop on the stagecoach line between Easton and Philadelphia.

Pho 75 on Adams Avenue does only one thing, but it does it very well. Beef Pho in all its variations still makes for a fairly limited menu, but on the other hand makes for easy choices.  Round Eye, Tendon, Tripe, etc., are all there in either a regular or large size.  Their bowls are smaller than in other shops, but still big enough to completely fill your belly with very good beef broth, rice noodles, onion and a load of selected cow parts, to which you can add fresh Thai Basil, Sprouts, Jalapeno slices, and Lemon(not lime) Squeeze.  

If Beef Pho is your yen, then you will be quite content here, because the steaming bowls flow quickly from the kitchen, and are very tasty and filling.  Just be sure you are not looking for a full course meal, because that won't happen.  No apps. No com (rice). No Binh Mi. No sweets. No Pho Ga.  They do offer coffee and a few other drinks. 

So, what's the problem? The restaurant has little atmosphere; tables and heavy stackable chairs without the semblance of comfort.  The service is efficient with no effort to interact with the customers beyond perfunctory order taking and fast delivery. The place is a bit worn out and could use some TLC.  Most significantly, it is CASH ONLY, with a little ATM sitting near to the cashier.  For a business with five outlets in the region, that is another indication of lack of concern for the patron. Certainly they have the roots in the community and relationships with financial institutions to be able to offer a credit card option.  

Bottom Line - While the pho is quite good, if restricted in options, the surrounding elements within make Pho 75 a less than desirable destination for my Vietnamese fix.  There are too many nicer, friendlier, more comforting joints, to make this place "go to."

My first time back here since joining Yelp*.

New Plum Tree is a Chinese/Thai restaurant in name, but it is fundamentally Chinese American cuisine with a Thai menu thrown in for good measure.  Neither are really outstanding, but both are competently prepared for the local palate.  I tend toward the Thai side of the street and have tried several dishes from noodle (Pad Thai) through Curries (Like the Green Curry dishes better than the Red).  

Today I stopped in just after 12, which is early for me, but I was coming back from Philly, and decided to sit down rather than pick something up to eat at my office.  I had a veggie plate primarily of Eggplant mixed with Green and Red Pepper, Carrots, Peas, and Basil Leaves.  It had a mildly spicy brown sauce that also suggested some Ginger Root in the mélange.  It was good, and felt to be a healthier alternative without meat.  

What can I say?  It was Okay. I am not rushing back, but neither will I avoid it. 

My fortune: "If it seems fates are against you today, they probably are."  Thanks. I already knew that!

Learn Chinese:" A moment" = Yi hui er.  Yes. Time waits for no one. (Especially, bad fortune cookie makers.)

Tan May Chinese Restaurant sits in the Shop Rite center just off Pennington Road in Ewing, NJ. While primarily a take out joint, there are six tables for sitting in, and for the owner's kids to hang out on during summer vacation. Nice to see the family together. 
My lunch special was actually better than expected. The egg Foo Young was made with fresh ingredients and the ubiquitous brown sauce lighter and more flavorful than in most chop shops. Even the fried rice, though that prefab yellow cast, was at least tender and full of finely cut veggies. 
Prices were ridiculously low (under $7), and there was a choice of soup, egg roll or bottled drink included. No extra charge for my Snapple. 
While the place could be cleaner, and the mess in the hallway leading to the restroom organized and stored out of sight, the food makes it worthy of regular, if infrequent, visits.

Northern Liberties now has a fair share of interesting and comfortable places to eat, drink and hang out over cups of good coffee.  One of the earliest pioneers that continues to pump out java and decent bakery snacks is Higher Grounds on North 3rd Street.  This converted row house draws a local crowd, as well as longstriders from farther south in Center City, and the occasional visitor from farther afield.  It is attractive in a Salvation Army Store furniture kind of way, with a lot of art, crafts, and a vast variety of tchotchkes to catch your attention.  It is cozy and worn, like an old couch or settee should be.  

The caffeine options are decent, but by comparison to other jumpin' joe joints in the vicinity, not in the vanguard in terms of coffee quality, nor barista excellence. Our sampling of hot chai latte and cappuccino left us feeling like we had tasted better elsewhere recently.  Still, the lemon pound cake was tasty, and the ability to sit back and watch this part of the Universe go by was a pleasant timeout.  Just wish we were holding ceramic rather than paper cups to enhance to quality of the experience.
