There are ever more coffee outlets in the expanding urbansphere, and they all try to outdo each other with service, product, and atmospherics. Higher Grounds has the advantage of being an early provider in this neck of the woods, but also the disadvantage of staking its claim before cafes became more popular and the customers more demanding.  

If it was open to suggestion, a gentle makeover with heavy cleaning, fresh paint, and a competition to select the best available local roasted coffee, would raise the expectations here to better account for the changing java life in Philadelphia.

The old furniture is reminiscent of grandma's house, and should stay.

Enzo's Pizzeria on West Maple Avenue, Langhorne, PA, is in the same strip center as CVS and Hong Kong Cafe. It is a traditional American pizza parlor with full complement of pies, stromboli, steak sandwiches and standard pasta and chicken dinners. There are a half dozen booths in house, so most of their business is takeout. Service is friendly. 

I stopped in to check it out with an early supper. I took a booth toward the back and ordered their Enzo's Eggplant Bonanza sandwich, an amalgam of breaded fried eggplant, sauteed spinach, roasted red peppers, melted sharp provolone and very tasty pesto mayonnaise. 

It arrived on a paper plate is a puddle of oil and thin plastic utensils. Presentation is important, and these guys blew it royally. What would it take to serve a heavy leaky torpedo on something more substantial? That the mess wasn't noticed or they just didn't care shows lack of quality control and disrespect for customers. 

The ironic part is that the sandwich was actually very good. The combination of flavors and textures, and especially the pesto mayonnaise on the crusty loaf and the mix of the eggplant and peppers we're well worth the price of $7.95. 

If they had just thought about a better way of dealing with eat in customers they would have been starred up for creativity in the kitchen. 

2.5 Stars

I am a little confused by this new chicken shack on Race Street in Philly Chinatown. 

Yes. It is cool the way it is an up the stairs second story shop. Its utilitarian set up with basic tables and chairs with little comfort shouts that this is a fast food joint that doesn't invite hanging around, although the wings are prepped as ordered and take 20 minutes to come out of the fryer. I am okay with all that. Yet, although called, "bbq chicken," all lower case, in fact there is no BBQ chicken there. It is all Korean-type double fried chicken wings and cold drinks, bubble teas, smoothies, etc. The wall menu has about 50 drink options, yet just 7 flavor finishes for their wings. Bird choices are wings, boneless wings or chicken sandwich. If I didn't know better, I'd think this was really another over saturated bubble tea house offering wings on the side (By comparison, Vivi around the corner is all about interesting drinks, and offers deep fried wings as a nosh, for a lot less money.).

Go figure.

What about the wings? Well, they were crispy enough, and the soy garlic and secret spicy sauces were pretty good. As others have said, the secret in the spicy was that it was more sweet than hot, although there was some warmth behind the sugar. I liked the soy garlic better, but as I slowed down after the initial rush to dive into them, I began to taste the underlying oil they were cooked in. Not so nice. 

Soho has nothing to worry about from understated lower case 'bbq chicken'. It needs to decide what it really is and let everyone know.

Called ahead to pick up a large pie for dinner. Half plain. Half sausage. This was my first visit to Red Star Pizza 3, and my impression was that it was attractive inside, with room to sit for dinner, and had a friendly efficient staff. The pizza was ready when I arrived, and I was back on the road in under five minutes. 

Opening the box in my kitchen, it looked good and had a nice aroma. Pizza is always best eaten straight from the oven, and this one confirmed that axiom. Both slices had the right combo of sauce and cheese, but having cooled for a while, the crust was now weak and could not hold the topside weight. Still, the taste was there. The sausage crumble was strong. 

We had a decent dinner from Red Star, and will get back there to mange in house as soon as possible.

This is a mini-DD that shares the building with another business, yet it has a small outdoor seating area in front of the shop if you really feel like hanging out and smelling the exhaust of the cars parked right next to you. 

The coffee is what most of us expect from this ever expanding franchise.  Average coffee whose main attraction is its basic consistency across the nation.  

Service here is fast and efficient, if not overly friendly nor engaging.  

It is amazing how different each DD "makes the donuts," however, I did not have any here and cannot speak to their taste and quality.

Lambertville Trading Company on Bridge Street, Lambertville, NJ, is right next door to Sneddon's Luncheonette, so it is possible to have breakfast at the former, and a decent java jolt at the latter, and feel good about your exploration of this beautiful river city. 

The shop itself is quite small.  There are a few seats in the window alcoves, and a couple of stools in the rear, but otherwise, this place is mostly takeout. It is all wood and glass displays from floor to ceiling, and it is somewhat captivating in its downright cuteness. It was brewing coffee before there was a Starbucks, and certainly deserves your affection and appreciation for that.  They also do a small bakery product retail to go with the joe. 

Word is that they use Small World Coffee Roasters out of Princeton, but I could not vouch for that as there were plenty of other bags of beans behind the counter with other labels on them. My own decaf latte was a bit harsher than expected and slowly degraded to a bitter aftertaste by the time I reached the office. The chocolate chip cookie I scored for accompaniment was nearly as large as my hand and was nicely crisp.  The $1 Yelp discount upon checking in made it a pretty sweet deal. 

LTC is still the best place in L'ville to buy your coffee for your walkabout. It continues to fit right in with all the other antique shops in town.

The choice was between Jack & Jill hard ice cream and vanilla/chocolate/orange soft serve. I went with a cup of orange vanilla swirl in styro. While waiting at the window of this renovated former fast food shell, I watched all the families sitting around enjoying a cool moment on a humid sticky evening in June. 

I was more in the mood to drive home and spoon the melting combo in air conditioned comfort. Besides, I prefer drinking this elixer to licking it. I sampled it at red lights along the way. 

Have to admit to being disappointed. The vanilla had little flavor and the orange while tasty, was also grainy like the orange powder had not been mixed enough to reach the smooth silkiness desired for soft serve. 

There are many choices for ice cream in this part of the world, so I hope this was just a glitch in a normally high quality operation.

This Dunkin is located at the intersection of Parkway Avenue and Pennington Road in Trenton, NJ.  It is fairly new and is well maintained.  There is a drive thru option. Plenty of parking if you want to go inside. 

I walked in after lunch to grab an afternoon wakemeup.  The woman behind the counter was friendly and efficient. They had a surprisingly full rack of donut and muffin options for the time of day.  A few customers sat at one of the tables discussing business. Overall, the place was attractive, with everyone doing their job professionally.  

The coffee was what you expect from this franchise.  Consistent. Strong. Not overly acidic. Not particularly flavorful. Fully capable of keeping me awake for my afternoon surge toward the five o'clock world.  

Right down the middle.

Chinese/American Lunch Special Review - 

I didn't expect much reward when I stopped into King China on State Road, Croydon, PA, for lunch after getting new tires for my car a few days ago. Walking in, the shop appeared worn and in need of some TLC. The menu was a trifold handout and photos of their greatest hits high on the wall. I ordered egg foo young, which came with wonton soup and fried rice, for around $7. 

Surprisingly, the meal was pretty good (for Americanized Chinois). The chicken stock was not overly salted, nor did it taste past its prime. The wontons were fairly thick skinned, but the filling was decent. The rice was likewise recently made and still granular without being clumpy and with plenty of veggies and bits of pork. Finally, the egg pancakes were light and loaded with bbq pork, sprouts, carrot and peas. The brown sauce was well made and plainly  prepared just for my order. Although the soup was served in a plastic pint container, the solids arrived on a nice heavy gauge plate. It would have been great had they offered wooden disposable chopsticks, rather than flimsy plastic utensils. 

I enjoyed the lunch despite its expected shortcomings, but moreso for its small unexpected pleasures.

The first review I wrote for this burgerdom disappeared from Yelp a few years ago for reasons unknown. When I stopped in recently with my son, I realized I hadn't replaced it. Out of sight. Out of mind. 

This is the BK closest to Sesame Place in Middletown, Bucks County, PA. As such it draws heavily from family visits, and has attempted to make this operation a showplace. To a certain degree they have succeeded. There are inside/outside play areas for children, ordering stations that let you avoid human contact if you don't want to deal with high school students working their first jobs, and even partial table service where your tray it brought to you by the staff rather than waiting around in the lobby to be called. There is even a cozy fire pit zone that could be considered romantic by some. Mostly good things (except, my first job was in a burger joint and it was a great training experience, that I wish they continue). Given these amenities, you know that they have some good ideas, and makes you wonder why they don't do these tricks everywhere. 

Still, there are some things that don't change. Like the quality of the meal prepared in the kitchen. You still have to deal with thin, too salty burgers, that have little flavor, fries that chill quickly and become dry and lifeless, and sugar loaded drinks that just are not good for you. 

Bottom line - Comfort is a variable they are willing to enhance to impress the visiting public, but food service remains inferior to most of the new fast casual joints sprouting up across the country, with much better sandwiches and shakes for only a few bucks more. 

In the race for a better burger, BK only seems to be falling further behind.

As the name suggests, Peking Tokyo is a new Asian fusion house in the Pine Watson Shopping Center in the heart of downtown Langhorne, PA. In addition to Chinese and Japanese elements, Thai cuisine is given a nod with a few curry and noodle dishes. I was there for lunch, and as everyone working there were speaking Chinese only, I was most interested in that part of the menu. 

I asked for their lunch specials General Tso's Chicken, extra heat, which came with a cup of soup (Wonton), small ginger dressed salad, and fried rice. I also had a mug of green tea (an extra charge, although not disclosed until the bill appeared). 

Everything was okay, but the only thing that stood out was the quality fried rice. It was freshly made with a higher standard grain, veggies and no dye. The soup was beef consomme with thick skinned wontons and decent filling. The chicken was plentiful and encased in a thickish shell. The sauce was tart as requested, with a few Szechuan red peppers in the mix. Particularly tasty when the rice was tossed in. The salad was from their sushi offerings - a first for me for a Chinese lunch and a nice touch, although I am not a fan of that ubiquitous ginger dressing.

Service was fine, and the manager stopped by to check on my satisfaction. The sushi chef stood at his bar in uniform and at the ready. 

Peking Tokyo (Bangkok) is a step ahead of its predecessors in variety and quality from this vantage point, and as a new business it is still on its shakedown cruise. Hope it maintains high standards and is successful. Langhorne Borough certainly deserves that.

Second Street Pike Grill is a nicely laid out dining room with the look of gray marble on walls and table tops. The menu is oriented around fruit smoothies, breakfast and lunch. When I walked in the other day around 8:45 AM, I was the solitary customer and was told to sit anywhere. I did so at a table close to the front window after picking up their bifold menu at the counter. There was a large board on the back wall listing the smoothie possibilities. Not for nothing, I wondered why there were no fruit, nor blenders in sight. Maybe not the best way to market their signature product. 

So, I slid over to their more traditional breakfast options and Made My Own Sandwich of turkey bacon, cheddar and fried eggs on English muffin with side of home fries included. It arrived open faced about ten minutes later. 

It was okay, but could have been better @ $9. The bacon was thick, but lacked crispness. The eggs were fried to near dryness, where a bit of runny would have better integrated the elements. The potatoes were mealy and lacked the firmness of quality chunky morning spuds. On the other hand, the house coffee was very good. 

Service was friendly and informative. Access was fine throughout. 

2 Street Pike Grill - Attractive with good ideas that fall short in execution. A more deft hand at the hot steel would help.

Farnsworth Avenue was all dress up for the Sidewalk Sale going on Friday afternoon.  Looked great! 

I was in the mood to sample the Tomato Pie at Marcello's Restaurant & Tomato Pie, but as it was not offered by the slice, and the small pie was a glaring $16, I decided it would have to wait for another time when the cost was more in line with the occasion. It might be awesome, but it would have to knock my socks off. 

So, I ordered the Eggplant Parm Sandwich with a two buck Side Salad (total cost: $10. plus tip).  It took a while for it to arrive, and I had ample time to look around the barroom where I sat.  Very attractive cross between Colonial and contempo styles.  The room was mostly full with leisurely diners enjoying this mid August afternoon.  The side patio was temporarily closed for construction, but it looked like it would be a nice place for a cooler evening al fresco dinner.  

Maybe next time.  

My meal arrived.  It looked great on the plate with toasted Italian loaf seared to melt and seal the Mozza and thin sliced Eggplant within.  There was more bread than veggie, and the diameter made it necessary to eat with knife and fork.  The Eggplant was well cooked; pleasantly soft and mixed well with the cheese and Tomato Sauce.  It is a matter of personal preference, but I prefer the double sautéed approach to Eggplant and the use of a light coating of spiced bread crumbs to give it more texture and flavor.  This dish was done in a single cooking style, and without the crumbs; thus, somewhat light on taste and interest.  There could have been more sauce as well, perhaps on the side, to provide more oomph. 

Marcello's is a nicely appointed house, with attentive staff, and it clearly aspires to be a higher end Casa Italiana. In this it mostly succeeds.  But, I won't know for sure if it is all that until I take my first bite of its tomato pie.

COFFEE STOP REVIEW:

When the sign on the door of the nearby bagel shop said it was closed permanently, I looked for an alternative source for the caffeine fix I needed to account for my earlier than normal awakening to attend to a court matter in Mt. Holly, NJ. Luckily for me there was a Wawa right down the road. 

It was an old version convenience store, sans gas pumps and large food preparation area. Still, it had 6 types of java and a fixings island. All this boy needed. The Guatemalan medium roast caught my attention, and I poured it into a 16 oz container with a milk lightener to taste. 

I pulled in the first sip as I settled back in my car. Hot, strong and pleasantly robust, it was just what the doctor ordered. Had me humming and beating my fingers on the wheel in minutes. When I walked into the judge's Chambers I was fully equipped to handle whatever my adversary threw my way.

New China House down on Haines Road, Levittown, PA, is the successor to Zhang's, the mildly popular dine in/take out joint. The transfer of ownership took place three years ago, but this news wasn't shared with Yelp for some reason. Too bad, because it turns out that despite the divey appearance the Chinese American food is better than average. The place deserves some recognition. 

The House is family run with wife up front and hubs in apron beating the wok. Strictly take out, I was told I could not eat my lunch on the one table on the floor. Okay, I'll leave. I can stand the rejection, but if you had permitted me a few minutes to eat, you would have heard me compliment your rendition of General Tso's Chicken as not being too breaded, with decent sauce, and appreciation for throwing in a few Szechuan peppers for the extra heat I requested. 

Too, you would have heard me say that the wonton soup tasted fresh and that the wontons were fairly thin skinned and filled with decent ground beef/pork. Finally, that the pork fried rice had a natural color and good texture full of peas, carrots, onions and sprouts. Overall, a satisfactory lunch at a very reasonable price.

Just wish I had been there to let them know. Guess this review will have to do.

I have never seen a larger breakfast menu than at Cracker Barrel. It is all very traditional and Southern, with huge portions of everything. Prices reasonable, too. Yet, this is not the place to go if you want to avoid temptation to over indulge on very fattening dishes.  Simply unavoidable here.  Even the "healthy" oatmeal is loaded with sweet fruity things that sound good for you, but really are not. Too much sugar and processing with everything you eat. 

However, if you feel like chowing down with country fried steak, biscuits and gravy, fat bacon, sausage ground from various animals, and lots of eggs, there are few places that can fulfill your fantasies like Cracker Barrel.  That, and a cute-to-death country store up front that is Americana gone to seed.  Where to look first?! 

I was here for a business breakfast suggested by the other guy.  I was curious, because Cracker Barrel was new to me.  I've seen them around, but always thought it was more a gift shop than a restaurant. I was wrong. It is really both. I tried to order a simple breakfast sandwich on a biscuit, but was advised that was not on the menu because their biscuits were too small. Instead, I could have it on thick sourdough-like white bread, complete with eggs and cheese, but not with the meat on the bread.  It had to be a separate plated side.  Okay. Whatever. Do it your way. Surprise me. 

What arrived was a large plate with oversized toasted bread, two fried eggs (medium hard), and a large dose of melty yellow Colby.  Two medium sized pork sausage patties were on a separate dish. I had to cut and assemble each forkful bite.  I didn't mind, but it was hard to believe the kitchen could not do this so that the pieces had time to meld together.  It was all decent and tasty.  The homefries mound which they brag about was also okay, but perhaps a bit to mashed and not as chunky as preferred. 

The coffee was average, and flowed freely.  

Can't say that I fell in love with Cracker Barrel, but I understood how that would be possible for people who like big breakfasts loaded with meat, eggs, cheese and/or pancake mix.  For me, it was just overload.

COFFEE STOP REVIEW:

Driving south on Route 130 (perhaps the ugliest road in New Jersey) on the way to court in Camden, I knew I needed a caffeine boost to compensate for my early start to the day. Up ahead I spied the golden arches on my side of the road and pulled in. 

They had double drive thru lanes which seemed to be moving slowly for the cars in front of mine. When I reached the order kiosk I realized that the order taker was taking his time, repeating the order and asking if he had it right. Nothing wrong with that. I requested a small coffee with milk. 

He asked me if I wanted to buy the milk to put in the coffee. What?! Apparently, this store only offered complimentary mini-moos for java, but milk was a luxury extra charge item. This surprised and annoyed me, and I wondered whether this dude had it right. Would McDonald's be that dumb as to refuse to open a house bottle of milk for such orders, or was this an untrained part timer gone rogue? My decision; two creamers, please. I wasn't going to pay for this bizarre policy. 

Anyway, the coffee was a fine generic blend, hot and strong. It did its job, and I went about the rest of my day.

Kumo Asian Bistro is in reality a Chinese sushi joint in one of the many shopping centers along Bethlehem Pike in North Wales, Pa.  As such, they offer a nice facility with broad menu that is primarily rolls and cold fish, with minimum dishes from China and Thailand. Everything is decent, but nothing stands out as exceptional, requiring return visits, unless you are from the area.  It is very much a variation of the sushi theme, without high artistry. Still, service was fine, and I had no real quarrel with what we ate. 

Meeting friends we were able to order extra dishes and sample everything placed before us. We ordered several apps, and two rolls (sorry, didn't catch the names).  We began with their "Sushi Pizza," a good tasting, if poorly named, mix that reminded of its Italian namesake only in its shape.  It was just as much "taco."  Crisp tortilla-like base with a pleasant load topside. Fun and enjoyable.  Their calamari was tempura style, which was not as good as the original in that it lacked good texture, and once cooled, returned to a too-chewy amorphousness.  The beef negiyaki was more interesting as a semi-spicy veggie combo wrapped in beef.  In truth, would not get either of those again. The two rolls ordered by our friends were fine offerings, one topped with eel. 

This experience was more about our conversation than our meal, so the food was comparatively less important than what we were talking about. Still, the room and the platters were a good backdrop for us. We had room, space and time to relax and enjoy the moment. We never felt rushed, and our server engaged with us when appropriate. 

Prices were reasonable given everything involved.  There are no doubt better sushi houses around, but this one was right for the occasion.

Two Slices & a Drink Review

The first thing you notice when approaching Mannino's Pizza is the pollution coming from the tobacco shop next door.  Heavy cigar smoke hangs in the air, making it an unpleasant challenge to go inside.  Public officials should not permit such uses near food establishments as is a negative and so unhealthy. 

But, after getting inside, this Italian house is fairly typical of the genre.  Booths up front. Kitchen counter in the rear.  Dining room to one side.  Clean and pleasant.  I ordered a slice of Tomato Pie and another Regular with a soft drink.  The pizzaman behind the counter was friendly and understood with a nod when I asked for the reheat to be "well done."  

That is what I received.  The slices were placed on a large plate (so much nicer than using paper), and were steaming nicely as I carried them to my table.  A peak at the undercarriage showed nice scorch marks from the oven, and the aroma of tomato, garlic and basil wafted pleasantly in my face.  The Tomato Pie was very good.  The crust held firm when picked up, and released a loud crunch when bitten.  In addition to the above ingredients, the sauce was mildly sweet, which I prefer.  A nice slice from beginning to end.  The Regular Slice was not quite as athletic.  Its point wilted when lifted from the crusty rim due to an excess of cheese that was too heavy for the underside to endure.  Folding the slice was a help, but it also provided a crease for the extra oil to run off onto the plate.  The sauce was okay, but overwhelmed by the cheese.  I prefer more balance between the two topsides.  

Still, I was satisfied, if not ecstatic with my evening snack.  The place is comfortable and the staff is friendly and capable.  

Just wish the dudes next door had better ventilation that didn't leave a cloud of Perdomo exhaust where non-smokers must inhale.

Take out only Chinese American shop on Lincoln Highway (Rt. 1), Levittown, PA. All the usual suspects, including General Tso's Chicken, my choice. The place needs a thorough cleaning, especially around the floor to near ceiling stack of soda cases around the cooler. 

My combo included a heavy load of fried rice dyed dark brown from the bouillion in which it was cooked,  and a smallish egg roll that while crisp was 95% cabbage. The actual chicken was pretty good with the extra heat from a few Szechuan chilies I requested. The portion was impressive. I couldn't finish all that was stuffed into the plastic container. 

Overall, if the main course is what matters most, 21 Chinese Kitchen did chicken well, with  respectable sauce. The rest of the meal was mostly empty filler, not worth consuming. If you figure out how to get just what you want without the other stuff, a satisfying meal is within your grasp.

What for decades had been a dilapidated ramshackle old corner at Langhorne-Yardley Road and Stony Hill Road has been nicely renovated into a small commercial complex with Edgewood Café anchoring the intersection.  The architect and builder did a very good job.  The property is now very attractive. 

The Café feels both old and new.  Narrow plank wood floor and exposed beam high ceiling provide a light airiness, while the dark tones of the booths offer a sense of colonial times.  I sat at the counter with several other guys and had a nice overview of the operation.  The breakfast menu is two pages with an adequate variety of options and flexibility.  My wait person suggested that the fancy egg dishes were very good, but I opted for a full stack of French Toast and a mug of coffee.  A note said the toast could be made, "crunchy," so I asked about that.  Breading with crushed Captain Krunch. Maybe next time. 

My breakfast arrived a few minutes later on a large oval plate, dusted with powdered sugar, and a small dish of butter on the side.  The syrup was brought up from under the counter, and had a thick pour.  Not maple, but decent.  The menu describes the dish as a "Texas" slice of bread.  Not sure as I did not measure it, but perhaps the extra width required more time in the egg bowl to assure full saturation, as the middle was slightly dry.  Not a serious shortcoming and easily corrected. My coffee mug was refilled thrice, and it was a good commercial blend from a Bunn drip. 

One piece of advice I would offer is that the servers smile more.  They are helpful and efficient, but they put off a vibe that they are not comfortable in their jobs.  Perhaps, they are naturally shy young women, but learning to act like a wait person will improve their job approval, and tips. That is something management can talk to them about, and tell them to act more relaxed and try to have some fun while being professional. 

PS. A sign at the back door/main entrance would be a big help for newcomers, as it is not obvious where the café is, nor how to enter from the parking lot.

Not a fan of the Chipotle approach to Mexican food, I was disappointed that the new Mariachi Grill in Campus Town on the edge of The College of New Jersey adopted that process. Their shops on Parkway in Ewing and Quakerbridge in Hamilton are the traditional full kitchen variety, and are pretty good representations of Mexican American cuisine. Although the "pick your ingredients" can be considered  the way to customize a taco or burrito, to me it seems more the way to limit the menu to only a few possibilities, while preparation of the elements in advance means you often secure overcooked and dried out parts. A look at all the choices on the steam table behind the counter, offered proof of theory. The steak, chicken and ground beef all seemed desiccated and lacking energy. 

They were out of the al pastor (roast pork & pineapple), and the only remaining juicy-looking choice was the carnitas (BBQ pork). I went with that in their duo taco plate (rice, black beans, lettuce, tomato, lime, radish & pico). The double tortilla soft shell kept its poise throughout the meal, with minimal leakage. They were tasty and well spiced. The rice and beans were forgettable. At just under $9 with drink, the price was fair. I left belly full. 

Still, I prefer other Mexican dishes like chili rellenos and flautas, not to mention fresh fish and fruit drinks,  much more than tacos, burritos and quesadillas, which all have the same contents with different packaging. Such variety was not on the menu there, although they are in their other tiendas. 

If all you desire is basic Mexifast food, you can be satisfied at Mariachi. But, Mexican cuisine is far more diverse and delicious than portrayed here, and deserving of exploration and ravishing. There are plenty of those places across Trenton, Hamilton and Hightstown. Once seduced by those amazing spicy senoritas, it is difficult to really enjoy the Chipotle approach to South of the Border cooking.

Pop's Bagels sits in the shadow of Johnny Apple's in Holland, PA. It is a small shop with a few tables, counter and bagel bins along the walls. It is bright white, and on a sunny late September morning the room was very inviting. The folks working there were nearly as bright and cheerful. I ordered my customary onion bagel with butter and swiss, not toasted, and retreated to the side of the room to wait and watch. 

Families came in for bags of rounders, and a few occupied the tables available. My coffee and bagel were called, and I grabbed and walked out again into the morning light. The parking lot is far larger than the store so there is never a shortage of spaces. 

The bagel was fresh and pliant, with a mix of both savory (onion) and sweet (dough) flavors. The crust lacked any crispness and I couldn't differentiate between the skin and inner texture. Too, the meat of the bagel although light and chewy, lacked the air pockets found in traditional ones. Perhaps, more boiling or lye exposure would create that texture. 

Many people prefer this style bagel, but it is not my desired finish.

Stopped into JB Bakery after court the other day.  I had driven by many times, but never at a moment when I could check it out. 

This is a traditional bakery with wall to wall refrigerated display cases showing rainbows of cakes, donuts, cookies, as well as a coffee service station for those in need of java.  Everything looked great, and the young women working there were friendly and very helpful with making selections.  

I ordered a half doz Glazed and Vanilla Iced Donuts for the office, and one Carrot Cake Cupcake for a home dessert.  None of them were as good as I had expected from just looking at them.  The donuts were a bit past their prime when I picked them up before noon.  Their edges were becoming hard, and the heart of the dough was no longer soft and fresh.  They were still pretty good, just not the stuff of deserving a ringing endorsement.  

The Carrot Cake Cupcake was packaged well in a well designed plastic container, but I found the ample icing to be tasty, but lighter and less dense than true butter cream or cream cheese.  The actual cake was okay, but not the moist carroty base of a true carrot cake.  Again, it was decent, but far from great. 

The coffee was brewed as I waited, and was fine. 

Overall, this place is fun to explore, and perhaps there are other more delicious options within.  Still, I am a donut/cupcake person, and I would not rush back for more of them.

Ritz Diner at the intersection of Roosevelt Blvd and Rhawn, is a fairly typical roadside diner in Northeast Philadelphia. Its menu is likewise standard fare, with a full page of breakfast possibilities on the back. That's what I was there for, and it only took a minute to decide I wanted their Ritz Omelet (onion, green pepper, tomato and hot Italian sausage), with Rye Toast and bottomless mug of Java. 

Service was very good and it was beautifully presented within minutes of ordering. First observation was that it looked to be a three egger with filling enough for a smaller shell. Its pants were too big for its body, as both ends were a couple inches of egg without anything within. It tasted fine although the heat from the sausage failed to materialize very often. It was still enough for me, especially with the well buttered toast and refills of coffee brought to me by my friendly server. So, I am not complaining, but only making an observation, and suggestion that if I was aware of this imbalance, others would be too, and perhaps adjustments should be made. 

Didn't see much in the way of in-house bakery goods, nor a bar, nor even a traditional counter with spinners for the solitary traveler.  

Adequate parking in front.

This is one of the Einstein Brothers Bagel franchises that has not been accurately identified on Yelp*. 
As with all the other Einsteins I have customered, this one has in-house baked fresh bagels for any meal. The floor plan is large, the tables and high tops are not too close to each other, and in warm weather there is a small outdoor deck with a few tables. 
There are more varieties of bagels than in most local shops, including those with jalapenos, cinnamon, asiago, pumpernickle, etc., along with the standards found almost everywhere.  The coffee is better than average, and its beans/ground are for sale. The staff is young, well trained and friendly.  This particular location often has seniors meeting at the large tables having a good time.  Perhaps, this is because there are a few assisted living facilities in the area, and this is a nice place to hang out as a mall walking alternative.  There are also doctors, nurses, lab techs stopping in on their way to/from the local hospital. 
This is not my favorite bagel, as the outside is soft, not firm or almost crunchy, as I prefer them.  It is more like regular bread in a bagel shape.  Still, the freshness and customizing makes it acceptable when in need, or close by.  
Many people enjoy bagel sandwiches, but I am not one of them.  Still, there are many options on the menu.  Their Bagel Dog (hot dog wrapped in a thin bagel skin) is pretty good.  Their daily soups are okay, and they have soup/sandwich combos at good prices. 
Bottom Line - It is an OK place for a quick stop or sitting around for a while, but if a better bagel is what you need, a visit to Bagel Train in Yardley is your next stop.

Typical Chinese kitchen in DeKalb Pike, Blue Bell, PA. All the usual menu suspects with long lunch specials list @$6.95, with rice, broccoli and soft drink. Soup and egg roll not included. 

My General Tso's Chicken was served in house in a takeout container and flimsy white plastic fork. The flavor of the sauce had a little heat, but was otherwise unremarkable. Same for the fried rice and the florets. The only thing that stood out from the other Chinois/American hybrid houses was the outward charm and warm interaction provided by the friendly and solicitous owner, who was very happy to meet a new customer. 

Decent takeout place, but not beyond the mean of all such restaurants. Good for a fast and cheap lunch. They had a stream of people coming in for pickup while I was there, most of whom seemed to have been there before. 

Doubtful I will ever be in that group.

I guess you have to possess fond memories of Pollo Campero from your childhood or hometown to fully appreciate the specialness of this place.  It is a bright and happy place, and the food gets to your table quickly with a smiling face attached.  But, after taking a big bite out of their famous Chicken the party comes to an end rather quickly. 

True, the chicken is fresh and juicy, and has a citrus and chili flavor going on to tickle the taste buds.  But, after that the experience is rather flat.  The side dishes are ordinary (beans, coleslaw, taters, etc.), and the drinks are generic except for the Horacha, which was too sweet and tasted like it was from a mix. 

As fast chicken goes, this is a reasonable alternative to the Colonel or Popeye's, but not as good as a Bojangles or Cluck-U. There are other Guatemalan restaurants in Trenton that make great fried chicken in a much more unique and pleasant atmosphere.  If you have the time and sense of adventure, you should try them and compare.

This is my third visit to a Manhattan Bagel store in the past few weeks. They all look basically the same, both in substance and cleanliness. Staff is friendly, helpful and efficient. 

The bagels were all decent, but not in the pantheon of great New York style rounders. So, it is somewhat surprising that they use the name of the city that made bagels famous, because they fall far short of that standard. Yet, they are good enough to satisfy my breakfast hunger, even if not epic. 

My onion bagel with veggie cream cheese was tasty and chewy, with a slightly crisp skin. The spread was ample, if not over the top generous. Their coffee was good, with a few alternatives between House Blend, Bold, fruity and decaf. Certainly, caffeinated to wake me up and keep me focused. 

The only real issue worth noting was the inconsistent experience offered by the three shops visited in this area. They looked the same, and the cream cheese was enjoyable across the board, but the freshness and texture alternated between right on target with crisp outer surface and softer texture within; and a chew that suggested the bagel was not as fresh (although purchased and eaten an approximately the same time), and may have been from a batch made earlier in the day. When it comes to out of the oven bagels, even a few hours more exposed to the environment can mean an aging that is noticeable. 

So it was with these samples. Today's was the least fresh, while smeared with the most cream cheese. Perhaps that was not an accident.

Einstein Bros. App Review -

I have returned to Einstein Bros Bagels after several years away, drawn in by their new app on mobile. Now that I have used it a half dozen times I have a few comments to offer:
1. The app is easy to use and attractively presented.

2. If using PayPal or credit card on the app, once you provide the account info, ordering is a breeze, and can be repeated with a few clicks. 

3. Both curbside and walk-in pick up are available, but if ordering java, you have to go in and pour it yourself. They do put an empty 12 oz. paper cut and plastic top next to your bagged bagel, so there is a level of convenience if you don't mind walking to the self serve coffee shelf to take care of this. 

4. Of course, their bagels haven't changed, so there is no magic in digitalizing the process. Still a soft finish, with a heavy dose of toppings all around. As I prefer a crunchy bite, these rounders will never make my hit parade. Nonetheless, the spreads are decent and the overall gestalt, satisfactory. 

5. There are a few shortcomings in the bagel preparation which should be addressed. They don't cut the smeared bagel in half, as I remember they did when eating in. Too, there is no paper wrap around the bagel before placing in those small bagel sized envelopes. Thus, removing the bagel from its sack is a messy proposition. I never fail to get cream cheese on fingers in the process. Picking up and biting into these guys is a similar sticky problem. 

So, while the app improves access to the bagels enough to warrant an additional star, other issues remain that continue to make their bagels problematic. Just don't forget to grab a few napkins before you leave, as the tiny bag is not big enough to slip them cleanly inside.

Love the name. Love the notion of sourcing exclusively from a Pennsylvania Amish farm. Love the antibiotic/filler free birds resting easily in my belly. But, the actual experience of eating their Baja Chicken Sandwich, and the takeout confusion, not so much. 

Lovebird just opened earlier this week, and making all the necessary adjustments as Bucks turns Yellow from Red (Covid-19 speaking), earns them some slack from this sensory deprived quarantine, but some things are still hard to ignore. I didn't mind that there was a communications gap between online ordering, paying, and the chaotic scene upon arrival at the small shop for pick-up. It was a bit tense as some customers came in to wait with their shirts pulled over their mouth and nose because they lacked required masks and recommended gloves and the business had none to offer. It was even okay to wait 30 minutes for my order to be ready, and watch a dozen teenagers scrambling to package the orders into brown bags and seem lost about how to construct a strong meal sack that wouldn't descend into a leaky mess at the bottom of the bag by the time it reached its destination.  

That was annoying as the sandwich containers were removed with oil stains and partially deconstructed ingredients. Worst offender was the brussel sprouts side dish that tasted great in a black roast way, but whose oil cooking medium could not be contained and ran over everything in the bag. A class in solid trigonometry would have helped the unschooled packers. 

Not sure what I expected from a $9 chicken sandwich, but I may have believed that it would compare well with the Chick-fil-A, Popeyes, Wendy's of the world which sold for a coupla bucks less. Aside from the warm fuzzies from knowing the chicken's impressive pedigree, the Bite & Chew left alot to be desired. Plump, yes. Crisp, no. Spicy, no. Hang together to the end, sort of. Of the local competition, Lovebird came in last. 

Just not worth the high end pretense, especially for what they put you through to reach that conclusion.

Mayfair Diner on Frankford Avenue in Northeast Philly, is a classic stainless steel railroad car diner.  The front dining area has been well preserved, so if you are into these iconic food circuses, Mayfair is one you should consider for your collection. 

We stopped in after a concert Saturday night.  The lights were on, and a few tables were occupied. Our server was efficient and gave us time to decide what we wanted as first timers. We ultimately ordered a patty melt, Buffalo chicken cheesesteak and hot Buffalo wings.  Everything came with a boatload of fries.  

My rye burger was pretty good, with lots of sautéed onions on top of a half pounder encased in good rye bread.  The fries were okay, but not as crisp as I like. The cheesesteak was abundant with chopped chicken, onions, peppers and gravy boat of melted cheese. The roll was decent, too. I didn't try the wings, but my son scored them as average. 

Eating in the dining car was a trip.  Although renovated, it still had the legit ambiance of a last century lunch wagon, with long counter and semi-swinging stools. It may date me, but I enjoyed this atmosphere even more than our meal.  

There are several diners along Frankford Avenue, some bigger, others smaller.  Some may have better food, but none do the "Diner Experience" better than Mayfair.

The other reviewers are right. 

This Lucky 7 Deli on Princeton Avenue, Lawrenceville, NJ, is more than it appears to be from the exterior. In addition to the expected convenience store, the operators have put in a small kitchen (grill) and dining area for folks who want to have a hot breakfast or lunch on the premises. It is all very basic, with industrial strength tables and chairs, but the cook seems to know what he is doing, and turns out decent grub. 

My sausage, egg and cheese on kaiser roll, was a double egg and sausage patty job with a single slice of American. The roll wasn't so good and lacked texture and taste, but the runny fried eggs and meat offset that shortcoming. Too, they brew New England Coffee beans - a better than average large roaster/distributer. 

While the joint lacks in the comfort department, my breakfast was delivered to the table by the manager/cashier with a smile, and the purpose of my visit was met satisfactorily. I wouldn't come here on a date, nor even a business meal, but a quick stop by is well within its parameters. They mention fried chicken on the outside sign, but didn't see any within to be able to evaluate its look and quality. 

Maybe another time.

I just needed a caffeine boost to make it back to Pennsy and saw this DD on Broad Street.  It was dark and a little difficult to see the driving lanes in the parking lot.  Next thing I knew I was in the drive thru lane and couldn't get out! 

I reached the order speaker, but did not understand the Hindi dialect being spoken.  I waited until it changed to English and ordered coffee and a round sweet.  Easy so far.  Of course, when I finally opened up the bag when I was back on the street, I had not been given what I ordered.  

Ate it anyway. Not bad.  But, it does prove a point - Sometimes, a drive thru will not do.  There are some things that must be seen before being ordered.  For all I know, they gave me what they thought I wanted. Or maybe, it was just fate that brought me a Sour Cream Donut rather than the Glazed requested.  

These things were meant to be a mystery.

Mil-Lee's Luv-Inn Diner...
It definitely feels like 1975 when you walk in to Mil-Lee's.  It is surprising spacious for occupying one half of an old Victorian mansion of Main Street, Yardley.  Looks like there is room for at least 60 people with many deuces around the room, and a few booths.  Brown and beige very pronounced neutral colors. The staff is warm and friendly, and promptly seat you and ask if you want something to drink.  The coffee arrives quickly while the large menu is perused.  

My breakfast of french toast was good with powdered sugar and cinnamon, but did not seem to be the thick "Texas" style promised.  My partner in crime ordered eggs over, hash browns and well done scrapple, and her plate was overflowing.  The java kept coming, as did the smiling oversight of the waitpeople.  The crowd was mostly locals having meet ups with friends and associates.  One woman had a birthday, and the establishment provided a candled cupcake and announced to everyone that we should sing "Happy Birthday" to the honored guest.  We all joined in.  That was a first for any breakfast I have had - that kind of thing most often happens at a group lunch or dinner.  Great sense of community spirit.

The meals were solid and satisfy, if not particularly inspired, nor memorable for the cuisine.  The thing that makes the  experience special
is the warmth emanating from the staff and customers.  After all, who calls their place a "Luv-Inn" in the 21st Century?  

"...come on people now, get together, smile on your brothers, try to love one another right now!..."
(with thanks and memories to Jesse Colin Young)

Come here for the timeless vibe of returning home, if not for the nostalgia of a good mom-cooked meal.

Mil-Lee's slogan : "Food From the Heart"

Very nice place for our UYE last Friday night.  10 brave souls ventured out after a laborious week to enjoy each other's company and some good grub.  Karma was the choice of our up and coming unofficial social director, Sari (Another great job!). 

The space was a little tight in the back of the house on a long table next to the lunch buffet table and hot plates, but with the glass of wine that came with our $20 three course dinner had us forgetting our surroundings as we caught up with our Yelphriends and new initiates.  True, that the cuisine is somewhat secondary to our passion for each other, but we are "foodies" to a greater or lesser degree, and we are aware of what we eat.  

So, tonight had its good points and some of the other kind as well.  My Veggie Samosa was quite good with good mashed curried potatoes, peas and onion is a lightly fried dough with good tamarind dipping sauce.  One was enough for me.  My Chicken Xacuti had a nice coconut milk based sauce, but with somewhat dry overcooked Chicken.  The Naan/Garlic Naan were very thin, but tasty and capable of holding both the pinched main course and the superior Coconut Curry bath it came in.

The regrettable shock of the evening was tasting my buddy's Taj Mahal Indian Beer.  It was downright skunky, like it had been left in the heat for far too long and only chilled at the last minute.  Management took it off his check, but the damage to the  taste buds was not as easily mended.  

Overall, a decent meal, but one that was not as good as many nearby Indian houses can provide, although our camaraderie made up for much of its shortcomings.

Very surprised that this Mickey D's does not show up on Yelp, although it has been open at this location for several years. It stands next door to the Broad Street Car Wash, so after a shine-on-line, I dropped in for a quickie before heading back to the office. 

The shop is fairly small, but clean.  The counter staff was alert and efficient.  I tried a Double Jalapeno Burger on the Dollar Menu, and a Lemonade.  

Surprisingly, the burger was decent (I know...compared to what?), with both sliced, pickled pepper and crispy, lightly dusted and fried bits of the hot green meanie. 

It might be a few years before I hit another one of these places, but since the last time it was obvious they were trying to improve their offerings.  

The $3.50 price for this small meal had me whistling a happy (meal) tune.

After trying the sushi, Yummy remains 3 Stars.  

It is true as others say that the rolls are larger than in most fish houses.  By larger, I mean in circumference and in size of the component parts.  Yet, while the fish seemed fresh, they did not offer a pronounced flavor beyond the sauce that was drizzled on top and the Soy/Wasabi/Ginger accompaniments.  

Too, the Wasabi was the mass produced green variety that most offer, and the Ginger was the artificially colored orange, rather than the actual white of natural Ginger.  

It was adequate and fresh, but certainly far from best of breed that is available only a short distance away.  

The family is very pleasant, and the hostess friendly and helpful. Her husband does the artistry, while the kids and grandmother sit nearby, making it feel somewhat like I was eating in their dining room.  

Not bad, but not exceptional.  When convenience is the primary factor, it serves its purpose well.

I came here today with my Korean friend who operates a small restaurant in Newtown who needed to restock rice noodles, bowls and a few other things for the ethnic elements of her basically American shop.  This was my first visit, although she knew her way around from past experience here.  

The supermarket is showing its age and lack of maintenance.  While large enough to inventory most of everything needed for an Asian home or resto, it has seen better days, and suffers by comparison to its competitors both nearby and in other Asian neighborhoods here and in Jersey or New York.  The fresh produce and frozen food sections are the highlight of the store, complete with those exotics and flavorfuls that are signature to such establishments.  The remainder of the aisles feel dark and dreary, but possess the required products unique to Asian stores.  The fish department in the back is large with plenty of whole fish on ice, and cut ups in refrigeration units. Plenty of staff to select, weigh, cut and package. However, the ice melts onto the floor, making for a slick foothold and slippery walk.  Yes. There is also the appearance of mold on the floor, bins, and walls.  Perhaps, not the safest place to spend time.  

So, we were able to secure most of what we needed at good prices.  Yet, the check out was slow and bagging disorganized.  Right. Just like the old country. 

There is also an in house restaurant that seemed popular, but we did not check it out, having filled up at Pho 75 less than an hour before.  

This is not the place to make your primary market unless you don't have access to a better shopping experience.  Still, it has just about everything needed for an Asian kitchen at good prices.  It you don't mind the slovenliness, it is acceptable as the place you go to get the things you need while trying not to notice all the things that are wrong.

South Warren Street in Trenton is making an effort to get its act together.  It has always had the big trees and 19th Century architecture, but until the last few years, the storefronts were often empty or lacking in attractiveness.  Things have changed for the better, and it is now possible to walk down Warren and find several nice places to have a meal, drink, or even shop.  

Sunrise Luncheonette is one of those urban pioneers.  It is a small shop with 7 or eight stools at the lunch counter, and about the same number of tables.  Décor is rather Spartan, but the management makes a real effort to make you feel welcome when walking in for breakfast before 8, while the surrounding state government drivers are yet to open.  I sat at the counter and watched as well known customers chatted with the counterman in friendly tones, swapping stories and jokes.

Coffee was served promptly, and was about average.  My Sausage, Egg and Cheese Sandwich on a Roll was also decent and tasty.  The convenience of location cannot be beat.  I enjoyed being able to park on the street without using a meter until 9 am, having a pleasant breakfast only 5 minutes from court, and getting out for under $6. Trenton is actually showing some gritty charm early in the morning, and I enjoyed being part of the wake up.

Sunrise's breakfasts should not be compared to suburban style diners where excess is the name of the game.  No. This is a cityscape locale, where the clientele tells a different story than heard out there.  Life is rougher downtown, and Sunrise Luncheonette reflects that reality.  

If you get off on the difference, this can be a nice way to start the day.

If you like street push cart hot dogs that can be found all over New York, you might really enjoy sampling a couple of "franks" at Russ Ayers Hot Dog Stand in Rt. 206 in Bordentown, NJ.  

Although the push cart is now housed inside a hat box sized structure, they are still boiled in the stainless steel compartments that sit inside the old wooden external walls.  Even the wheels are still attached.  The menu is limited to a half dozen variety of toppings, and they are all slapped into basic white bread buns that can't hold the mustard, onions, relish and other options that the staff loads into them.  

The environment is the best part of the Russ Ayers experience.  The small hut has about 6 stools at the small counter, but many outside tables for good weather noshing.  The drinks are simple soda fountain options or a few bottles in the standup refrigeration unit.  

As a rookie, I ordered one of their basic dogs that came with mustard, onions, kraut and relish on top of the Hatfield pork/beef sausage.  The young cook worked very fast to open the top of the boil box, snag a hot dog, drop it into the bun she held in her other hand, and then slather and spread all the accessories is a blur of near-accurate preparation.  My other choice was a bacon and cheese dog (see photos).  

They were both decent and fun to eat.  In chatting with the workers, I learned that Mr. Ayers was deceased for a couple of decades, but that when he passed, he left the business to his waitress.  She carried on the enterprise with the help of family until the present.  I also learned that they would be installing a milkshake machine soon to add to the festivities.  If done well, that would certainly help.  

I could not help thinking how much more this joint could be with a little more imagination and investment in better provisions.  The Hatfield dogs had a cheap taste.  At $2.25 a dog it was obvious why they didn't have higher quality meat.  Still, I would gladly pay more for a kosher or all beef frankfurter that had better flavor.  Too, improving the buns and condiments would likewise make most people happier with the overall meal.  Finally, unless Mr. Ayers' Last Will & Testament strictly forbid using anything but boiled hot dogs, finding room for a grill as an alternative cooking source would broadly expand the possibilities.  

As it is, Russ Ayers is fine enough for the uniqueness of the experience, as well as its unusual history.  Generations have stopped in for a few dogs and a coke.  So, it really doesn't need to change if it doesn't want to.  But, as a hot dog lover I would so appreciate having more available from this iconic never-franchised food classic.

"It was the best of times. It was the worst of times."  - Charles Dickens, Tale of Two Cities. 

With apologies to the master, my experience at Empire Szechuan resembles that opening line in the classic novel; in reverse.

We were just looking for a decent meal after excellent foot massage down Bustleton at Lavender Foot Spa.  I saw the sign and was curious without checking Yelp first.  Spontaneity can lead to wonderful discovery, or just bust your balls.  This was a strange hybrid of both. 

Walking in, we quickly realized this was primarily a take out joint.  Two tables out front, with one occupied by the owner's sons playing computer games.  It was also chilly inside with everyone wearing jackets to keep the electric bill down.  I love Szechuanese cuisine and hoped the name on the sign reflected the product in the kitchen, when so many others simply do not.  

We ordered at the counter. Apple ordering and pay system.  Reading the menu, it was obvious there was precious little Chengdu kitchen here.  Still, we agreed to ride it out and see what happened.  Orange Beef, Eggplant in Garlic Sauce, and Steamed Dumplings, were our desire.  We sat at the sole open table to wait, and hoped for the hot tea to warm us.  

It arrived in a quart sized plastic soup container, with tea bags inside.  No teapot. No ceramic teacups.  Just styro cups. Free pour by bending the rim into a spout. Really?!  Before we could pour the tea,  our place settings were brought out.  Styro plates and skimpy plastic forks, with those take out packets of duck sauce, soy and mustard thrown on top.  

Feeling so appreciated right there!  

We poured the cha and waited for the next act to unfold.  This was either going to be a disaster, or outright conflagration, if their slovenliness continued.  We scored a pair of chopsticks, which were much sturdier than the malformed forks.

Then the moon broke through the brooding clouds.  

The Eggplant dish arrived first.  It was a large amount of the veggie, with other colorful edibles mixed in.  This was way more than could fit in a Chinese take out box, and it glistened from the oily sauce that held it together.  We opened the rice box to shovel some on the plates as our base for eating, and sticked a few pieces of the purple nightshade on top.  We were guarded lest the load prove inedible.  

We looked at each other in astonishment as the taste registered in our pleasure centered brains.  It was excellent!  Soft eggplant.  Appropriately cooked secondaries. Wonderful garlic sauce that was just prepared for our meal.  Yes. It was rather incongruous after the inauspicious start to the dinner, but one we gladly welcomed.  

The Orange Beef arrived moments later.  Another huge pile of food, this time, dark brown spicy gloop on top of a motherload of nicely sliced beef, that had been wokked and rolled in a light batter and deep fried before returning to the stove for the final pouring of the Tso-like sauce.  

Munch. Chew. Blooming, mouth expanding flavor of orange and chili, that had my eyes open wide in silent exclamation.  What the hey?!  This was even better than the eggplant.  The meat seemed fresh; not frozen, and again the sauce was prepared just for us.  It tasted as good as almost any orange beef I had ever eaten.  We agreed that we were enjoying an exceptional Chinese American meal, especially given the dive we were in, and the way the story began.

Quite frankly, we were blown away.

Maybe the secret of this place is to overlook the distain of the sons, and the stain of the environment, and just hunker down in the winter heatlessness of the house, knowing something those who only do take out and delivery never discover - that the food at Empire Szechuan is a slam bang winner for those who sit there and wait to eat right out of the wok. By the time it arrives to your home, the magic has disappeared.  Astounding! 

We packed up the leftovers in anticipation of a second round of slammin' Chinois, suspecting it would not be anything like what we had just devoured.  We paid the twenty bucks or so, and walked out into the night slightly inebriated from this rags to riches saga.

PS. The dumplings sucked (not XLB), but we forgave them after this profane/sacred epiphany.

I love the name, "Wild Ginger."  It evokes images of spicy jungles with Jaguar eyes and Elephant tusks lurking in the deep canopy forests of northern Thailand.  

This version of the two shop restaurant empire is not quite as wild as the name suggests, but does have its positive moments.  The Jamison store has dark red walls with black cut out images of exotic Asian women and the Eiffel Tower.  On a hot day it instantly cools the visitor with its permanent shade.  

The menu works especially well at lunch, where the offerings on the Thai side are based on the main ingredient you chose - Tofu, Veggies, Chicken, Beef or Shrimp and range from $8 to $9 for the style you select.  I almost ordered the Pad Thai, but allowed myself to listen to my server telling me the Cashew Thai Style was just as good.  She was very pleasant, and she convinced me to try the nut approach.  

First came the Tom Yam Soup, which was nicely spiced and steaming.  It was what I expected that soup to be.  Tart and sinus rattling. Nice. The main dish was very attractive with fresh Veggies (Pepper, Onion, Scallion, Carrot, Baby Corn, Cashews), and a light brown glazy sauce that made everything shine.  Looked great.  The taste was were the letdown occurred. While the menu described a mild sweetness, to my buds, there was little if any flavor. Freshness and quantity were not issues, but I truly wanted something bolder in line with my Thai-spectations.  Rather than ask for more sauce or something sweeter to add to the plate, I went the other way and asked for Sesame Oil and Chili Sauce to bring up the flames.  

After dumping the small dish of spice and oil into it and mixing thoroughly, the flavor was much improved, and I enjoyed the meal the rest of the way.  It still wasn't authentically Thai, but it was reasonably good. 

Turned out that Wild Ginger (II) was a "fusion" or hybrid kitchen, owned by someone other than Thais or Japanese.  Such 'con-fusion' houses usually don't work well as the concept doesn't exist in the "wild" of southeast Asia, and relies on the theory that no one here will recognize that this concoction approach lacks roots in any indigenous culture.  

Wild Ginger gamely tries to offer a valid alternative, and the dishes are okay for what they are.  It's just that they fall short of being fully satisfying because of what they are not.

First visit to a Quick Chek anywhere, and I was surprised how large this one was. It easily reminds of a rest stop along a turnpike or a Sheetz station anywhere in Pa. 

They prepare hot dishes on request and have a long wall full of refrigeration units stocked with every American soft drink imaginable.  

The coffee selection is broader than most 7/11s, and the adjoining snack section will remind you to take your insulin.  

Fairly clean as such places go.  Good pricing, too. 

I will stop into this and other Quick Cheks when the situation allows.

Stopped in for an early lunch today at Xi'an Sizzling Woks, one of the three XSW sister shops in Philly.  
They are known for this Biang Biang noodles and semi-spicy dishes.  Their sauces are excellent for sticking to the mein, and when you get the hand drawn pasta from their kitchen, you are in for a good time. 

Two of us ordered the same thing (unusual for us); the cumin beef with noodles.  This was a single serving in a medium bowl.  It arrived with unseen noodles at the bottom of a pile of small strips of braised beef, green pepper and onion in a cumin based light sauce on top. Gentle mixing was required.  The noodles were not handmade, but a decent store bought variety.  The beef was tender with ample cumin powder and a little crushed cumin flakes, making for good flavor and a filling meal. 

The third dish was a pita soaked lamb noodle soup, which I am told is a extra specialty of Shaanxi Province.  At $16 it should have been, but my spoonful did not impress my palette, despite the dent in the wallet. However, the one who ordered it seemed very pleased, so what do I know?! 

Service was friendly and water/tea refills prompt.  It always helps to have Mandarin speakers in the party to get a little extra TLC from staff.  I'm not above taking advantage of that benefit.

This house is much larger than the shop on Race Street, but it also lacks the forced intimacy of sitting at tables placed on top of each other.  To each his own, but I remember Chinatown's version being somewhat better in kitchen quality and cultural (crowded) authenticity.

Yummy Sushi has moved to newer digs just off the College of New Jersey campus, but their food hasn't changed along with it. 

It had been a few years since last visit because I found everything I tried from pho to sushi rolls was average at best. Today I ordered their teriyaki salmon bento box, and must report that nothing has changed. The rolls are still on the thick side with far more rice wrap than contents. Made for an adequate chew, but lacking in much taste beyond the soy/wasabe/ginger additive. It was nice to see they were using white ginger. 

If all the iceberg and cabbage were removed, there really wasn't much to the meal. Two small shumai, 2x4  grilled salmon with decent teriyaki BBQ sauce, and the six roll segments. Not complaining about the $12.95 tag, but a little more real food would have made for a better value. 

Yummy is still a family place with Granny sitting in the corner and now teenage kids in the opposite corner yakking while serving customers. No problem with service otherwise. 

There are still better choices nearby if higher quality dishes are your priority.

TAKE OUT REVIEW 

I was looking forwarded to sampling the kitchen of Saigon Café, especially for a bowl of their bun bo hue and a bahn mi sandwich, but I failed to note that their hours were from 7 am to 6 pm. When I walked in at 6:55 pm, I was advised that the kitchen was closed and the doors would be locked in 5 minutes. My bad. 

Luckily, one of the women working the counter took pity on me and offered to make a bahn mi for me to take out, as she had all the ingredients available, and nothing needed to be heated.  I could work with that. I thanked her and ordered a roast pork bahn mi with all the trimmings. I watched as she and a cohort put it together, wrapped it up, bagged it, and handed it over - all for $4. Couldn't beat the price.

I realized as I stood there that Pho 75 was right next door and I could bring my sandwich there and have it with a bowl of their excellent pho. That's exactly what I did. The guys there acted like they had seen this before and were fine with me spreading out my meal with some solids. 

The beef noodle soup was awesome as always, and having the sandwich to eat with it made for a very nice meal. 

The banh mi was very good, with plenty of daikon, carrot, tender pork and leafy cilantro. The only weakness was the roll itself, which lacked the crispness of a French style baguette, but was soft and too pliant. I guess at the end of the day, the bread had been around awhile and lost its crispy edge. 

Aside from that I was satisfied, and plan to return to Saigon Café earlier next time so I can enjoy their menu more completely.

Dacey's Pub (aka Dacey's Irish Pub) is a fascinating place.  The location is right out of a Kafka novel.  The railroad tracks across the street are a massive wall of gray trap rock and high fences.  Not a blade of grass grows, nor tree casts a shadow.  Viewing that while walking to the entrance can be oppressive and other worldly.  

Yet, once inside I was enveloped in a dark mystique of long bar, high top tables, and rear kitchen window.  The rows of silently glistening bottles offer respite from the harsh glare outside. I slid onto a stool at the bar to await service and allowed the aura of the place to settle on me.  Felt good.  There's something going on at Dacey's, and I would figure it out. 

The bartender came up to take my drink order and hand over a menu.  First timer, I needed a few minutes to reconnoiter the offerings. This was lunch so Redd's would have to do.  The special of the day was Guinness Fish and Chips @ $6.95.  Although I considered a burger, I was intrigued by what was "Guinness" about the meal.  Turns out, not much.  The basket was delivered with a nice load of chips (fries) and two frozen to deep fry breaded fish fillets, and a choice of tartar sauce and/or malt vinegar. I took both, as I sort of like my chips with tartar sauce over ketchup.  It did not seem that the fish had been dipped in Guinness before frying, which had been my expectation.  They were okay, but not more.  The chips were actually a bit dry.  So, I would not order that again. 

Yet, the dudes at the table close by had saddled up to huge burgers and pints of suds, and were elbow deep in their meals and conversation.  That was the way to go, and will certainly be the next approach for me.  I felt like starting over and joining these guys, but thought better of it considering the time.  

Walking back into the sunlight the prison escarpment across the road again stood a menacing presence.  I realized that Dacey's was the sentinel protecting the rest of us from whatever evils lurked behind that barbed wire, and the patrons and staff the soldiers on the wall.

Willow Grove Park Mall is not where I normally shop, but sometimes a little diversion pays unexpected dividends.  Generally, I find the latest incarnation of Macy's to be a shoppers hunting ground.  There are always sales, coupons, and additional discounts on lots of the merchandise, so at least in the clothing departments, it is possible to find quality pieces at surprisingly good prices.  

This Macy's is laid out as the others in Oxford Valley or Quaker Bridge, but on this Saturday late morning/early afternoon, there were many fewer customers, and salespeople. Not sure what the story was, but I found what I needed, tried things on without interference from staff, and only found slight delay at cashiering on the way out.  It was almost like they were using an honor system.  Pick out what you want.  Try it on. Leave what you don't want. Pay for what you do.  Interact with Macy's only when you draw your credit card.  We trust you. 

Saved about 60% off the original price, and left a happy man.

The mural on the wall shows the Sphinx and pyramids along the Nile in Egypt.  Then I heard one of the men behind the counter speaking something that sounded like Arabic. I realized I was in my first Egyptian pizza shop.  Why not?!

They certainly have a huge display of pies under glass for people to choose from.  Buffalo Shrimp, BBQ Beef, Cheesesteak, Chicken Parm, in addition to regular and mushroom standard oldies, to name but a few.  Their lunch deal is two slices and a large soft drink for $7.  I've seen that offer around town for less, but when you get the actual slices in front of you, and pick them up, it is obvious that the weight of each piece is equal to two in those other joints', so in fact you are getting half a pie for that price.  For those who value weight and max load for lunch, this is the place for you.  

A traditionalist when it comes to tomato pie, I went for a slice of regular and mushroom.  The crust was thick and supportive of the topside.  With the first bite I knew that I had ordered far too much.  There was a thick layer of cheese atop the substantial base, which was more substance than I enjoy on pizza.  The flavor of the tomato sauce was drowned by the cheese, making for more of an open face grilled cheese experience, rather than a true pizza chew.  Fine if you like cheesy cheese pie, but not exactly what I was hoping for. I prefer a lighter experience where all the elements are apparent, and the topping an accent to the main attraction, as opposed to dominating it.  

I knew I couldn't finish these heavyweights, so by command decision I ate half of each and left the balance behind.  Didn't feel called to take them home.  

If you enjoy heavy pie, Purple Pizza is calling your name.  They certainly have a large selection of flavors. However, if you are more inclined to a lighter bite, and like a thinner crust and balanced top load, you may have to look elsewhere. 

They also do fried chicken according to the sign out front, but I didn't get to try any on this visit.

Huang's Garden is really a misnomer. 

It may be Huang's, but it surely isn't a garden.  

This Chinese house sits on the southern end of Farnsworth Avenue in Bordentown, NJ.  Where most of this main street has come to life in the past decade and now is attractive for strolling, eating and comfortable happy hours, this place is a throwback to when B'town was more or less a dump you wouldn't consider visiting unless you lived nearby.  

My beginnings were not auspicious, as I parked at the front door, and immediately behind a exterminator's truck.  I asked the driver if he was about the treat the restaurant, or was coming in for lunch.  He appreciated my concern, and replied he was only doing an inspection as part of an ongoing service contract.  Glad they were on top of that. 

I came in and sat down at one of 2 booths and 2 tables in the front end.  The space was cluttered and populated by three generations of the family running the operation.  Grandma and grandpa sat at a round table in front of an HDTV watching a Chinese station, while mom and dad worked the kitchen, and granddaughter came in and out doing what 10 year olds do.  

I was sitting in their living room.  Gratitude for the invitation.  

The menu was state of the art for 1990.  All the usual dishes.  So, I asked for the Sesame Chicken lunch special and a bowl of Wonton Soup for an extra 4 bits.  Let's see what was delivered.

The Wonton Soup was surprisingly good!  The 3 dumplings had a thin coat, and the ground Pork within was tasty.  The broth was unusual because it had a mild lemony flavor, which at first stopped me mid-chew, but ultimately was interesting and enjoyable.  Cool.  

The Sesame Chicken was plentiful dark meat chicken that was textured as if it had not been frozen, with a very dark brown sauce that was not as gloopy as expected and nicely piquant.  Again, above average for the standard Sino American plate.  Finally, the Fried Rice while suspiciously uberdark brown, was full of chunkies, and tasted pretty good.  

While I wouldn't make the trip to this tail end of Bordentown's main drag again for this, I was pleasantly surprised that the cuisine emanating from the kitchen was far better than the dining room atmospherics suggested.  

Grandma was a gracious hostess and server as her hubby napped peacefully.  I left satisfied and appreciative of being adopted by this lovely family.

This was my second visit to a Panda Express, and true to it's corporate nature, it was consistent with my first experience. That is both a good thing and a bad thing.

Let's start with the positives. The facility was clean and bright, and constantly being mopped and wiped while I was there. They keep staff busy in visible ways. The service was friendly and expedient, if formulaic. I was offered a sample of a special chicken dish on a toothpick. Can't remember the taste, nor the name. 

I ordered the two mains, one side option for $7.95. Veggie Lo Mein, Gung Pao Chicken, and Beijing Beef we're loaded onto my styro dish, which was place on to a plastic tray before being handed over.  I took a pass on their sweet waters. 

All three were luke warm and past their prime. The taste was good, with strong spiciness on the gung pao, and crispy tangy sweetness on the beef, even though the latter's sauce was overly goopified from hanging around for a while. Really no better or worse than the versions found in traditional Chinese American shops, just not as hot. The noodles we're becoming al dente, but not beyond the pale. 

Given a choice I would normally opt for the local momasan papasan joint over corporate mass produced dishes, but it is safe to say that the Panda is a reasonable alternative, especially if you come when the offerings are right out of the wok.  Even when approaching their sell by date, the taste is okay even if texture and temperature are not quite right.

My second visit to any Quick Chek, and I admit that their approach to Convenience Store is a nice upgrade over the traditional view of the genre.  

They offer hot and cold customized food, an array of coffee and snack options, and a spacious floor plan that encourages you to walk around and check it out.  Too, the staff in both places I have visited is friendly and courteous to a very noticeable degree.  

These places remind of modern rest stops found along the highways and byways of America.  Finding them on the streets of our cities is a bit of an amazement. 

A very enjoyable one.

My first time to Indian Garden, a destination hidden in the shopping center on Stony Hill Road in Lower Makefield (we all know it is not really Yardley).  It is catercorner from the Giant Supermarket, and next door to Vesuvio Pizza. 
Walking in the first impression is that the space is darkly lit, and in combination with the aroma of curry, cardamon, and other spices, feels a little like entering a bazaar on the subcontinent.  As the eyes adjust, white table clothes appear on small square and large round tables reflecting the dim recessed lighting and the illumination over the buffet tables. They are a little close together, requiring a bob and weave to access the back tables. Still, very engaging way to start the experience.  The staff in black and white with ties is super efficient and helpful. 
I went with the buffet to be able to sample more than would be possible ordering off the menu, although another reviewer warned off doing this.  I tried : Vegetable Pakora (not hot enough, and thus a little oily), Chicken Tikka Masala (very good), Chicken Kadai (good and smokey flavored), Chicken Makhani (nice creamy tomato/ginger sauce), Vegetable Korma (was that frozen veggies in a good Korma?), Chana Saag (very enjoyable), Aloo Bhartha (love eggplant in all incarnations), Paneer Makhani (the cheese reminds of tofu, but decent), Naan (quite good, but wanted garlic), Mango Lassi (excellent), and mango pudding (really?). Ok. I won't have dinner tonight. 
Total Cost: $12.50
