Given the almost total absence of Indian food in the immediate area, Indian Garden is very good, and worth another trip.  Next time, I will order off the menu and see what shakes out.  Upgrades are definitely possible once the larger menu is penetrated and surrenders its secrets.

9.28.13 - Returned for another lunch buffet today with a few campaign people. The floor was not crowded when we arrived, but slowly filled after 1:00.  I think I was placed at the same table as my first visit. I love when that happens. Kismet. The food was as good as last time, and the Naan changed from Regular to Onion while we were there, and added to the sop up enjoyment of all the rich sauces mixing on the plate.  I was a bit distracted with conversation so did not commit to memory what I ate, but I thoroughly enjoyed the mix of flavors, textures, and basics. 
3 Stars with a Bullet.  This place is going to move up soon.

11.11.16 UPDATE - Sometimes the best intentions to return to a restaurant soon to followup on good early impressions are swallowed by life taking you elsewhere. So it was with Indian Garden. Job changes, new food outlets, or just plain forgetfulness, play a hand. Still, I finally came back here last Friday night with family when we decided we hungered for local spice. 

We were seated promptly without reservations at 6 by the smiling hostess. The large dining room was half empty on arrival, but filled quickly with some recognizable faces. Just beat the rush. 

The three of us ordered Veggie Samosa and Chili Pakora apps. Both good, but the Pakora had a too thick fried coating over the pepper and filling. Reminded of a Relleno, but not as smoothly integrated. The Chicken Curry was fresh with a nice red mild heat. Our Lamb Korma had grilled baa-baa pieces in a smooth and almond sweet beige sauce, that was the star of the show. The third dish was a potato and eggplant combo with chunkiness and light spice finish without a pond around it. Their Basket of Naan completed our table. 

Everything was solid, if not exceptional, with a tendency to underspice all their dishes, perhaps in tune with the palates of their clientele. Not a criticism, but an adjustment to reality. Yet, if a stronger  South Asian taste is what you seek, just ask for max heat, or try the local alternatives (Guru, Dream Spicy), where there is less accommodation to neighborhood preference for dilution. 

Still, the quality of the meal was undeniable. A little fine tuning will achieve the heat quotient desired. Indian Garden is fan worthy.

Yummy Sushi sits in an unconventional food court - a mid-sized strip center surrounded by Chinese, Pizzeria, Bagel joint, Hungarian, Italian and Sports Bar restaurants.  You can walk to all of them in under five minutes.  Very convenient if you have a diverse group that can't decide what to eat.  

Although Yummy is ostensibly a raw fish house, I came strictly for the Pho, the Vietnamese Noodle Soup that is known as a wonderful comfort food.  And, it was so here.  The broth was rich and complex with the right spices and time spent simmering to unleash the subtle undertones.  The nest of rice noodles at the bottom of the large bowl was difficult to corral as they were very long and did not drop easily into the flat bottomed spoon.  

They offer only one form of Pho here - Flank Steak and Meatballs. The Steak arrived medium/rare and continued to reach medium from the heat of the soup.  The Meatballs were sliced, but very dense, reminding me that "meatball" doesn't always mean Italian. The bowl already contained Sprouts and Basil Leaves when it landed on my table.  Only the Lime and Jalapeno slices were on the side.  Hoisin Sauce and Sriracha were delivered, but there was no dish to squirt them into.  I used the one the lime and jalapeno came in, and dipped the meat into both before eating.  

I did also try the Fried Wontons (described as Pork Dumplings in the menu).  They were not very good, as they were over deep fried and had a burnt taste. The Duck Sauce that came with them was watery and lacking in flavor.  

The Mama-san was very cordial to all the customers, although she spent a lot of time with those she knew best.  Her children were present, but did not disturb anyone.

What the heck is a Chalupa? 
In Mexico it is a small boat or a food creation in Oaxaca and Puebla that molds masa dough (base ingredient of a tortilla) into the shape of a concave container, filled with pork, chicken, beef, peppers, onion and salsa, before deep frying. It looks like a cup or skiff, rather than a enlarged taco. 
What I ordered at this Taco Bell arrived at my table looking much more like the big soft taco, than the smaller corn cup described on Wikipedia. So, the name is assumed via poetic license, and not the actual dish it is South of the Border. 
Despite this misappropriated name, this version of a Chapula was still tasty and filling. I had the chicken filling, and found the package enjoyable to eat, if not the most authentic tasting Mexican food in the world. Really lacked serious spice quotient. The lunch special offered two of these babies, plus a soft ground beef taco thrown in for good measure. It was all far too much to eat in one sitting, unless gaining weight was a priority. I left half the second Chalupa and three quarters of the taco on the tray when I departed. 

With all the excellent real Central American houses around these days, it is difficult to be excited by Taco Bell, which is a mere shadow of  good Mexican or Salvadoran food. Prices are low, but so is the dining experience. 
 
Okay if hungry in the desert, but not close to what you can get if you really want the real deal.

A Happy Family is both the name of this Chinese/American shop and a description of the people who own and operate it. 

I met both spouses during my lunch there yesterday.  The mister took my order and chatted with me, and the misses served my plate of egg foo young, egg roll and fried rice, with a smile and gratitude.  They have been in this location just off Brunswick Circle in Trenton, NJ for a few years, and seem to be making of go of it.  

The store is long and narrow, with a small dining room in front, two middle rooms that appear to be used by the family, and a rear kitchen.  There is some distance between front and back, and they installed a bell for customers to use to catch their attention.  I used it to get them to come out and accept my payment.  

The lunch was about par for the course in the metro area.  All the owners must have gone to the same restaurant school, because most of the wonton houses have identical menus, and tastes.  A Happy Family is no different, except that they deserve credit for making their fried rice without soup bouillon with dye to color the rice.  This pile of grain looked natural, and was nicely chunky.  The pancakes were full of veggies, wok fried, with a plastic cup of brown sauce on the side.  It was decent.  The egg roll was mostly cabbage with a few slivers of pork, but I didn't expect anything more.  

They have a confusing menu because of the similarity of the lunch specials, and combo offerings.  Not clear what the differences are, except one costs less than $6, while the other comes in at $7.50.  Not a big deal either way, but I like to know what I am looking at when ordering. 

A Happy Family is worth a visit if Chinois Americain is something you like. Your visit will do a lot to keep these folks pleased.

Home Place Restaurant sits in a rather forlorn older strip center on Bristol Road in Bensalem, PA.  This is the latest in a line of restaurants that have made a run at a successful kitchen at this location. It shares the strip with a Wawa, which offers indirect competition for coffee and breakfast sandwiches with its neighbor. 

The house is pretty large with several dozen tables, a high display with desserts, and two HDTVs on the wall.  The furnishings are new utilitarian, but there is a dark carpet on the floor which is never a sanitary solution compared to a hard surface that can be swept, mopped and vacuumed clean. Service was friendly and attentive.  My small coffee mug was refilled twice without need to ask. Breakfast menu is larger than many restaurants, and although Home Place is not a traditional diner, and lacks a counter service, it did have a broad breakfast list with morning specials at very low prices. 

I opted for their Greek omelet with special request to put the home fries inside, rather than on the plate.  That always adds substance to the eggs and allows the potatoes to integrate with the rest of the ingredients. Tastes better to me. The plate arrived ten minutes later looking quite good. The three eggs had been mixed with the feta cheese, onion, pepper and spuds, rather than left as a shell.  I prefer this approach, although it was no longer a true omelet. It was pretty good, but needed more than a shake of black pepper and salt to bring up the flavor. The feta, while salty, was not in sufficient abundance to offset the need for sodium chloride. The rye toast was lightly buttered and a good complement to the eggs. The coffee was strong and hot.

No serious complaints about Home Place. It was pretty much a decent breakfast, but lacking any WOW factor. The location and clientele do not permit prices necessary to do things to make the space and offerings more attractive and intriguing, yet does provide a substantial meal which should not be disregarded.

Hard Rock Café is an icon of the 20th Century.  It does feel dated and retro in the 21st. 

I hadn't been in Philly's franchise for about twenty years, and it felt and looked the same as I remembered.  Guitars on the walls, TVs everywhere the guitars weren't.  A gift shop that remains the heart and soul of the establishment.  Overpriced? Check. Gitchy? Check. Mediocre food? Check. 

My friends from Copenhagen really wanted to go so they could collect another Hard Rock T shirt. I remembered that their burgers were 'the thing.'  We went it to buy what they wanted first, and then grabbed a table for lunch.  The staff was professionally friendly.  The menu as expected. 

$14 for a Legend Burger and $3.50 for a Lemonade (no refill offered) were strictly based on what they could charge, not on quality, but I guess you have to pay for the atmosphere.  The Burger was right on Medium, but crumbled when cut due to freezing.  It wasn't bad, but they would have done better hiring a crew from Five Guys to handle this chore. The Onion Ring on top was over-fried, as was everything on the Appetizer Mix Platter. The Wings were not good, the Chicken Fingers were dry and tasted of yesterday's oil. I stayed away from the Spinach Dip. 

My friends are not foodies, and had no issue with the scene and grub.  This is what they were here to do.

Who was I to rain on their parade?

The Dining Car is an old style stainless steel diner on Frankford Avenue, Northeast Philadelphia. It has a small private parking lot behind the structure, with much more space available in the Mealey Furniture lot next door. There is a dining room as well as a large counter for folks like me who are eating alone and enjoy watching their employees as they work. 

The staff is friendly and efficient. I had menu in hand and a mugga joe before me within a minute of sitting down. Traditional diner fare, with a few things for which they are noted - chicken croquettes and Jewish apple cake - among them. It even had a moment of fame when it was the subject of Guy Fieri's Diners, Drive-Ins and Dives show on the Food Channel. Of course, Guy is all about spiked hair showmanship and excessive exuberance, and not necessarily honest assessment of the food he is mugging for. Here, his enjoyment was legitimately entertained by the urban nature of this part of town having its own stainless palace, but also likely uninformed by the other Philly Special joints in the same neighborhood that far outshine The Dining Car (The Clown House, for example). 

I was there for a French Toast breakfast, although I was tempted to see what the fuss was all about with the apple cake. Doubt it was better than grandma's. 

Still, I enjoyed my morning repast, even if not outstanding. Two slices of decent white loaf seemed a bit light if it wasn't a short stack. Although advertised with "maple syrup," I'm fairly certain that the sticky sweet colloidal liquid pouring out of the container on the counter was not from a maple tree. Tasted a lot more like a generic Mrs. Buttersworth. Still sweet. Still a decent companion to the fry bread. Just not Grade B Dark. The coffee was strong, hot and free flowing from the Bunn brewer. 

The place was humming on Thursday morning. A definite community gathering spot.

Not a bad place to stop for a cuppa joe on the way into Mt. Holly.  

It's clean and the service is good.  Only 6 tables for those who want to hang for a few.  Definitely built for get and go, but lacking a drive thru window.  

The seasonal Pumpkin Donut wasn't bad, either.

Not a bad place for a pie, but my experience with their Eggplant Parm Sandwich left something to be desired. 

The slices of this nightshade were thick and not quite sautéed through and through, leaving parts of the meal somewhat harder than expected.  Too, they seem to have only been in the pan once after breading, rather than twice, before and after breadcrumbs were added.  When heated twice in hot olive oil the veggie is much softer and takes on the taste of the surrounding ingredients better.  No complaint with the gravy, cheese, nor roll. However, I would not order this again. 

Nick's has the feel of a slice and cheesesteak joint.  It is small, but nicely appointed in a low key way.  The staff is fine, and anyone who has hands free behind the counter will bring out the platter when it is ready.  

Lipton products, meaning that high corn fructose is a prime part of every bottle.  Not so good for health.  An upgrade in the drink cooler would be a big plus.

This Wendy's in the corner of Morrisville Plaza was renovated a few years ago, and has a nice look and feel.  It is a smaller shop, with minimalist décor, but clean and highly functional.  The hours are from 11:00 am to 2:00 am, although the hours presently on Yelp incorrectly state it closes at two in the afternoon.  

It has a wrap around take out lane that requires drivers and pedestrians to be careful approaching the front door.  Very easy to ignore the vehicles coming from the left, or walkers in front of you while stowing a bag of nosh.  Service is fine at the counter. 

There is no doubt that Wendy is attempting to up its game in order to compete with the fast casual burger crowd.  Most ingredients are fresh, and the new basic roll is an order of magnitude better than the old one.  It holds together throughout eating, and has a pleasant flavor.  The only remaining issue is the quality of the beef patty.  Its taste and texture appear the same as the old version, which is to say that it is somewhat mealy (frozen), and lacking any real verve in taste, and juiciness.  It still seems flat and uninspired.  

So, the key to enjoyment is keeping the package together while consuming, with the fresh onion, lettuce and cheese can dominate the experience.  As a whole, the burger is just okay, although an improvement over its predecessor, it has a long road to travel until it can stand next to its cousins at Red Robin, Cheeburger, or even your local corner tavern.

Tre Fratelli was the first meal I had when moving to Bucks County many years ago.  It was decent then, and remains decent now.  The pizza, cheesesteaks, sandwiches and pasta are the way to go here.  The dinners are a step down from memorable, and not able to generate a strong desire to return for more.  

Two of us had the Chicken Parm dinner, and our third, the Marsala.  The Parm's chicken breasts were large and cooked to the right point of nicely retained juiciness, but the Red Sauce was heavy and covered the entire bird so not even a pan fried edge could be seen for visual cuing. The Mozza melt was similarly overdone; making the plate about its toppings rather than complimenting the chicken.  The Marsala was overcooked and left less than tender medallions adrift in a dense brown wine redux that should have been lighter and more subtle.  Both dishes were edible, but less that we hoped.  

The surprising upside were the sides that came with the meal.  Each of the three we ordered; the French Fries, Penne Oglio Olio, and Veggies arrived in large, family dinner sizes, and were totally enjoyable.  The taters were hot and crunchy, the veggies bright and lightly tossed with Olive Oil and Garlic, and the pasta, loaded with razor-thin Garlic Slices browned to gold like copper leaves in a mound of snow.  Al Dente and more fun to eat than the mains.  

It happens that way sometimes.  Stick with the basics.

Sitting back off Bethlehem Pike a block from the top of Chestnut Hill @ Germantown Avenue, Thai Kuu is a small attractive Asian dining room. Buddhas and elephants adorn the walls and menus giving a serene atmosphere that augurs well for the meal to come. This establishment offers weekend lunch at a reasonable price, and I was there to check it out. Many similar houses eliminate the midday meal discount on weekends, and I appreciated that this one kept it in play. 

I saw what I wanted and ordered Tom Ka Soup and Spicy Pad Kee Mao (aka Drunken Noodles). Service was provided by a gentleman I took to be an owner/manager. While efficient and cool, he also had an officiousness that was subtly off-putting. Maybe he objected to my black hoodie or my dining solo, but I wasn't going to allow his silent judgment interfere with my enjoyment. The food, on the other hand, could impact my take on the experience. At the end of my meal, that opinion was less than my first impressions. 

The Tom Ka was pretty good with strong coconut flavor, a hint of lemongrass and fair amount of string bean, carrot, mushroom and broccoli. I lifted the square bowl to my lips to suck it all in. I anticipated the Pad Kee Mao would be hot and spicy from a chili pepper base sauce, and from the word "spicy" in the name on the menu. Not the case. 

Instead, the word was used to label the sweetness of the middle width noodles and brown sauce, not its heat. An exceedingly small portion, its lack of traditional burn was disappointing; pointing to the conclusion that Thai Kuu was far more an Asian fusion kitchen than anything close to vibrant Siam fire. 

It was all okay, but could have been so much more had they the courage of their culinary convictions.

Housed in the Riverfront Market on old Orange Street, Wilmington, La Taqueria is a food stall serving assembly line Mexican street food a la Qdoba or Chipotle. By the time I arrived around 4, most of the other shops were closed and the rest were cleaning up and getting ready to head home at the 6 PM closing time. In fact, I was the only customer in the house. I had the warehouse to myself. 

I ordered their tacos carnitas with pinto beans and brown rice. I watched as the friendly preparer put my snack together, asking me to choose from each of the ingredient options as she moved down the steam table. She ended with the type of finishing sauce I wanted squirted on top. I went with the most spicy chipotle/chili pepper. 

The tacos were good, if a bit drippy. The pork was tender and moist, and the overall big bite was tasty and filling. The rice and beans may have been on the steam table all day, so were past their prime - a bit dried out. Still, I was dining alone and had time to look around and appreciate the historic structure surrounding me. More on that in another review.

While I appreciate the difference between Joe Santucci's rectangular upside down pizza with mozzarella cheese baked under the dark red sauce, and traditional east coast round pies that put the cheese on top, I can't say that after picking it up to bring home that it is significantly better. I did like the somewhat thicker crust and pasty thick tomato sauce, but not more than the quality "Jersey" style pizza from joints like DeLorenzo's in Lower Makefield, or the Burg in Falls, to name a few others. 

I guess being suckled on Brooklyn and Trenton slices spoiled me for other conceptions. I just like the thinner crusted, basil flavored, chunky tomato sauced, creations, with the secrets of the dough mixed with softer water that flavors the crust with subtle cracker-like tones and texture. 

To my buds, the Trenton Pie is perfection, far superior to the upside down variation Philly is famous for. It's not that I don't enjoy this style once in a while, but given the choice, the ones from Trenton win every time.

Solid 3.5 Star breakfast & lunch deli in the Glen Roc Shopping Center on Scotch Road in Ewing, NJ.  

Décor is minimalist, with a few tables near the counter and kitchen and a second dining room to the right with ten more tables when the crowd arrives. The joint is clean and the service is friendly and efficient. Ordering is done at the cashier, and one of the staff brings the food to the table. There seems to be a group of regular alder cockers hanging out, but they are amusing and harmless. 

My breakfast sausage, egg & cheese sandwich arrived with a small container of orange juice, a nice unexpected touch. The roll was better than average with a fresh firm crust and flakey innards. It was a good sammy with oozing American cheese and fried egg.  I would certainly have it again if nearby in the morning. The coffee was hot and middle of the road in strength. 

Price was under $6 for food and beverage; a very attractive price.  

If Deli-Licious Café had a bit more character and comfort, it could easily garner the fourth star.

Anthony's Pizza Town (& Cantina), has been at the same location on northbound Rt. 130 for a long time, and the passage of time has not been overly kind. The place looks like it did in 1990, with the same wall decorations and the same Anthony in his suave hat tossing dough and making conversation.  If you love Elvis and think he and Marilyn are the apex of American culture, this is your place. 

The world may have changed, but the Anthony's pizza remains the same.  It is still crisp, with mildly sweet sauce, and a hint of garlic.  It is no longer at the top of the pizza food chain given the evolution of tomato pie over the decades, but it is still a solid and tasty option.  It just isn't the first place you think of when considering where to get your pizza fix.  In this part of the universe, Palermo's has that weighty distinction.  

Pizza Town is now a Cash Only operation, although my memory tells me that this was not always the case.  It remains a place where you can have a beer with your pie, or even a brew without the slices.  

The sign out front claims this is also a "cantina."  I didn't examine the menu closely, but offering a Mexi/Guat/Hondoran alternative along with the pizza, is a darn good idea!  It's already being done well by Castillo's on Clinton Avenue in C'Burg.

REHEATED SLICE COVID TAKEOUT REVIEW:

The constant problem with ordering pizza by the slice is that they require sufficient reheating in the oven to resuscitate it into edible condition. If not requested to be "well done," they are only partially revived, while the rest tastes dead or just lacking in energy. 

The same is true here. Without knowing how long it had been sitting on the cooling rack, nor the heat of the oven, the time spent could have been enough to scorch the undercarriage and bubble up the cheese, but it didn't quite make it all the way back to life. As a result it was a mediocre slice. Decent crust, almost right sauce needing more basil, and thick cheese deposit in the center that wasn't quite the volcanic lava desired. 

Not bad for noshing in the car on the way back to Bucks, but not the Jersey Strong hoped for. 

Oh, and the shop really needs a deep cleaning. Where's the TLC?

TAKEOUT REVIEW

Can't speak to the cuisine served in the spacious but dark dining rooms, but the takeout seems like a separate operation going out the back door of Cena Ristorante in Bensalem, PA. 

When I entered the front door, a server informed me that I should walk through the restaurant to the rear entrance to the patio, turn right, and go into the other door which was propped open. Once there I saw a counter with kitchen equipment behind it, and a couple dudes aproned up for food service. My personal sized pizza and cheese steak hoagie were already boxed and ready to head out the door. 

Maybe using this Slice app would be acceptable. At least the food was ready as advertised. 

Upon opening at the kitchen table, I beheld a 12" pie with heavy cheese, and lighter puddles of red sauce, mozza droppings and a scattering of green basil leaf. Looked sort of like a child's drawing of a clown face. The cheese steak hoagie was more handsome, with goodly amount of thin grilled beef mixed with cheese (provolone?), topped with lettuce, tomato and red onion. Liked it.

Taste was uneven. The pizza had too much cheese and not enough of anything else. Even still warm it was out of balance, with the crust its strongest attribute. The sandwich was good and hung together well in the torpedo. 

Won't be rushing back for takeout, but the broader menu for in house dining might be worth a try aside from the tomato pie.

This Donkey Donuts is in the parking lot of Fieldcrest Center, Columbus, NJ. It has the latest style with smallish indoor sitting area and wrap around drive thru for those who don't have a moment to spare to get out of their cars and walk inside. 

The coffee is pretty much standard DD, and the sweet dough fry what you expect from this outfit. Of course, the Christmas donuts are a pleasant diversion. 

No problem with service, although I forgot that it was on me to pull out napkins and stuff them in the bag. Had some in the car anyway.

Maybe I've been spoiled by all the cafe/coffee house alternatives around these days, but I am finding the Donkey brew to be somewhat pedestrian. They really need to kick it up a notch if they want to succeed in the java wars.

Flip -N- Shakes is a 1960's-esque burger joint on 2nd Street Pike, Southampton, PA. It is a large room with tile floor and utilitarian furniture. Built for speed, not comfort. I was the sole customer when I walked in last weekend on a Saturday afternoon. I was mildly surprised by the lack of activity, but the staff was friendly, and answered by rookie questions with a smile. 

I opted for the Chop House Burger (horseradish, darkly sautéed shrooms, steak sauce, dijon mustard, provolone and onion frizzle on a standard bun), and an apple pie shake. I asked for medium, but then I read that all burgers were served medium-well. At $6.59, the price was a little high for the product presented. Quarter pounder without fresh taste, and a ton of spicy additions that were enjoyable (love horseradish on my sliders), but somewhat contradictory on the tongue. The interplay with the steak sauce and dijon was not harmonic with the radish, and appeared to have been absorbed by the mushrooms so that the original earthiness from the cellar dwellers was lost. Not a bad sandwich, but I wasn't in love with it. 

I had visions of a real slice of apple pie being placed in a blender with ice cream and milk to create the shake. Not exactly. There were a few small apple slices, and the cinnamon nutmeg flavor, but no crusty bits. The flavor was strong and sweet fun, but would have been completely off the hook with an actual slice of pie. It was comparable to a Shake Shack freeze at a better price, so no real demerits for the shortcut. 

The Five Guys nearby makes a better burger (with double meat), while the shake was very good here. Flip City sound track is mostly classic rock, so the atmosphere is fine. These guys have some tough competition in the burger wars. I wish them well in finding the sweet spot that will distinguish themselves from the surrounding hordes.

Tony's Place Bar & Grill sits on Greeley Avenue, Ivyland, PA, across the street from the terminus of the New Hope & Ivyland Railroad.  It has an interesting history coming out of Philadelphia in the last century to set up shop in the wilds of Bucks County. The place is very attractive from the outside, with lots of slate and stone, and outdoor canvas covered patio to one side, and large bar/dining area within. Lots of HDTVs to establish its bona fides as a sports bar. 

On a early Sunday evening in December it was about half full when I arrived around, but the crowd grew as it neared kickoff for the Eagles-Seahawks game.  This is definitely a good place to take in games with friends and family as the beer options are pretty good, and the kitchen cooks up a lot of comfort foods. Although high end steaks are also on the menu, I did not see any brought out. My pumpkin cider tasted like autumn and had a nice kick.  

I was impressed with their Tomato Pie. Very thin cracker-like crust, mozza cheese under a nicely balanced sauce.  Similar to the pies found in New Jersey, and not the "upside down" thing that often is called TP, but is nothing like the real McCoy. So, congrats on getting it right. 

Service was okay, but there were long stretches of time when no one stopped by to see how we were doing. Long wait for the check, too. The customers seemed to be mostly locals who were there for the games and party time, or to pick up a few pizzas to take home.

This ten booth diner sits in the middle of a small commercial strip on Bethlehem Pike, Hatfield, PA. The bench I chose was lumpy and uncomfortable, but I found the high ground on the naugahyde, reviewed the substantial menu as I sipped their large mug of coffee. I went with the french toast, although my server had recommended the overburdened "He Man Special." Far too much for me, although I appreciated the sentiment. The long list of omelettes was likewise tempting, but my semisweet tooth got the better of me. 

When the platter arrived ten minutes later, I beheld three thick slices of bread, yellow from the egg batter, and somewhat browned from its grill time. Unfortunately, as with many renditions of FT that use thicker breads, the egg/sugar/vanilla mix had not penetrated beyond the surface, leaving the center bland white and uninvolved in the frying. There was little caramelization to produce crisp edges, likely because the grill was not hot enough under the bread. This, along with table syrup lacking any flavor but sugary sweetness, made for a competent, but uninspired breakfast. 

The free blueberry muffin presented upon payment was a very nice touch, that helped redeem the mediocrity of the morning meal.

Spice Rack on Knights Road, Bensalem, PA, is in a strip shopping center I had never visited before, called Bensalem Square. It is a small house with about a dozen tables, and courteous, efficient service and a rapid response kitchen. 

Our order of a chaat appetizer (Sev Puri), spinach soup (Palak), chilli chicken and cheese curry (Mughlai Sahi Paneer), with garlic naan, arrived on time and as ordered.  Each had its strength and weaknesses, but overall was a good meal. The chaat was their take on traditional Indian street snacks, with a crisp cracker base, ground veggies and spiced crispies on top. Very good and fun to eat. The spinach soup was sort of a flat dark green broth with interesting flavor, but little body. I bit of cream would likely have really brought it to life. The chilli chicken (dry) was okay, but although said to be dry, was still fairly moist in a heavy goopy sauce. I have had this in several other Indo/Chinese fusion joints, where the chicken had a drier coated finish and a better texture/flavor profile. The paneer dish was rich and flavorful, and was the star of the show. We asked for it moderately spicy, and thought it hit the mark. Finally, the garlic naan was very good. Thinner and crisper than most I had eaten before. The mango lassi was a thick smoothie with crumbled cashews on top. A tad expensive, but a delicious suck. 

Spice Rack is pretty far out of my way, so it is unlikely I will return. There are many better and more consistent Indian kitchens in and around Bucks County, so unless your in the hood, there are plenty of other choices. 

Hidden? Yes.  Gem? Not really.

Pottstown, Pa., is an interesting old city.  We dropped into it late in the afternoon after a day in the heat of French Creek State Park and Hopewell Furnace National Historic Site.  I was feeling the effects of the 90F temp, and needed hydration and a little nourishment.  

First choice was a tour of Yuengling Brewery, but I had confused Pottsville with Pottstown, and would have been too late anyway. (Should have looked further and found Sly Fox Brewery, but that will have to wait.)  Second choice was to find the nearest dairy bar and settle in for some fresh cool creamy ice cream and a burger.  Yelp Search found Coventry Parlor at Laurel Locks, not 10 minutes away from Main Street.  Not too many reviews, but a little more pioneering today wouldn't hurt.  

Actually in Coventry Township, the Laurel Locks refer to both the canal built there to connect with the Schuylkill River canal system, and the large farm that took root there in the early 18th Century.  Another little remembered historic fact was that this area was the home of the a small religious sect called the Stubblebines, whose moral code allowed nudity and cohabitation; giving this locale the name, "Free Love Valley," in the early 19th Century.  It all got out of control, with murder and jealousy rampant.  The group died out by the mid 1800's, when self- proclaimed prophet, Hannah Williamson, caught the last wagon train out of town heading west.  

So, we settled on a couple of burgers and split a Cashew Raspberry Shake.  The shake was thick with nuts and ice cream, and was quite refreshingly creamy sweet.  The burgers were something else.  Past well done, they were crunchy and almost beyond redemption.  I was too weary to bring it to the server's attention.  It came with store bought bun, cheap chips (not even Herr's), and a soft pickle.  

If not for affording the opportunity to learn about the fascinating history of this community, I would have departed disappointed by the grub here.  I just won't look past the front retail ice cream shop next time, should that come to pass.

I came for a business lunch last week.  It is located in a sprawling commercial center parking lot, and is easy to see, but a bit harder to navigate to through the lot. 

Like any mid-range casual dining franchise, there is a sameness to every plant.  While this may have been cozy and "intimate" at one time, today it feels tired, like an old home in need of new furniture and fresh paint.  The formula is dated.  The menu looked the same as when I visited other Applebees' a decade ago.  I guess I shouldn't argue with success, such as it is.  On this day, the customer profile seemed to primarily be grandparents and their grandkids. 

In keeping with the "Oldies But Goodies" theme, I ordered the same Oriental Salad with Chicken as I had ten years ago.  My partner for the meal went with one of their burgers.  Not unexpectedly, my lunch looked and tasted the same as last time, although the bowl was now colorful rather than white.  While we were not there to discuss the food, I did learn that the burger was satisfying. 

I don't feel as critical of this joint as many others here, although I am not enthusiastic about it, either.  It provided a decent meal, service and price in a reasonable time, and in a comfortable setting.  

While this shop and its brethren will not make my short list of desirable dining, I will not turn up my nose if someone wants to go there.

Angelo's is a lovely local Italian establishment on 2nd Street Pike in the heart of the Southampton commercial district.  The reviews show they have the devotion of a lot of people living in the area.  After 30 years that is to be expected and it is well deserved.

The facility is fairly large, with ample privacy for the tables.  The staff is exceptionally friendly and attentive.  The menu is traditional Italian-American fare, with many pizza options, Parms, Alfredo's, Marsala's, etc.  Prices are very reasonable.

My son and I went there last night for the first time.  He had the Chicken Parm, with Minestone Soup; I the Pizza Rustica (small).  The accompanying Italian bread was very tasty, with enough thin crusty crispiness to be enjoyable in taste and bite.  I really enjoyed it with a smear of sweet butter.  It was served warm. 

Son's Parm, was excellent.  The breast was pounded and breaded with a pleasant bread crumb mix, and covered in a heavy fresh tomato sauce.  He was rolling his eyes in delight.  If anything was off, perhaps, the spaghetti side was a bit mushy (he gave me a taste of everything so I could review it).   The Minestone was rich with veggies, pasta and a little beef.  Very good.

The Pizza Rustica was hand-pulled, with fresh Basil, Garlic, chunky Tomatoes, and a heavy Mozzarella finish.  It was good.  Now, pizza is a very personal and subjective taste.  We are all experts.  Some may love this style, but for me it left something to be desired.  I prefer my pizza to have a thin, but firm crust that does not bend or fold under the weight of the toppings.  This one suffered from cheese overload, and required a knife and fork.  It was tasty, but the cheese overwhelmed the other flavors and softened the firmness I prefer. I added crushed hot pepper and garlic powder, which was helpful.  

We will certainly come again and see what else is cooking.  I will tell the waitress more about my pizza preferences, and perhaps, we can reach an accommodation. A good chef appreciates a customer's positive input.  Given all the other positives,
Angelo's may yet become as special to me as it has been to so many long time patrons.

So, what do you order in a restaurant named, "Non Solo Pasta?"  

Although it gave me a moment's pause, I went with the Rigatoni Aglio Olio with Spinach.  I did not see it on the menu, but that is what I had a craving for, and I suspected the kitchen knew how to make it. 

I sat in the corner near the door and shared the attractive floor with three other occupied tables.  It was a cold and quiet night.  My server took a few minutes to find me, but she was courteous, efficient and prompt.  The Side Salad came out first.  It was small with a nice Spring Mix, if a bit light on the house Italian dressing.  Just greens. No cheese, nuts, dried fruit. Basic salad. 

The two small dinner rolls were housemade and quite good with a crunchy crust and mildly salty flavor.  

The wide brimmed white bowl of pasta was adequate, if not generous.  The spinach was cut into smaller pieces and fully sautéed into the oil and garlic.  Tasty.  The pool of oil at the bottom of the bowl was perhaps more than expected, but it did not detract from the al dente Rigatones that were bathing in it.  The garlic taste was strong although not a lot of the bulb was showing in the dish.  

The meal was competent and filling, if not memorable.  There was a lack of energy emanating from the food. It did not visibly shine as many good meals do. Maybe it was the cold night, or the sparse occupancy, but the experience was flat.  Given the cost of this simple meal ($17), I guess I anticipated something more dynamic. 

That I could not get an internet signal in the house compounded this impression.

This Cheeburger Cheeburger franchise is right across the street from Red Robin, so there is a natural choice to make when making a burger run.  If you want a beer with that, than RR is your only option.  If great shakes are a priority, Chee Chee is the better way to go.  

Here, the ambiance is all ersatz 1950's diner-esqueness.  Very similar to Nifty Fifty, Johnnie Rocket's, Jake's Wayback, and the like.  I forgive them the weak attempt at historical orientation, as the actual product is pretty good.  

The burgers and fries are fresh, not frozen at the start, and the end result is a decent (not great) burger experience.  Compared to 5 Guys, it falls a little short in the taste department (not enough tasty grease), but it compensates with more menu variety (chicken, salads), and additional treats to put on the burger (banana chilies, shrooms, pickles, etc.).  The shakes are very good, and they will add malt powder for no additional charge if asked.  Really, creamy and tasty. 

Bottom line - Worth the trip and money when you want a good nostalgia burger.

Cheeburger, Cheeburger is another 1950's throw back concept burger joint franchise.  It is similar to Jake's Wayback, Nifty Fifty, Johnnie Rocket's, etc. 
 
The burgers are fresh beef, not frozen, and are quite good with tons of choices as to things you can add to customize your dining experience.  For me, I love the jalapeno chilies, sauteed onions, and sweet pickle, but there are a zillion combinations.

Last night, I had the Patty Melt, which comes on over sized rye bread, a pile of onions and American Cheese.  The Jalapenos added the kick I love.  The Fries are also fresh cut and not frozen, and come with some of the potato skin attached for extra taste and nutrition.  My son and I split a Vanilla Shake, which was very good - sweet and creamy. 

There is certainly more on the menu here than at places like 5 Guys, the current standard bearer, which makes it a good option for those who do not want the beef, but prefer chicken or salads.  However, to my taste buds, the dining experience is slightly less satisfying than the more limited offerings at 5 Guys.  

To each his own.  Certainly, the burgers at Chee Chee are worthy of your time, taste and money.  The cost for the burgers, fries, and shake came to $30, including tip and tax.  Not cheap, but not quite an indulgence, either. 

Take a big bite.

Pho Xe Lua (Loosely translated as "long car special") is one of the older houses at the bottom of Race Street, and it shows its age.  The menu is extensive, particularly if you like Vietnamese dishes or Pho.  Portions are large.  Prices are low.  Very popular combination that keeps the two floors busy day and night.  Just don't spend time looking at the floor around your table, because cleanliness is an issue.  The house hasn't been inspected by L & I for a long time, and it shows. 

Still, it is mind over matter.  If you don't mind the grit around you, it doesn't matter.  Just enjoy the plentitude so light on your wallet.  

We were there for a late lunch and stayed with the soup.  My partner had the Pho Special that contained all the meats available in the kitchen, and I their Bun Bo Hue.  They label the sizes of their bowls as large and extra large, as if that was something everyone understood.  The former would be a large bowl in most establishments, and the later, a fish bowl.  We couldn't finish either.  

The Pho broth was decent; full of noodles and a load of meat.  It was tasty, but lacked some of the more subtle flavors associated with the better noodle soups.  I did not taste Anise, although it could have been in there.  My Bun Bo was stocked with three big Pig's Feet (Glad they left him one on the hoof), plus slices of Beef and shreds of Pork.  It had ample Lemongrass for the strong spiciness that makes this so distinctive, Fermented Shrimp Paste for sourness,  plus Onions, Mint, and a few unidentified floating objects.  I did not detect Coriander, Rock Sugar, nor Congealed Pig Blood (thankfully), which are part of the totally authentic mix.  The side dish accompaniments had the usual Sprouts, Thai Basil, Jalapeno Slices and Lime Wedges, but was missing the Banana Blossom Slices, and/or Red Cabbage.  

Still, it was pretty good; the first spoonful paralyzing my vocal cords so I could only whisper for about 15 minutes.  It wasn't the best BBH I have had in the City, but it wasn't the worst.  Given the complexity of the real deal, perhaps it was unfair of me to expect Pho Xe Lua to get it completely right.  

Service was fine, and our server was multilingual, making my Mandarin speaking friend happy with his descriptions in her native tongue. 

No need to run back here, but its broad non-Chinese menu makes it a reasonable alternative when in Chinatown, but not feeling like Chinese food.

Right on the Broad Street/Rt. 206 Circle in Hamilton, NJ, this Advance Auto Parts store used to be a Chinese Buffet back in the day.  There are similarities in the wide display of everything car/truck related being found on the aisles, the same way the multitude of chicken pieces were dressed up with many sauces, accompanied by veggie and rice alternatives.  

I came in looking for a jack and lug wrench to replace the original equipment that had gone missing recently (one of the great mysteries of life).  Everything Advance had was for much heavier usage.  Even the smallest scissor jack was engineered to lift a panel truck, and much too heavy duty (and just plain heavy) for my needs.  I did remember to pick up a replacement wiper; finding myself studying the chart to determine which model and level of sophistication was required.  For $22 this better last forever. 

Service was of the DIY variety, which was okay after I located the area of the shop I wanted, but no one volunteered to assist.  I guess most customers have been there before.

Chik Fil A in Newtown stands across the parking fields from Acme, and shares a parking lot with Appleby's.  They have both drive through and eat-in services. 
I am not a fan of their chicken sandwiches and nuggets, although my young son loves them.  For me, they lack much taste and the roll and filet together are too soft for an enjoyable bite and chew. I will only eat them if I am very hungry.
However, the breakfast sandwiches are superior products compared to other fast food variations.  The sausage, egg and cheese biscuit is super tasty and textured, so every bite is a pleasure.  The fresh biscuits are flakey and have a mild buttery flavor.  
The best thing offered are the shakes.  They claim to be "hand spun," whatever that means.  The taste is wonderful with the right amount of sweetness and creaminess.  Their season special shakes are fun on St. Patrick's Day (green minty), late summer (peach), and fall (pumpkin).  They are a little expensive compared to the drink alternatives, but a palate pleaser. 
I am not a regular here, but there is a time when it offers exactly what I want.

Stumbled on Trent City Pizzeria on my way back from court. I had stopped to pick up fresh coffee at Trenton Coffee House, and continued down Cass Street until I turned onto Lamberton Street to head back to the office. I didn't remember a restaurant being there.  It looked new and shiny.  Decided the time was right for lunch, so I parked on the street in front of the shop and went in.  

It was indeed a new store.  Four booths. Seven stools along the walls. A big kitchen in back, separated by glass counters and work space.  Everyone spoke Spanish, and Telemundo was on the tube, yet the menu was all Italian with Spanish specials behind the counter for the asking. I went with my old standby, eggplant parm sandwich.  I sat and waited.  A couple of local street dudes came in for a bite.  We all fiddled with our smart phones waiting for our food.  

The nightshade was pretty good.  Plenty of thin sliced eggplant, breaded and sautéed in olive oil.  Tender and nice taste.  The red sauce was ample, as was the mozzarella melted on top.  The roll was crisp from the oven's warm embrace.  It was a big sandwich, and came with fries. Left most of those behind to concentrate on the star of the show.  

With a Snapple, lunch was $9 and small change.  Thought it good enough to warrant a return visit to sample the pizza, and perhaps a cheesesteak or Italian Hot Dog.

Donuts seem to be making a comeback after years of suffering through the likes of Dunkin and other over extended chains turning out mimeographic fry dough, that are little more than a standard platform for applying a variety of colored sugar. Yawn!

Places like Factory Donuts have the right idea.  Make the donuts just in time for the customer to receive them hot from the oil bath and customized on the spot to suit their taste.  It works for burgers and pizza, why not for other fun comfort food? It is an idea whose time has come. 

Of course, it really helps if the overall experience contributes to the enjoyment of the finished product.  Here, that is not quite the case. I noticed that the rounders were smaller than found in most other outlets; and more expensive. If you are going to charge over a buck for one of these babies, shouldn't each one be magnificent in taste, texture and size?  Not only were they diminutive compared to the competition, but the apparent variety of flavors was not quite real. To my tongue several varieties had different colors, but more or less the same taste.  That pretty red one was no different than that pretty purple one with sprinkles. 

Hocus pocus. 

I don't know about you, but I love a good cup of Joe with my glazed sugar fix. The java at the factory doesn't stand up. It is a bland commercial blend that does not contribute to the enjoyment of the moment. For a premium price, there should also be a premium bean. 

Finally, when I buy a box of six donuts, I don't expect to eat them all immediately.  I will sample one to taste it warm, and wait a bit for the rest, sometimes until the next day to consume them all with help of friends and family.  The first one eaten while I was still in their parking lot was terrific.  Fresh cake out of the kitchen, glaze barely set to hardening - a pleasant jolt on the tongue. Teased and almost seduced. Yet, by that evening the thrill was gone, even with a short burst in the microwave. Come the next morning, there was little to enjoy beyond scraping the excess icing from the bottom of the box for the mouth rush hardened sugar provides. 

It wasn't a complete fiasco, as watching the donuts being made and customized was fun, and they were truly very good right off the assembly line.  If they would up their game on the coffee, I would return knowing that I should only buy what could be eaten within an hour or so. Under those conditions, Factory Donuts would be a hit.

The upper reaches of Washington Avenue are rather bleak with warehouses and abandoned buildings all around.  The only ray of light in the area of 15th Street is the corner Dunkin Donuts.  On a dark night, it is like seeing Las Vegas as you drive in from the desert.  

This particular shop seems to be a hang out for a certain taxi company, where at any time of the day, the parking lot and surround curbs are parked up with off duty cabs.  The drivers stand around outside or sit within, chatting in their native tongues, and sipping the local brew.  All this adds to the color of the joint.  

The coffee is pretty much standard issue DD.  Never great. Always adequate. The bakery offerings are below average, as if they are being made by people who don't really get the donut concept.  Maybe that's the way the cabbies like them. 

It's hard to get excited about any Dunkin, and this one is no different.  

Any caffeine in a storm.

I have visited several past incarnations of restaurants at this location on a gentle rise along the Delaware River and Delaware & Raritan Canal.  No wonder successive owners have tried to make a go of a comfortable retreat here.  It is really quite lovely, especially before dusk when the western orientation raises a curtain on some magnificent sunsets. This was my first meal at Erini and I looked forward to the opportunity to enjoy a repast in the large and well appointed dining rooms of the past. 

Walking in past the well fed cats, I soon saw that little had changed within. Same bar crowded at happy hour, and same spacious dining area.  Although we were early, the hostess easily sat us at a nice table, and the server brought us menus and took our drink order.  Seemless. We ordered the Grilled Salmon and Chicken Marsala, foregoing apps and sides in the expectation that we would have a substantial dinner. 

And, substantial they were.  Both plates were large - steamy, colorful  and textural  in presentation. We dug in.  Not to bring you down too quickly, but nothing was quite as good as it at first appeared. The Salmon, although a nice size steak, was not first quality according to my companion.  She found it too "fatty," and less than the tight morsel she desired.  Good sauce, nice Roasted Potatoes, but still disappointing. My Marsala has a similar story.  The chicken was slightly overcooked in the fry pan and lacked moistness. The sauce, though plentiful, was monotonal and lacking finesse.

 It was all good, but not good enough to make me a fan. Kudos to the staff that was professional and engaging. The Happy Hour trade is a success, and perhaps that is where the sweet spot is at Erini.

PIZZA BY THE SLICE REVIEW

Nova Trattoria recently moved to this location, replacing the Mexican casa that was there before. It is a smallish space with a row of tables along the wall, with kitchen on the opposite side behind another wall that gives the appearance of being a very narrow dining room. 

I ordered a slice of Brooklyn pie and another tradition regular triangle. The Brooklyn slice was pretty good - thin crust, Marzano sauce and dollops of mozza in a square pan. It was firm, crisp and pleasantly chewy.  The regular slice was not as good.  The crust was limp despite requesting it be reheated well done, and there was ample oil drip onto the paper plate. Just not a strong presentation.

The price was good at around $5 for the slices and bottle of water. Service was pleasant from start to finish.
 
There is much better pizza and tomato pie right nearby.

Decent D & D on West Trenton Avenue, Morrisville, right next to Italian Peoples Bakery.  Run by an efficient and friendly crew. 

The coffee is okay, but not outstanding.  The baked goods are also right down the middle of the road.  My Everything Bagel with Light Veggie Cream Cheese filled the need to quiet my stomach until after court. 

Plenty of parking at a mildly difficult intersection.

Another fairly typical urban Chinese/American house on Broad Street in Trenton.  They have all the classics on the menu from General Tso's Chicken to anything with Broccoli, and Steamed/Pan Fried Dumplings.  

Nothing is outstanding, but neither is it beyond the pall.  My Egg Foo Young was thick and loaded with Veggie and Pork.  The Brown Sauce seemed identical to all the others I have tried in such joints.  The Pork Fried Rice had the brown tint of beef stock base, and the Egg Roll was mostly cabbage with a bit of something else - perhaps, pork. 

At least, China Garden seemed cleaner than many of the others.  Too, it is obviously a family place because the owner's son was on site and helping out, though he seemed no more than 12.  

The people are friendly, are fully bilingual, and the prices seem like from the 1990's, perhaps because they have been there so long and making a go of it in part because of the low rent on that strip of Broad Street.  

It's not the place to take a date, but it is certainly decent enough for a combo lunch or cheap and filling dinner.  

Garden? Can't see the connection from out front or inside.  But, maybe they all fly away to a secret place at night, or have a small cultivated plot out back.

Bagel Barrel on West State Street, Doylestown, PA, has been around for a while, and aside from the Manhattan Bagel shop a few blocks away, is the only game in town for boil and bake rounders. The joint is cozy with small dining area, self serve coffee and very reasonable prices. It's a nice place to hang out with friends and family (if you can find a table). 

Downside is that their bagel style is not my fave. They are on the small side and more densely textured than I prefer. To my buds, they taste like sour dough loaf with thin shell and lots of sprinkles (onion being my primary choice). The quality is there, but I jump for a lighter, air-pocketed inside, crisper shell and less sour flavor. It comes down to the base flour used and the amount of kneading before forming the ring of dough that becomes the bagel. Like pie crust, less is more when it comes to great texture. 

Everyone behind the counter was pleasant and having a good time when I was there. That's always a good sign for a positive atmosphere. If they made the kind of bagels I loved, I would stop in regularly. As it is, Bagel Train in Yardley will continue to be my station for awesome bagels in Bucks County.

Manny's Restaurant & Delicatessen is the new name of the former Steve Stein's Deli on Buck Road in Holland, PA. It has been open for a few weeks, and it appears many of the old customers remain as regulars to enjoy the kosher style smoked meats, soups and salads for which the former management was renowned. The floorplan is attractive with large ceramic tiles on walls and ceiling and the dining room separated from the deli by a semi wall that still allows you to glimpse the operation and smell its delights. 

The menu is small compared to its predecessor, so you may not find every ethnic dish hoped for. Still, there was enough for me to find something I liked for lunch. I went with a soup/sandwich combo of split pea and chicken salad on rye for $9.50. Service was friendly and attractive. 

I wasn't overwhelmed by what arrived at my table a few minutes later. The split pea soup was thick and hot, but was salty and lacked any extras like croutons or other textural enhancements to add interest. The chicken salad was okay, but again monotonal in taste and lacking in chunkiness. Overall, a ho-hum lunch. Not bad, but lacking a spark to draw me back. Prices high for what they offer.

Surburban Diner has the misfortune of sitting at one of the ugliest intersections on the East Coast - Street Road X Bustleton Pike.  Man, where were the urban planners when we needed them? Recently with all the bad weather drivers have been too busy dodging potholes to notice that the entire zone is really one Grand Canyon sized pothole. Once safely in the parking lot the challenge becomes finding a slot for your wheels.  The lot is undersized for the capacity of the facility, but if you drive behind the building and turn right, you might get lucky.  

Once inside, the familiarity of Diner World takes control and you know what needs be done.  Wait to be seated at booth or table, or slide past the throng at the door, turn right, and take a spinning stool at the counter - no waiting. So moved.  I was promptly greeted by a kind waitress in black and white who deposited a multi paged breakfast menu and inquired about a drink.  Coffee, please.  She turned and poured mine into a white mug from the antique Cecilware Auto Coffee Urn.  Can't get those any more, but back in the day they were the best way to make large volumes of java. Still great Joe. She returned often to refill.  

I ordered the Whole Wheat French Toast.  It arrived on white oval industrial ceramic, dusted with powdered sugar.  The middle slice of bread stood on edge mid-plate, like a mainsail mast in a sea of Maple Syrup.   The bread was fresh and a thick cut.  It was super absorbent.  No matter how much syrup I pour on it, there was nothing at the bottom of the plate to sop up with the FT.  Three additional pours and still not a drop.  Oh, but the meal got sweeter.  I was impressed.  

In years of French Toast sampling, I have come to prefer a thinner sliced bread over the thicker version, because the egg absorbs more completely, and with a hot grill carmelization takes place where hot metal cauterizes the egg/bread surfaces, creating a mild crispiness.  Still, this stuff was pretty good for thick cut, and I had no complaints.  

Clearly, Suburban Diner has its loyal followers.  A look around the dining room disclosed a predominance of seniors, some with children and grandkids.  The place seemed wholesome. The bakery turned out some pretty cakes and pies.  Maybe next time for that.  

With "I Love Lucy" playing in black and white on the TV, it was easy to slip into a time warp and imagine myself in a Back to The Future moment.  

I enjoyed the experience on several levels, but I am not sure I would put Suburban Diner on my short list of fandom.

Richboro, PA, is experiencing a big growth spurt with the closing of the Davis Auto Group facility in the center of town and the new businesses being developed in that large space. The cranes and construction workers are still there, but a couple of buildings are finished and the new look downtown is taking shape. Dairy Queen leased the space at the rear of the new office/retail structure at Second Street Pike just off the Bustleton Pike intersection. It is a little hard to find hidden way in back.

The store itself is fairly small, with two rows of about a dozen booths and tables in front, cashier and kitchen in back and soda service area against the rear wall. Service is young, friendly and accommodating. The order taker was kind enough to point out that as I was there before 2, their $5 and $6 lunch specials were still in play. Cheeseburger, fries, soft drink and small sundae for a fin was good deal, so I went for it, except I knew I couldn't handle the dessert, so he gave me a coupon for a free one instead. Much appreciated. He even permitted me to swap the carbonated beverage for a small blizzard without upcharge. 

The package was okay when delivered to my booth, but not really inspiring. Fries were hot and crisp. The bun was not grilled, nor heated and could have used something to improve its plain white bread texture and taste. The 3 oz. burger was decent with onion, lettuce and tomato topping. The shake was a shallow imitation of the thick, rich and creamy 'Zzard of my childhood. Too watery. Not much flavor. A disappointment. Maybe something was missed in the downsizing for lunch. The whipped cream on top was more dominant that the mix beneath. 

So, while I might return, I would skip the cheap deal and go for their full bore burgers and blizzards to see if those were true to the DQ Brazier creed.

 Life is too short for boring burgers.

The Langhorne Hotel has anchored the corner of Maple and Bellevue for a couple of centuries.  The world around it may have changed, but this establishment has not, except for a few architectural modifications to accommodate the uses to which it was being put.  

This is both good and not so. Walking into the tavern area throws you into the Eighteenth Century, where the local Sons of Liberty gathered to plot the Revolution. Downside, the beer selection is from the same era.  The dining area is also dated to about 1890.  The menu is solid for a 1960's kitchen.  Everything is well prepared and tasty, but if you want something in the way of vegetarian, vegan, or even contemporary cuisine, it will be hard to find. The burgers, traditional Italian, and usual suspects are present.  As long as that is what you want, you will be satisfied.  

Today I tried the Italian Sausage with Peppers and Onions in red sauce over Linguini for a lunch special. At $7.99 the price was right.  I enjoyed the meal, but there was nothing memorable about it. We turned lunch into a work meeting and remained for  more than an hour after we finished eating. The room was practically deserted on a August Friday afternoon.  We were not rushed, and the room was comfortable, if somewhat brown in tone. 

A new menu, broader beer options, fresh coat of paint and new carpets would go a long way to bring the Langhorne Hotel a new clientele. But, if they did that, the Sons of Liberty in the tavern might go elsewhere to plot our way to independence. 

Maybe we are wise to leave well enough alone.

The Newtown Farmer's Market is not really a farmers' market at all.  It is a space where various food vendors sell their homemade (or not) products from Thursday thru Saturday.  The overall gestalt is Amish, but many of the retailers are local people selling non-Pa. Dutch things.  Go if you like fresh food options in meat, produce, dairy, bread, and Middle Eastern/Mediterranean food,  or Amish-style pickled stuff, sushi, fresh fish, or my favorite BBQ'd everything.  There is a small eating area if you love to snack or have a noisy meal, but otherwise take out is the name of the game. 

The prices are more or LESS competitive with local grocers, but the freshness is what they score with. Also, the Pa Dutch folks who are there, provide a quaintness that makes the exploration a pleasant experience.  

Overall, whether you like it or not depends on your expectations.  Don't think: Reading Terminal, because it is not even close to that in scope.  Think: small time alternative to megamarkets with some local color and fresh food.  With a little creativity and space, it could be so much more. 

If you have the time and enjoy this kind of thing, the Trenton Farmers' Market is much larger and more diverse.  Worth a hungry visit.

B-Uno's still has its, "Grand Opening" sign up on the window, and it seems it has not been discovered on this out of the way corner of Jacksonville Road, just off Rt. 130 North, in Burlington, NJ.  It is really a Latino Casa that does breakfast and lunch.  The menu is on a large blackboard on the wall.  The gist is mostly burgers named after the automotive universe, with burritos a strong option.  

I was there for a late breakfast around 10:30 am, and went with a Sausage, Egg & Cheese Sandwich on a Kaiser Roll.  At $6 for the sandwich with a small side of Tator Tots and a large Coffee, I thought the price proposition to be very attractive.  I sat at one of the 4 small tables along the front window, facing the wall menu, with the counter to my left and the short order grill just on the other side.  

Standing up to look for the coffee (it was being fresh brewed for me in the back of the kitchen), I observed the cook putting my meal together.  Link sausage was being deep fried before slicing and grilling and lay the groundwork on the base of the roll.  I didn't need the extra oil from using that approach to preparation, but it did not affect the taste.  The same was true for the Tator Tots.  Deep fried and crunchy.  The eggs were fresh and folded flat on the hot steel before being slipped into place on top of the meat.  The cheese went on last and helped seal the fresh roll top to the contents of the creation.  

All in all, a pretty good sandwich, and better cup of brewed java.  

Next time, I will ask for one of their well-named burgers, as that seems to be their sweet spot.  

These guys should make it.  They are friendly and play good music with a strong nod to Carlos Santana. 

Oye Como Va!

Pat's King of Steaks reminds of the fable, The Emperor's New Clothes. 
After picking up my California friend at 30th Street Station, we wove our way down to  South 9th Street for a taste of Philadelphia - the renowned, Pat's.  My 12 year old son came along when he heard we would go for cheesesteaks.  

The environment around Pat's is terrific.  People all over the place.  The queue to order.  The Rules for Ordering.  The smack in the puss aroma of burning grease and onions.  The whole migila.  I felt my own excitement rise the closer I came to the ordering window.  I felt the vicarious thrill as my son ordered his first Cheesesteak Witout and Provolone, and a Birch Beer.  Truly, a right of passage. 

Yet, when we sat down at a red metal grate table and began to devour our sandwiches, I noted my son's displeasure with the amount of fat and gristle he had to  spit out.  I, too, was surprised to find red meat in my tumultuous pile of steak, onions, mushrooms and cheese.  Uncooked.  It felt careless. I did not mind that each time I picked up the load to have a bite, and equal amount fell out the back end of the 'wich. That was to be expected from an unfortunate roll incapable of holding its load.  Still, I did not feel like picking up the canned shrooms  and steak pieces to eat them.  

5 Stars for the institution and historic icon that is Pat's King of Steaks. 
2 Stars for the actual product generated from this amazing operation.  

3 Stars for the King who needs to look in the mirror and realize he may be wearing only his reputation.

I seem to remember this prefab diner being delivered and installed a few years ago.  Nice job making new look retro. It is not as big as I was expecting, but well maintained and definitely creates its own unique carnival-like atmospherics.  

Stopped in for breakfast recently and took a seat at the counter.  Big breakfast menu, and a cup of coffee were placed in front of me before I had a chance to squirm to a comfortable position on the spinner.  Impressive attentiveness.  The servers wore smiles and were warmly engaging.  

I opted for a breakfast sandwich on a Kaiser roll.  I thought that was all I would get for the reasonable price.  However, my waitperson then asked if I wanted Home Fries or Fresh Fruit with it.  Potatoes or fruit on top of what was already a big bite.  Thinking quickly for that time of day, I suppressed my surprise and inquired if it was possible to have half of each.  I wanted to sample more.  She nodded in appreciation.  

Now, most Sausage, Egg and Cheese 'wiches come with a single sausage patty, one fried egg, and a slice or two of American cheese.  Not this baby.  It came with two patties, one egg, and a load of melted cheese that had to be three or four slices.  The Home Fries took up a third of the large plate, and the Fruit Cup was a nice mix of Cantelope, Watermelon, Pineapple, Grapes, Blackberries and Strawberries.  

Needless to say, this was more than a single meal, and much more than I wanted to consume early in the morning, so I tasted a bit of everything, but could not finish anything.  I had a momentary qualm about the over the top quantity of food, the obesity epidemic in the US, and starvation elsewhere.  It felt excessive and indulgent.  

While everything tasted good, if I return I will make a conscious effort to ask them to give me less.

If I had to guess, I would think that Chalfont Family Restaurant/Diner had changed hands somewhere in the not too distant past, and been taken over by Spanish speaking owners who were trying hard to duplicate traditional American cuisine, but not quite there yet. Nothing wrong with that, and I wish them success. 

I found the large dining room clean, but somewhat dreary in worn yellow and brown tones. The menu hadn't been modernized in some time. Only one server handled the several parties there for breakfast, keeping him extremely busy and unable to check up on everyone often enough to keep coffee mugs full and timely remove old plates. He kept his smile and aplomb, but always running to catch up. 

My County Style Omelet (onion, green pepper, potato mixed inside the egg shell), was ample, but a tad too dried out from over cooking. Too, I splashed on Tabasco to liven up the flavor when black pepper wasn't enough. It would have been so much better had a choice of cheese been part of the deal, rather than a steep upcharge. A little feta would have been a great place to start. Coffee was industrial; Rye Toast, standard. 

Overall, it was an acceptable breakfast, but could have been a contender with more attention to detail, and perhaps another set of hands in the kitchen.

Lunch Review

Bamboo Kitchen (Why do I want to say, "Bamboo Curtain?"), Sits in the space of the former Peng Yuan Chinese house. New owners. New look. Very similar menu. 

I went down Buck Road to the Pleasant Valley Center to pick up my order for General Tso Chicken from their lunch list. It came with choice of rice (fried), but without soup or egg roll. Although I hadn't asked for it in advance, they were happy to add a Hot & Sour Soup for another $1. 

Good decision.

Turned out that the soup was very good and the best part of the meal.  It had fresh mushrooms, lots of sprouts and tofu, and  strong tart vinegar base. Liked it alot. 

The rest was pretty much forgettable. The chicken was okay, but somewhat dried out, and the sauce sweet, but not the least bit spicy. The rice was dyed yellow from the bouillon it was cooked in, but did have a fair share of veggies and small pieces of pork. Given the quality of the soup compared to the rest, it would seem that lunch is a loss leader for them, priced too low to justify a really satisfying meal.

The dinner menu is likely better.

Asian Chopsticks is now just a takeout joint dispensing primarily Chinese American fare to the masses in lower Bucks County. There are two tables in the house, but they don't turn the heat on in the shop on cold days, so the message of inhospitality is evident. The staff behind the plexiglass are bundled up, too. So order, wait, pay and go, is the true order of business.

I only go with basics at a new place for me like this. After all, I might get lucky and have hit on a kitchen that can really cook despite the apparent slovenliness of the operation, but in all likelihood this is a poor to middling' wok room that is in it to survive and save enough dough to maybe launch a second store somewhere. So, I ordered roast pork egg foo young and wonton soup to size up the potential. 

The soup was about average with a few more wontons than expected, and the three pancakes were also in the middle of the pack, although the brown sauce was better than most (just made, not lumpy and decent flavor). 
Service through the glass was cordial but remote, with no effort at interaction. 

Bottom line - You could do worse that Asian Chopsticks, but unless you are otherwise in the area, it doesn't pay to go out of your way to buy your Chinese victuals here. There are far better choices not very far away.

Happy China is the third in a series of Asian takeout at this location in Levittown, PA. The previous tenants lasted as long as their leases and succumbed to the poor location at the ass end of a run down strip, it's nearly invisible from the main roads and a tiny floor space that had little room for dining in. 

Still, this iteration has a chance, if they maintain reasonable standards of taste and cleanliness and do a little advertising. I found the interaction with the woman owner to be pleasant. She took my phone order of Crispy Orange Chicken (extra spicy, with fried rice and Wonton Soup) graciously and had it ready moments after my arrival as discussed. 

Here's my rundown of the this lunch special -

Crispy Orange Chicken had a pretty good sauce, and the cut chicken was plentiful, as was the rice. Problem was that the crispiness was gone by the time I opened the plastic container because both were mixed together, rather than keeping bird and sauce separate until consumed at final destination. Too, but for this premature exposure, the chicken could have been left dry with a little ventilation to allow excess moisture to escape as the food cooled. Still a tasty dish, but could have been so much better without the soggies. 

Wonton Soup was less redeeming. The wontons were thick skinned and filled with mystery meat. The beef stock in which they swam was aging rapidly and lacked much to applaud. It was hot, so I'll give it that. 

Fried Rice was the largest part of the combo. It was okay, with enough pork and veggies to warrant some merit, but I left most of it behind as unwanted starch. 

There was nothing unusual about the meal, although the price was inexpensive. Happy China falls into the overall Average range of Chinese American takeout. It would be hard to find much better in similar joints, and much easier to find worse.

COVID-19 TAKEOUT REVIEW

Out on York Road just before it enters Montgomery County from Bucks, sits Rey Azteca (King of the Aztecs), a decent Casa Mexicana located in what looks to have been formerly a Pizza Hut. Adequate parking and nicely remodeled interior with those colorful carved chair backs and murals depicting the bright life made famous in all the pastel paintings sold on the streets of almost every small villa in Mexico.  Looking for a place to pick up a good meal, I picked this one because of strong reviews and relative proximity. 

Bottom line - It lost something in-between house and store, as many carry-outs do. Sitting in aluminum containers and covered to keep in all the moisture, it was no longer as fresh and crisp as they would have been if eaten right there. 

The Steak Fajitas were plentiful, but overcooked and too chewy when eaten at our kitchen table. Far too well-done and dried out. The side salad, guac and crema tasted good, but couldn't revive what was already deceased. Luckily, the Los Coco's Special (two beef/chicken quesadillas with red rice) was much better, especially with salsa roja generously applied over top. Very satisfied. 

Neither dish came with the promised side tortillas. 

The Chip & Salsa was a hefty bag of corn crunchies and fresh tomato, jalapeno, cilantro in a large plastic bowl. They were a strong compliment. 

No doubt this meal would have been better if we had spoken with a server about how to finish the steak (medium), and done without the grillman scorch them to well done. It's hard to get it right when the only dialogue is over the phone, and all you see is a packed up brown paper sack with your name on it upon arrival. The dining room, though closed, looked inviting.

Broad Street Diner (formerly Manetas) is aptly named for the street where it is located. Of course, there are other diners on Broad Street, so don't be confused.

This place has been well renovated to match its new moniker, and although smaller than the better known places like Mastoris and Town and County a few miles away, it is still comfortable, although the tables are fairly close together. 

I was there for a late lunch last week, and the floor was mostly empty.  I was greeted with a smile by a waitress and the cashier, and led to a deuce in the side dining room. A second waitress brought me a menu and informed me where to look for specials. She promptly brought water and lemon, and returned again moments later to take my order of Greek Turkey Burger on Pita.  The platter came out with the grilled pita on the bottom of the plate, and the burger on top of it. It was up to me to make it a sandwich, which I opted not to do.  There was a small plastic cup of fresh feta cheese, and tachini sauce in another, so I could use what I wanted. Lettuce and Jersey Tomato sat on the edge of the plate.  At first, I was a little put off that the finished product was not constructed in the kitchen, but as I got into my own preparation I began to appreciate leaving the raw materials for me to combine.  That way I had it just the way I wanted it. There were also a side of fries, but aside from being hot and crisp, I don't recall the taste two days later. 

My server was very friendly and efficient, and obviously well trained.  She appeared to offer more water or ask if I needed anything, and I knew she really meant it, as opposed to the monotone I often get when the job is just routine.  I tipped her well for her pleasant professionalism. 

The meal was good. Everything fresh, quality ingredients.  While I would not rush back for another meal, I certainly will remember I enjoyed my lunch and not hesitate to return to the Broad Street Diner when in the area.

January 4, 2016 - Stopped in for a late night dessert, coffee and conversation.  All three played their part well in making an enjoyable evening.  The Rice Pudding was excellent.
