Originals Pizza sits to the side of the Giant Shopping Center on West Trenton Avenue in Morrisville, Pa.  It is in a small commercial strip next to a Wells Fargo office and a Dominos Pizza.  It has been here for a long time and has settled into its space nicely.  Although long and narrow, the furnishings create the sense of sitting on picnic tables under a striped awning along the outside walls of the building.  Nice, if gitchy, touch. 

The moustachioed men behind the counter look like brothers, but they assured me they were not.  They were both friendly and ready to serve.  As I came in after 7 pm on a midweek evening, the pizza offerings were not vast for a guy in need of only a slice.  That is always the risk taken late in the day of any pizza shop.  You never know how long the pies on display have been waiting for your attention.  Their "Tomato Pie" seemed to have the most energy as it sat there, so I asked for it to be reheated to "well done" for me.  

It was that.  When it arrived I could see that the heavy tomato pasty topping had been reawakened.  Picking it up gingerly, it held its point well with only the slightest quiver from the weight above.  The scorch marks on the chassis were well established from the oven.  That is what I wanted.  First bite revealed a thicker than expected crust that resisted my clenching incisors just enough to let me know it would not yield its secrets willingly.  Solid chew.  

The slice was more than enough for an evening snack.  Two slices would have been way too much.  The top sauce was thicker and saltier than I prefer, and the few chunks of garlic not enough to demand serious attention.  I overheard the chef say to a customer that this was "Brooklyn Style" Tomato Pie.  Not sure what he meant, as it surely wasn't the T.Pie created and made famous across the Delaware in Jersey.  There, the mozza goes on before the sauce, and the tomato mix is applied more sparingly to achieve balance in texture and taste between the two main food groups.  Originals had little or no cheese that I could discern, but just the overpowering sauce.  

It was okay for what it was, but not close to what I was accustomed to in a Tomato Pie.

Paige H. from Morrisville has it right.  This place is a mixed bag (of bagels). 
When Bagel Junction in Newtown closed its doors unexpectedly a few months ago I was heartsick.  My favorite bagel joint for many years was gone. What was I going to do?
I checked on Google and Yelp for a substitute for my addiction.  I tried several places in the area before going to Bagel Train. Their bagels are almost as good as Bagel Junction, and I found they satisfied my craving better than the others. 
Many of us are bagel experts, and I consider myself one, being raised in New York, and having strong opinions about such important things. 
So, this is now my local bagel place.  But, there is a reason for only 3 stars.  The bagels are 4 star (everything is relative), but the interaction with the owner is stiff and unwelcoming (1.5 stars).
 The coffee is so-so.  The help is very good, and compensate in part for their boss's personality, and the lack of physical comfort as I stand in a long line waiting my turn.  Even that has its benefits, as there are many nice people to talk with.
Cash or check only.

American menu with a Mexican twist, B-Unos sits where an old mom and pop luncheonette once filled the belly and entertained the troops in downtown Mt. Holly, NJ. They've done a nice redo of the place, with new furniture, walls and floors. The original six spinner lunch counter still sits in back for those who prefer taking a load off in the 60s, before returning to the teen years of the twenty first. 

The menu offers BYO omelets, quesadillas and loaded french toast in equal measure, but it pays to keep it simple because each additional item has an upcharge that quickly runs over $10 for even a basic sounding plate. Clever, but not exactly consumer friendly. I chose the naked Frenchie with three slices of thick white bread, melted butter and table syrup. 

It looked great with all the caramelized edges, but was a bit dry as the profile showed the egg mix had barely penetrated the wider bread and the middle remained uninvolved in the cooking process. It wasn't all bad, but could have been so much more. The java was hot and strong, as was the service by the young woman who also worked as the cashier and busser. 

Maybe staying south of the Rio Grande is the way to happiness at B-Unos.

Most Applebee's, like almost any national restaurant chain, are interchangeable. Eaten in one, eaten in them all. That reliability is a good thing if the basic experience is positive anywhere in the Applebee's Universe. While not a favorite, I find that when it comes to dining with family, this name can normally be counted on to deliver a reasonably good quality/value proposition, that satisfies the greatest number for a decent price. 

To be precise, my sons like their BBQ ribs, burgers and sides, while we adults can nicely make due with house salads as well as the beef offerings. 

Usually.

But, not the other night. 

For some reason, things started going sideways as soon as we sat down. First, my plastic water glass sprang a leak and left a pond on the table before we could catch anyone's attention for a towel. Then, when we did, a towel seemed beyond their ability to produce, and they brought a pile of napkins instead. Lacking much absorbency, they were quickly soaked to the max, leaving a large pile of sopping paper and smaller puddles on the table. At least the water was no longer spilling onto our laps, but the wet naps remained on our table through ordering and food delivery, untiI I asked for them to be removed. 

My son enjoyed the ribs/chicken breast platter. Devoured all of it. My Whiskey Bacon burger was okay, but beyond the medium finish requested by a few time zones, and crumbly. Not their best effort. 

Perhaps it was the exception that proves the rule, but this Applebee's night was all wet. 

2.5 Stars

A business lunch brought 7 of us to Miller's late last week. 
The house looks a lot better in daylight. Plenty of room, and large windows that open wide on beautiful days to give the feel of eating out on the spring porch. 
Small choice of draft beers, but enough to keep most people happy. Service was fine, especially the fact that they have some extra large booths that fit all of us comfortably. 
Most of us chose from the salad menu, but there was a burger in the group, too. 
When served, although 5 different names, they all looked basically the same with each having been accessorized slightly differently. It was funny, and they were okay, but not particularly memorable. We talked more than we ate, so it didn't make much difference. 
If we end up working a project together it will be all worthwhile.

Jake's Eatery on Cambridge Lane replaces several Indian Restaurants that occupied this tiny strip mall about a quarter mile west of Sycamore Street in Newtown.  
I have had lunch there several times, often choosing to sit at the bar rather than wait for a table. As I am usually eating alone, the stool is a good option, however, there always seems to be some confusion in the staff as to who will provide service to me. 
Everyone is friendly, but as with many wait people, they avoid eye contact as much as possible and thus are not always attentive to their customers.  This happens repeatedly at Jake's, and thus the time until my order is taken, served, and the bill arrives, adds unnecessarily to the time in-house.  
The food is all decent to good.  Most is fresh and tasty.  I enjoy their burgers, which are simple and can be customized to taste (sauteed onions, mushrooms, and jalapeno chilies, please).  The fish sandwich is also good. 
The place is clean and bright, and always has a nice crowd.  Many business meals, and post-workout meet ups.  
I do miss the Chicken Tikka Masala and Garlic Naan, but it has not turned up on the menu yet.

Victoria's Bagel Bistro is really more of a tie dye T-shirt, hippie dippy kind of place out on Rt. 38 in Mt. Laurel, NJ.  The place has a nice sized room with about a dozen tables, Rock & Roll Classic Hits for sound, and photos/sketches of Presley, Marley and a few other music heavyweights on the walls.  Definitely, a chill place.  

Victoria, herself, served me.  Very friendly and accommodating owner that puts herself into the environment she created.  She gave me the two bit tour of what was available for breakfast, and I opted for an Onion Bagel with a smear of Butter and a few slices of Swiss, not toasted. I took a seat at the table nearest the front window, and settled down to check in on Yelp.  

The bagel arrived looking quite good.  There weren't a lot of toasted onion flakes on the surface, but enough to hold the flavor.  In profile, the transection was a nice layering of bread and cheese.  First bite announced that the surface of the bagel was not crisp, nor crunchy, but rather more like the regular crust of a bread loaf.  I really prefer a more distinct outer texture with a softer airy middle.  So, while the taste was decent, it was not an optimal bagel for me. We all have our own opinions about bagels, and this must be what the strong enthusiasts here like most.  For me, is was really only Okay.  

Still, the java was hot and strong, the price very competitive, and the overall experience, positive.  I liked what Victoria was doing there. 

And, wish her continued success.

This International House of Pancakes on Mt. Holly Road, Burlington, NJ, sits in a renovated former fast food structure, and is small compared to the more recent versions of this franchise around the country. All the cues are there to prepare you for a hearty breakfast. 

I walked in before court last week for a light bite and coffee, and to kill some time before my workday began. I took a seat at the 5 stool counter and was served by Tim, a young dude who seemed diligent and engaging. After a short look at the long menu, I opted for their traditional french toast and strong java. All the other choices seemed like they would be way too sweet with berries and whipped cream. Didn't want those calories. 

My plate arrived ten minutes later looking attractive and tempting. I spread the cup of butter across the egg pocked surface, and poured on the old fashioned syrup (maple not on the counter).  First bite was very good, but a realized that their signature approach to this dish was to add pancake mix to the beaten eggs.  This was visible in the unusual shine on the surface of the toast, as well as the distinct mild taste of buttermilk with each forkful. I had not tasted this before, but I enjoyed this take on a historic platter.  Nice for a change of pace, but not something I would specifically request, as I prefer the traditional approach to french toast. 

The carafe of hot coffee in front of me is another thing they do well. They realize that coffee is an inexpensive way to appear generous. 

I have never been a IHOP regular, as I normally prefer a mom and pop shop to a chain or franchise for breakfast, or any meal. Still, I appreciate what they do, and their effort to find a new approach to their business. They even are doing burgers now. Haven't tried them, but they do look good on the menu.

Las Margaritas on 2nd Street Pike, Southampton, PA, isn't bad for a casa Mexicana that serves mainly an American audience not necessarily familiar with the deep choices available in a kitchen that caters to its own nationals. The space is large and dimly lit, with plenty of colorful cues of its South of the Border cultural heritage. It is very popular as witnessed by the long wait for people walking in looking for a table. Luckily, as a solo diner, I was able to grab a barstool and take my liquid and solid choices right there.

I have been somewhat spoiled by the wide variety and authenticity of all the casas Latinas in and around Trenton, which has become a very ciudad Centro Americano. All those formerly Italian corner restaurants now speak Espanol, and they put out amazing cuisine. 

Still, Las Margaritas is a good place for a reasonably priced cocktail by the same name, and the well known dishes found in most Mexican houses catering to gringos. Lots to choose from in terms of nachos, tacos, burritos, chimis, and tortas, and even a few decent dinner platters, like the chili rellenos ordered by me.  I found the two large breaded and fried poblano peppers to be nicely loaded with melted cheese and queso fresco, and topped with a thin, but well spiced, ranchero sauce. I tossed on the salsa from the chips to add texture and heat, and enjoyed the refried beans and dirty rice accompaniments. 

Not a bad meal at all. Bartender service was fine and muy amable. The only hiccup was being tendered the wrong cuenta for a couple of bucks more than what I ordered. El hombre tried to tell me it was the same price as what I got, but I knew that was not the case. Still, it wasn't worth a challenge to his manhood, so I let it roll, and adjusted the tip accordingly. 

Honesty is always the best policy when it comes to restaurant tabs.

It seems that Café con Leche has been in Newtown forever.  It is a place I used to go to with some frequency, but over the years it fell off my radar as a "go to" place for good Latin/Italian styled cuisine.  When a friend recommended it for lunch I jumped at the chance to revisit an old friend. 

Daniel Lucci is the owner/chef in this walkout basement of a restaurant on the Newtown Creek side of State Street.  It is best approached from the parking lot next to Isaac Newtown's, where it must compete for parking.  It is accurate to describe the dining area as small and dark, but for some that adds to the ambiance and charm.  The menu seemed smaller than I remembered it, but it still had Mexican, Italian, and Continental flourishes.  

Lunch was from the Sandwiches Menu.  All are prepared on French Bread with a side salad.  The bread is fresh with a moderately crunchy crusty ingratiating bite, and my accompanying salad was potato with celery and a mayo-mustard creamy connector.  The Yellow Fin Tuna Salad was good, layered with lettuce and tomato slices.  It was satisfying and filling.  The Cajun Salmon was nicely blackened with a Pesto Mayo dressing and side garden salad with Daniel's special Balsamic Vinegrette, he calls, "Balsamico." I tasted this and thought it was better than the tuna.  

I could not escape the thought that perhaps, Café con Leche had remained too long in the same space, and thus cramped its growth in both tables and adventurous gourmet meals.  A little more sunshine might open this accomplished chef to brand new and exciting possibilities.  In some way it seemed that the rest of the local restaurant world had caught up to CCL, and even passed it by.

The anti-Starbucks. In sight of its backdoor. Pour your own and no waiting. Decent coffee and snacks. Inferior view, but no seating required.
I'm not saying 7/11 is a true alternative to the Green Mermaid, but if you strip away the atmospherics and even the pretension, and the antisocial, illegal, parking in front so some can get their daily grind going without the trouble of finding a safe place to stash their wheels, what you are left with are taste and price.  On both counts, the Lucky Numbers win - with parking to spare.

Although this pizza shop calls itself, "The Original Dominick's," there is nothing of the that organization here beyond the name. The only Dom's these days are in Richboro and Washington Crossing, Pa. The family sold off the other locations several years ago, allowing the buyers to keep the name. 

The space has seen better days when it was a convenience store, "Mr. Milk." Yes. I used to live on Riverside Drive on the Delaware and this was my local shop. Still, it is a survivor, and puts out decent pies at reasonable prices, as long as you are willing to overlook the worn out feel of a now run down store.  

I am about the pizza and can ignore almost anything when in the presence of good T Pie. Pizza is at its apex right from the oven (even when reheated), so I prefer to mange right at its peak, and damn the torpedoes. We took a table and settled in.

The slices were served on the metal pans used for personal size pies. Nice touch that helps keep them warm,. Much better than the paper plates used by so many joints. I did not mind going to the high counter to retrieve them. 

Although I seldom order a "fancy" slice, she asked for a chicken parm wedge. It came loaded with chunks of clucker, sauce and cheese. The chassis held the heavy topside with minimal assistance. My sample bite was okay. She devoured it. Mine were sausage and traditional Trenton tomato pie. They had a firm thin crunchy crust that held up well. Not too oily. The gravy was a little salty, but nice and thick with clumps of Tomato on top of the mozza on the TP. They used sliced sausage rather than free form which exuded less flavor than preferred. 

They weren't perfect, nor even exceptional, but still pretty good. Clearly, they were given the recipes by Dominick, but had taken some creative liberties over the years.

A little elbow grease and TLC could bring this pizza parlor up a notch.

Fireside Smokehouse is the current incarnation of this old tavern down on Elmwood Avenue in Trevose, Pa. It has been run by one family since 1978, and they certainly know what they are doing adapting to changing tastes and fads to remain a solid choice for a hearty meal and a load of suds options. 

First impressions are that Fireside has three personalities - a front room dive bar full of locals enjoying the broad beer list and a few eating something meaty from the grill; a simple dining room with a dozen tables, and outside patio enclosed in canvas and plastic for cold weather, with a few picnic tables and service bar. The front bar was the most crowded  and with the most attitude.

Our server told us to sit anywhere and came back to us quickly for drink orders. Menus were already on every table.  Two pages of beer options took a few, but we settled on Limbo IPA and Weyerbacher Imperial Pumpkin Ale drafts. Cool and smooth going down. 

Son opted for a pulled pork sandwich with chips. He liked it, but has had better flavor. Too, there was no sauce on the table for added moisture and taste. The grilled salmon was a small steak, but fresh and nicely done. The spinach and slaw sides were forgettable.  My chicken & rib combo put a heavy plate with 6 ribs and quarter bird before me. They were both covered with the house BBQ sauce, a deep amber red.  The meat easily pulled from the bone and tasted of a good rub, long smoke and twangy sauce. Really liked it, and they were so loaded that I ate three, gave two away and brought one home along with the untouched clucker. The baked beanz were great and the mashed would have been too with a spoon of gravy or sauce on top. 

Fireside is a solid choice for basic BBQ in a down home environment.  It's nothing fancy, just serious meat overload and strong fermentation possibilities. Put a few table rockets of Memphis, St.Louis, Carolina,  along with the house slather in front of me, bring the ribs out dry for me to doctor the way I want, polish up the sides a bit, and this smokehouse would be seeing stars.

Two Slices and a Drink Review

Stopped into Peppi's Pizza & Pasta after shopping at the Giant Supermarket in the same Shoppes at Flowers Mill commercial center.  Narrow in front, with dining room in back, this is a typical pizza parlor with booths, and a vast array of pies for examination, temptation and ordering.  I asked that my two regulars be "well done," in order to reawaken the taste slumbering within after extended time under hot lamps and hungry eyes.  

The slices were as requested and picking each aloft showed the crust to be firm and able to supports its load.  The tomato sauce was on the salty side, as was the mozza.  Would have preferred a sweeter bite. Still, that's just a matter of taste, and many people like it that way. 

Service was friendly and prompt, and the free refill of the soft drink, a nice touch. 

Certainly worthy of a pizza snack when out and about.

I'm not sure what to make of the fact that there were no Indians in the kitchen of Cross Culture Indian Restaurant in Buckingham, PA. The menu was more limited than many I've seen, and the dishes themselves while decent, lacked some of the dynamism I associate with quality curry and other colorfully spiced South Asian cuisine.

We ordered their Veggie Samosa and Tomato Soup appetizers, Chicken Cashmere, Veggie Navaratan Korma as entrees and Garlic Naan for sopping up the anticipated creamy reductions. They were a mixed bag. 

The Tomato Soup was disappointingly bland, and we decided to bring it all home to doctor it to a better place. The Samosas had a good crunchy shell, but the potato/pea contents was dry with little tongue tickle. The Cashmere was the best of the bunch - pleasantly creamy sauce sweetened by the cashew and raisins and tender dark chicken. The Korma was also quite good, but the sauce was too similar to the Cashmere and needed a bit more curry heat to make it distinguishable from its sibling. Where was the tumeric and chili? Finally, the Naan was hot and oily as it should be, and quickly gone as we enjoyed spooning up the sauces as our dessert. 

Service was warm and efficient by one of the owners. She seemed to appreciate our presence in the days before restaurants were closed to protect from the COVID-19 crisis. We all suspected that moment to arrive soon, so in some ways we expected and acknowledged that this might well be our last meal out for the foreseeable future. Just wish the entire meal was as memorable as the societal moment we all were enduring. 

Be safe everyone.

I have a love/hate relationship with Wawa. It applies more or less equally to all of them, but especially the super hyper Wawas that are currently being developed on the East Coast. 

I certainly see the value buying their gasoline which is always a few cents cheaper than the regular gas stations in the area. Yet, I hesitate to buy it because I don't know who refines it for them, and thus can't trust its quality and ingredients. Too, I will sometimes stop in for coffee or a hoagie, but know that by doing so I am helping weaken the older mom and pop shops that rely on passing drivers for their survival. So, I usually feel conflicted visiting these 21st Century phenomena and avoid them more often than not.

It's not about whether they present a real monetary value to customers, nor offer the convenience of being able to fill up both your tank and stomach in the same place. Obviously, there are benefits in time and money being able to do so. But, do we want this to become normative behavior if the cost is really enforced conformity, universal standardization of our diets, and the end of all the variety that existed earlier in our cultural evolution? 

I have concerns about this piece of progress, and wonder (perhaps, too often outloud) whether we would be better off if we spent more time doing little things like buying gas or eating lunch. Ultimately, I have no problem if I end up at a charging station to power my vehicle rather than slaving to the internal combustion engine, because that's good for the environment. But, on actions where convenience and not ecology is as stake, I vote for a little less time saving, and much more consideration of the existential quality of our lives. 

It may not be fair to make Wawa the symbol of that degradation, rather than just another symptom of something bigger, but I came to that realization naturally, and it seems to capture my internal conflict as well as anything else. 

Feel free to ignore these rantings of a peaceful lunatic, but sometimes you just have to ask the questions.

Decent enough bagel and friendly service, but it is somewhat amazing that there is so much disparity between one Manhattan Bagel shop and another; this one on Bustleton Avenue in the Russian part of Northeast Philly landing on the lower end of the spectrum. 

Crust not as firm/crisp as others nearby, and far fewer roasted onion flakes attached. Still, more than adequate veggie cream cheese coverage within to help offset the shortcomings. 

Their coffee is strong and holds its own for a breakfast blend. Been sipping it for several hours and it hasn't turned bitter. 

Will certainly do until a real bakery shows up and turns out a Real McCoy bagel, that knows how to bathe well before baking.

Nino's Trattoria & Pizzeria sits just off the Brunswick Circle in Trenton, NJ.  It is easy to see how it is a pizzeria, but it does not look nor feel like a trattoria. Rather, there is a long narrow area to the left of the restaurant with the ovens and prep zone, and a larger dining room to the left as you enter.  There are a dozen or so tables and booths in this typical Italian shop.  It would look a lot nicer if the chairs had been taken down off the tables during business hours. It felt like they weren't quite ready for prime time. 

However, my lunch was of considerably higher quality than the atmosphere.  My eggplant parm sandwich was made of thin sliced nightshade, dipped in breadcrumbs, and pan fried in olive oil before being placed in a submarine roll, topped with red sauce and slices of mozza cheese and thrown in the oven to melt the cheese and toast the bread.  The coating was thin enough to allow the flavor of the veggie to come through loud and clear.  Not too much gravy nor cheese to obscure the main ingredient, but enough to enhance it.  

My companion went with penne with their house red gravy, in a child size portion. Just right for lunch.  I sampled the pencil points and found their sauce to be very good.  It had lots of minced garlic, salt, pepper and a touch of basil; creating a lightly chunky tasty crushed tomato texture and rich taste.  Although I usually eat the eggplant without the roll, I found myself sopping up the delicious mash with pieces of the hoagie roll, it was so good. When I asked for the second half of the sandwich to be packed up for home, the server put in two extra small containers of the sauce, because she had seen me going after it with gusto at the table. Gratitude! 

Nino's has some strong kitchen skills with their pasta and baked specialties. Can't speak to their pizza.  A little attention to the impression created in their customers would allow them to make the dining room more presentable, and create the sense of a polished dining facility.

Hunan Wok (identified as only, "Hunan" on the sign above the shop), is a fairly typical Chinese/American suburban restaurant in the Fairgrounds Shopping Plaza just outside downtown Mt. Holly.  The menu is what you expect to find in such places.  It is set up primarily for takeout, but offers a few tables for those who prefer to eat in, as I did.  

My lunch consisted of Sesame Chicken, Fried Rice, & Wonton Soup.  It was served to me in the takeout containers, with plastic utensils.  The soup was straight up chicken bouillon and the wontons were thick skinned and of average quality.  The Chicken itself was plentiful with a mix of white and dark meat, breaded, and drowned in dark amber goopy sauce, with sesame seeds sprinkled on top.  It was not bad, but undistinguishable from most other such joints.  The rice had been prepared in the same soup mix as the wonton, and carried the same yellow color.  More than enough, but not worth carbing out on. 

Service was fine.  The proprietress was engaged and efficient.  The price was under $7 with a soft drink.

Asian House sits in the Mallard Shopping Centre on northbound Route 130.  It is pretty far south of Bordentown, so don't give up hope if you don't see it right way if you are travelling south.  

The space is very nicely appointed for a Chinese/American shop trying to be all things Asian for the hungry public.  There are Sushi, Thai and Chinese options on the menu.  I went Chinese for my first visit as I knew it was owned/operated by Fujianese folks from the Mainland. 

I opted for Szechuan Chicken (extra spicy), which came with Wonton Soup and Pork Fried Rice.  The soup was not good.  It was a mass produced beef stock tinted brown from the dye in the can it came from.  The wontons were thick and not very tasty.  The Chicken dish was better.  The meat was fresh and the veggies colorful.  The sauce lacked much in the way of red Szechuan chilies, and was not hot enough despite asking for extra heat.  I think the kitchen was on autopilot and just turned out what they normally do and ignored my request.  At least it was decent, even lacking the spice.  The Fried Rice was better than average with the grains still distinct and veggies firm.  

 The best thing Asian House has going for it is Misty, the woman running the front of the house.  She was friendly, engaging, helpful, and prompt with service.  She singlehandedly made my lunch a memorable one, and provided the motivation to return to try other features of their menu.

Viet Thai Cuisine is a well designed Asian house just off the Pa Pike in Horsham.  Lots of stone and metal, and even a wall of pussy willow branches. A semi-private dining room was off to the side.  Service is warm and precise, and the menu offers a fairly broad cross section of dishes from Vietnam and Thailand.  In such "fusion" locales, the question always is whether it is really "fusion," or more confusion?  

The staff we saw was Thai, and we took that as a suggestion to stay close to the menu from their homeland, just to be safe.  Besides, we have been to many very good Vietnamese shops in and around Philly, and our Thai options were always more limited.  

We ordered Coconut Soup (w/ Tofu), Summer Rolls (Veggie), and Salmon in Red Curry Sauce for sharing.  The soup had the sweetness from the coconut and the hot bite of lemongrass, with plenty of veggies.  It was quite good, and was slurped away quickly.  The summer rolls were also top notch, with a thin strip of tofu holding the rest of the contents together.  The peanut dipping sauce was excellent with thin chili shavings and ground nuts sitting on top, looking like calligraphy (see photo).  If there was anything that missed the mark, it was the salmon, which was slightly overcooked, and was drier than desired.  Still, the presentation was lovely, and the surrounding elements on the plate along with the red curry, redeemed the fish to some extent.  

We were enjoying our time here, and decided to extend it with a fried banana dessert.  It came in the guise of spring rolls with a large scoop of Bassett's Vanilla Ice Cream melting on top.  It was a creamy sweet ending to our evening at Viet Thai.  

3.5 Stars

The good news is that this part of Street Road, Bensalem,PA, has a large Indian population and alot of commerce dedicated to meeting the needs of the community. The bad news is that Indian Hut is still the equivalent of a fast casual food outlet - better than fast food, but far short of haute subcontinental cuisine. So, unless your expectations are properly calibrated, you are probably going to be somewhat disappointed by the size of each entree, the roughness of the main ingredients, or the non-subtlety of the various sauces into which everything is thrown and mixed. 

Our Malai Kofta (veggie balls in mild red curry), Chicken Korma and Makhani (boneless chunky chicken in spicy red/lightly sweet mild yellow curry), Chili Gobhi (fried cauliflower florets in Manchurian red chili/tumeric heat) and Veggie Biryani (long grain basmati rice mixed with chopped greens, like fried rice, but not as captivating), were strong on spice, pretty in color, but perhaps too monotonal in texture and heavy handed Indian spices. 

Not that everything was bad, it wasn't. It's more that everything was too much alike, so that the dishes blended together indistinguishably from each other after a few bites. 

At $11-12 per choice, it wasn't too expensive, but would have been so much better with a deft curry hand at the controls. Then again, if you can taste the difference between fast casual and superior tasting North or South Indian kitchens, you don't really belong at such inferior joints.

Giovanni's Pizza is a Italian shop on York Road in Jamison, Pa. They do a big pizza business as suggested by the wall of pizza boxes awaiting use in the entrance hall. When I asked one of the guys behind the counter how many pies they do a day, I was told anywhere from 50 to 300! Quite a range, but they were getting ready for the high end when we were there by cutting up the dough and placing them in small aluminum canisters. 

The house itself has two dining rooms and can accommodate quite a crowd. It is clean, and service is prompt and friendly. We ordered a single plain slice to see how they do with their most basic commodity, an eggplant parmesan sandwich and a burger with onions and mushrooms.  Nothing stood out as exceptional, and some things need work. 

The plain pizza is average in size and taste. Mine was a reheat job, well done. They got that right, and the crust was nice and firm with a mild scorch on the undercarriage. There was too much cheese for me, and not enough sauce. Really could not get the flavor of the tomatoes due to cheesy dominance. Pizza requires the right balance on top to make it stand out. This did not do it. The eggplant parm sandwich was in a large torpedo roll, again covered in copious melted mozzarella. The nightshade itself had a heavy breading that absorbed a lot of oil in the frying.  Would have been better if just sautéed in olive oil without the extra breading, but was still okay. The burger was disappointing. A frozen puck, cooked to well done when medium was requested. Dry and tasteless, despite the additional sautéed onions and mushrooms. Even the ketchup couldn't save it. 

This was a late lunch, and we didn't explore the dinner and pasta options, which may be as good as the other reviewers report. Still, I can only write about my experience, which was not quite middle of the road.

2.5 Stars.

"Anything worth doing is worth overdoing."
- Albert Einstein

And so it is with bubble tea shops in Philly Chinatown. 
You can't cross the street without seeing bobba signs on every corner. Tapioca is definitely having an amazing resurgence. I don't get why gummy sweet goobers are so popular, but I'm obviously in the minority. 

Still, I enjoy good milk tea as much as the next guy, and Vivi Bubble Tea has it's fair share of that. The space is larger than expected, with a large room with group tables in back for all your friends. Service is efficient and friendly. I had my almond milk tea in hand in under a minute. Impressive. 

The tea was good and exactly what I needed to continue with my shopping list and Artiva haircut. Steamy hot, mildly sweet, sufficiently nutty. $4. 

Noticed that Vivi offered fried chicken wings. Piquing my curiousity, I made a mental note to give them a try next time I needed a nosh while in Ctown.

Keystone Bagels on Mill Creek Parkway just off Route 13 South, sits in a small commercial strip with a pizza parlor and ice cream shop, so it is possible to have breakfast, lunch, dinner and dessert without leaving the premises. I was there for the first meal of the day, although I have previously sampled the creamies next door. 

The store is fairly small, with half dozen tables and high tops, in addition to the kitchen area.  The bagels don't appear to be baked on site, but my onion bagel & swiss sandwich was certainly fresh and loaded with large crisp onion flakes.

 The downside was that it was more dense than I prefer in a bagel. I like the ones that have crisp skins and lighter dough within. That's just a matter of taste.  However, I was disappointed that there was no real milk in the small refrigerator next to the self-serve coffee counter. Liquid CoffeeMate was available in various flavors, but none are as healthy as 2% or even whole milk.  They do have longer shelf life due to the lack of any dairy component, so I get it.  It's just not what I want in my java. My black coffee itself was adequate, but it was obvious that Joe is a secondary consideration there.  

Upgrade the coffee operation and Keystone could be a real sweet spot for breakfast and lunch.

I like what they've done with this place at the bottom of High Street, Mt. Holly, NJ. 

What was a mom and pop dive restaurant for decades has been renovated into a clean, utiliitarian modern kitchen with small counter near the back and fairly large dining room upfront. It is the third B-Uno in the area, focusing on American cuisine with a overlay of Mexican flair. They have breakfast and lunch hours, except for Friday through Sunday when they are open until 9 for dinner. I stopped in after court this week to check them out for a morning bite and mugga joltin' joe. 

Their menu has a lot of "Build Your Own" dishes from omelets to pancakes, meat, tater tots and quesadillas. That approach gets pricey and belly stuffed quickly, so I opted for an order of French Toast neat - with just melted butter and syrup. I drank their java and read the news while waiting for delivery to my table.

It was pretty good. Thick cut slices, well caramelized with decent mix of sugar and cinnamon in the eggs. The only shortcoming was that the egg hadn't penetrated past the outer layer of the bread, and as a result the thickness of the loaf became a detriment, making for a semi dry morning meal that required a copious pour from the syrup squeezem to keep it lubricated for consumption.  

Service was fine. No problems with accessibility as far as I could see, although I didn't visit the bathrooms. 

Still, I liked the joint and recognized its possibilities. It is a nice addition to downtown Mt. Holly and will certainly contribute to local commerce. It just need to soak the bread a bit more.

There are things to like about Brick House Tavern & Tap, and a few other things that detract from the overall experience. 

The space is generally very nice, with an open floorplan, and brick wall along the back of the house. There are booths, high top large tables, sofas, and a bar - each offering a different comfort level. I was there as a solitary traveler, and chose to sit at the bar. This may have been a poor choice, as the design leaves a lot to be desired. 

Although square with barstools along each side, lines of sight are obstructed on each side by the beer tap hardware that extends down from the ceiling and spreads out it large apparatus just above eye level so it is impossible to see the HDTVs behind the bar. Also, after a pour (I had a Summer Shandy), the individual tap continues to drip onto the metal splash guard above the drain, spraying droplets of beer in all directions - especially toward me, the customer. While it didn't make me wet, it did reach the wooden bar top, making it damp and causing damage to the finish. There must be a better, cleaner, more sanitary way to deal with drippy taps. 

The bar ladies were clearly selected for their fit in jeans, more than their tending skills. While I am not complaining about the view, the dropped and broken glasses, cut fingers, and spillage was not the most fun to observe. And, it happened twice during my hour there. 

The Brick House Cheeseburger seemed a safe bet.  It looked good on arrival. Yet, the medium grill requested was much closer to well done. The fries were fine. It was an average burger, at best. 

The overall sense of this joint is that management does not run a tight ship, and should spend more time training staff to be sure the customer is the center of attention, rather than the interaction between the workers. The menu is pricy for this level of roadhouse experience, and the quality of the menu and service should reflect that. Otherwise, what you get is a dive bar trying to pass itself off as elite.

This Rancocas Woods section of Mount Laurel, NJ, has a out of Jersey feel to it.  Semi-pine barrens, small cabin stores along every rural byway, and an almost eerie 19th Century feel.  So, when I found myself on these back roads looking for a way back to the present, and came across an old roadside stand with a small parking area and a sign that said, "coffee and breakfast," I was curious enough to stop and check it out.  

Inside I found a 1950's shop, with a couple of tables up front, and a counter and grill in the far corner.  There was a woman in back putting together a large lunch order, and a younger guy working the hotspot.  He turned, smiled, and asked how he could be of assistance.  He recommended a breakfast sandwich by reputation.  I was down with that, and ordered a sausage, egg & cheese on Kaiser roll, with coffee, for immediate consumption.  I grabbed a take out menu and a seat at the table closest to the door.  Couldn't find them on Yelp, and decided to put them into the system.  He didn't mind.  

Maybe it was all the surrounding country that played with my head, or just the quality of the air inside this old wooden structure, but there was a definite drift pulling me backward in time.  Kind of pleasant, and not strong enough to stop me from returning to today.  When the sandwich arrived on a green plastic plate covered in sandwich paper, I had been looking out the window at an old pickup parked under BJ's rusted and distended sign creaking in the breeze.   

The aroma brought me out of reveries, and back to the quiet hunger in my pit.  It looked good; all steamy and melty.  Single sausage patty, two slices, and a nice egg scramble.  Tasted good, too., although their bakery provider could make crustier rolls. This one was soft and had the taste of white bread in roll form. The Joe was hot medium roast.  Only one size for coffee.  Fill it up as much as I liked, according to the chef/manager.  So, I did, about half way. 

Not sure I will find myself in this neighborhood again, because I'm not exactly sure how I got there.  But, if I am, I will certainly stop in for one of their burgers or cheesesteaks, for which they won an award according to www.cheesesteaks.com. 

Didn't realize they had internet back then.

White Elephant Thai Restaurant has served Huntington Valley, PA, for many years from it's location in a commercial center strip. Their menu is elaborate with separate lunch listings between 11:30 and 2:00. I was there to partake of midday meal and was greeted warmly by the gentleman who served me. 

The room is attractively appointed with elephant totems and warm curry tangerine colors. I was seated at a table behind the jungle growth of tropical plants separating the waiting/seating areas. On a long term addictive run with Thai broad noodles and elaborate sauces, I ordered their $10.95 lunch of Coconut Soup, Fried Thai Dumplings and Drunken Noodles with Chicken, 'Thai spicy.' 

The house began to fill as the hour approached 12, and more help appeared from the back. The soup arrived first in small cup. The lovely aroma of coconut smiled seductively. It was excellent, with a few slices of tender chicken, carrot, onion. It was semi sweet and steaming hot. Suspicious beginning. 

The dumplings were round with ground pork and spicy dipping sauce. They were plump and quite tasty as well. Two for two! 

Last came the noodles, and unfortunately, the letdown. Plentiful on the large plate, they appeared to have been sitting out too long after wokking, because the top was dry while the bottom of the dish showed sauce. Too, the chicken slices were extremely dry and dessicated. Likely yesterday's bird, reanimated. Disappointing, to say the least. Given that the chicken in the soup was right, the comparison was inevitable and suggested lack of concern.

A budding five star experience descended to three and a customer lost. 

Sometimes the last impression is more powerful than the first.

Seems this place is hard to find if you are not from the area. Here is the secret. Follow the signs to the Hampton Inn, and make a left just before you reach the front entrance. The DD is across the parking fields from the hotel. 

There are two Dunkins within a couple of miles of each other. There is one on Swamp Road in Newtown, and this one just off 95 in Lower Makefield.  I prefer this one because the coffee just tastes better.  How is that possible?  It all comes down to the quality of the water going in if it is not being strongly filtered before it touches bean. Two different water companies service each shop.  Newtown's water is hard and does not play well with coffee.  The Lower Make water is softer, and is a better companion in the brew. Thus, the taste in Newtown tends toward bitterness, while the L.Make drink is smoother going down. 

The donuts are about the same for each, with perhaps a slight edge to Ntown for available variety. Sandwiches and B and R ice cream seem identical. 

So, given the choice, I go to this place. Secondarily, it is also larger, and friendlier than its sibling. 

Lying just over the border with Ntown, this is the place the Newtown Zealots meet to plot their next move. 

Also, the best place to caffeine-up before starting a long drive north or south.

First time down in the Cambodian neighborhood along south 7th Street. A bit sketchy, but plenty of street life with cafes, food stores, fruit mongers, and a lot of action down in the park at 6th and Wolf. 

I Heart Cambodia has been in operation since December last.  It is bright and cheery, if a bit noisy due to constant drone of homegrown music videos and poor acoustics.  The folks operating the joint are friendly and amenable to longer discussions about their plans (a bar) and their kitchen (broadening the menu).  As a first timer, I had more than the usual questions about ingredients and spiciness.

When it was time to order we found out there were no Summer Rolls available.  Small disappointment. But, we moved on to select Papaya Salad, Stir Fried Flat Rice Noodles with Chicken, and Prahok Ktis (the "s" is silent).  They were all okay, but nothing was exceptional.  The Papaya Salad was spiced by something that tasted like radish.  It didn't work for us, especially compared to similar dishes in Thai houses. Even allowing for cultural differences, it just wasn't a pleasant flavor.  The Stir Fried Noodles was the best dish; well prepared, but still not as good as others I have had in Philly and in Asia. The sauce for the Prahok Ktis was tasty with a mix of Pork, Coconut Milk, Lemongrass, Kaffir, Fermented Fish Sauce and Peanuts, but the slices veggies to be used as scoops were very small, making it awkward to use as intended. Everything was fresh, but perhaps measured for smaller fingers.  

It became clear looking around the room that the most exciting dish was the Ginger Fried Fish.  It looked great.  Next time that is where we start. 

I would also skip the Thai Iced Tea and the extra bowls of rice as unnecessary for the meal at hand.

Pho Palace is a bit of a misnomer.  

The facility is minimalist in décor, and a bit dreary in furniture and lighting.  Hardly a palace.  Still, there is a reasonable trade off to be made if your goal is good Pho, Banh Mi, Com or Bun dishes.  There are Thai and Chinese offerings on the menu, but I have not gone there even though management and staff appears to be primarily Chinese.  

I ordered Banh Mi Thit Nuong (BBQ Pork Hoagie) and Pho Ga (Chicken Pho).  The Banh Mi was delivered on an oval plate over a strip of aluminum foil.  The torpedo roll was more Italian than French, with a thinner crust than a baguette, but toasted well.  The makings filled the bread with a nice quantity of tasty BBQ Pork, Daikon Radish, Cilantro, Carrots and Cucumber.  The mix crunched well and was quite satisfying.  My server assured me that the Banh Mi and a Medium Pho would not be too much for a meal.  He was right.  The sandwich was somewhat filling, but not so large as to be sufficient in and of itself.  I liked it and would definitely order it again.  

The Pho bowl was large enough to hold what seemed to be a liter of clear, well developed broth, loads of Chicken Slices, Onions, Scallions and a nest of Noodles. I spent a minute lifting and separating the clumped Noodles. After throwing in Bean Sprouts, Basil Leaves, Jalapenos, and Squeezed Lime Wedges, the bowl was overflowing and the aroma rich and comforting.  I loaded the side sauce dish with a Hoisin/Sriracha mix to dip the chicken, and settled in for a slurpy meal.  

Everything was pretty good, and the service was friendly and efficient.  

Adequate parking in front. Cash only with in house ATM.

So, how does this compare to the nearest other Vietnamese restaurant, House of Pho in Southampton?  I find them both good, perhaps appealing to different customers.  Where House of Pho offers a much nicer environment, Pho Palace is more basic and less comfortable.  The Banh Mi is House of Pho is higher quality; using real French Baguette, and more Pork.  The Pho in both locales are very close in quality and freshness of accessories.  To my palate, they are a draw.  Where Pho Palace has a distinct advantage is price.  The Banh Mi was only $3.75 - a (pardon me, I can't resist) PHOnominal price.  The Pho at $6.75/7.75 (Med/Lrg) is also lower than at the House.  

So, it comes down to what you need and want.  For a date or lux feel, House of Pho is the obvious choice.  You pay for it, but it may be worth it.  If only needing a solid tasty soup and sandwich, etc.,  without much environment, but saving a few bucks per person, Pho Palace is a very good alternative.  No doubt the rent each pays and the neighborhoods, have a lot to do with the prices on the menus.   Only separated by a few miles, the differences between Southampton and the Far Northeast Philly are considerable.  If I had to chose, House of Pho would be my first choice based on the overall experience from facility through food and ability to use credit cards.

Ho Choi Chinese Restaurant is located in a small strip center, right next to a 7/11 convenience store. It is within the standard deviation for take out Chinois joints, with a tip of the hat to folks who want to eat in (4 tables).  The menu is the same one you have memorized from going to any other chopstick house in the USA.  It is perhaps cleaner than average, and the woman working the front is friendly and has a sense of humor.  

The Roast Pork Egg Foo Young was also what I expected.  Two omelet/pancakes full of pork, sprouts, onion, on top of a massive pile of prefab yellow dyed fried rice.  The brown sauce tasted identical to all the others, with a slightly lighter color.  The meal was served in styro packaging with a mini fork for consumption.  The taste was fine.  

It always seems strange when a Chinese place doesn't have hot tea for guests.  Can of soda or water bottle are part of the meal deal, but how nice it would be if they provided a 2 cent tea bag and a small pot of hot water!  Alas, it is seen as unnecessary because so few Americans drink tea in these circumstances.  

Ho Choi did nothing to distinguish itself, but neither did it suck.

Langhorne Coffee House sits in the old Hicks House at the corner of Bellevue and Maple in the heart of Langhorne.  Edward Hicks was the artist who painted, "The Peaceable Kingdom," and other works that have some notoriety, so the name is well known by locals with a sense of history.  The café is cozy (some might say a tight squeeze), with tables in close proximity and a community seating sensibility.  

The coffee is quite good and bottomless, with several daily options, including the organic blend I drank today.  The room is colorful with large windows and local artists' works for sale on the walls.  The staff is warm and cheerful.  The displays show varieties of attractive pastries. 

My breakfast was a Sausage, Egg & Cheese in a Spinach Wrap.  It came quickly, but did look a little lost on the large white platter with a single slice of Orange.  It was fine, but the egg seemed to have been cooked in a microwave, which I do not prefer as it changes the consistency of the egg into something soft and airy, as opposed to how an egg is prepared in a fry pan giving it more substance.  I should have asked about that before ordering.  

All in all, an adequate meal, but not one I will yearn to repeat.  Yet, the atmosphere, service and coffee were all nice enough to make it a positive experience.  I would definitely return for my morning coffee when in the area.

Not on my short list of noteworthy breakfast stops, but a worthy community-centric shop that has a loyal following for good reason.

Why does Star$$$ coffee always taste burnt?
This is always my problem with Green Mermaid coffee.  The house coffee, without the benefit of heavy doctoring into lattes, capps, etc., is close to awful - harsh, bitter, skin peeling.  After being reformulated into the expensive brew, they are good drinks.  But, should you have to forgo the basics and rely on alchemy to be able to drink their stuff? Just asking. 
The bakery goods are very nice, and the oatmeal breakfast is way above average.  
The former Rexall never looked this good.  This is a great place to meet someone, and sit for a while. The bench sitters out front may take that idea to an extreme. 
So, how to rate when there is so much going on and such extreme divergence of quality and experience?  "Meh," doesn't really reflect the gestalt. "Yay!" is really going too far. "OK," is just about right.

It is a testament to the American melting pot that bagels have become an American dish sold by people from the Middle East who have no cultural connection to the ethnic source. 

A & S Bagel sits in a nondescript commercial strip at the bottom of Galloway Road.  It is clean and bright, even if uninspired in its décor, with yellow walls and lights, and white booths along one side.  The workers/owners are friendly enough and know how to slice and spread efficiently.  They don't have the broadest selection of bagels, but they are made in the back of the shop and are certainly fresh.  

My Onion Bagel, Butter and Swiss was ordered and delivered to my table within 5 minutes.  This being a Boar's Head operation, the option on the cheese was eliminated in favor of only their own brand; always a disappointment as the taste and texture of the Swiss is not as good as Finlandia, Jarlesburg, or other Euro-based names.  

The only major issue with the bagel was that it lacked a crusty skin, and had a weak yeast taste.  It was more like sourdough loaf in the shape of a bagel, and not the authentic crunchy outside and airy inside that notes a proper bagel.  Still, it was quite big, and obviously satisfying to many.  I suggest a visit to Bagel Train in Yardley if they aspire to a closer approximation of the real McCoy.

I hadn't been to the Kopper Kettle Tavern for at least twenty years, perhaps indicating that I didn't feel an urge to visit this fish oriented restaurant on Bridgetown Pike in Trevose, PA. It was as remembered - cozy, slightly past its prime, with small bar and side dining room. Lots of old Formica tables and rolled stainless steel chairs. I took a stool at the bar and ordered a domestic light draft and the flounder dinner with pepper hash and baked potato. 

Everything was pretty much average. No surprises in the brew. The fish was probably frozen, nicely breaded and fried in oil clean enough to have no secondary taste. The potato was not of a baking variety and remained dry no matter how much butter was melted into it. I liked the pepper hash, which was basically a spicy slaw. I mixed the tartar and shrimp cocktail sauces together on the plate from the two table rockets given me by the friendly bartender. They made for decent dipping of the fillets. 

Maybe the sandwiches are the way to go at the Kettle, because the platter was twice the price, yet far less than double the value.

I guess I picked the wrong night to see all the hubbub at the Buck Hotel.  No cougars. Not even a stray pussycat. The barroom feels like a hunting lodge with a large angular bar, large TV's and curiosities hanging on the walls. Most pronounced; a 12' nutcracker standing guard over the operation.  This was a quiet Sunday night. No complaint. 

I had a Chicken Salad sandwich and a glass of red.  Both were fine, but certainly I was not in search of the sweet spots on the food nor liquor menus.  They were enough for the moment.  

It had been many years since my last visit, and but for the suggestion of meeting someone there for a conversation, I would not have chosen it this time.  Still, I was curious to see what had changed, and I could not detect much alternation.  

Not a bad place for a Sunday evening, but to taste the full flavor it would likely require a return on a busier night.

What a difference 18 months makes! 

Returning to Pho Palace with a group of 6 to introduce neighbors to Vietnamese cuisine, and have another run at the menu, there were several new things going on in the house that all were all nice improvements.  

First, walking in, the redesigned dining room was striking.  A large wooden pergola dominated the new front room, standing over the majority of the tables that were now separated by half walls.  Nice structure and lots more privacy.  New smaller dining rooms in the back for parties.

Second, credit cards were now accepted for orders over $20.  This was a big convenience for most customers, allowing the avoidance of the ATM monster in the lobby.  They were even willing to split our checks and allow us to use separate credit cards.  Friendly and seamless transactions. 

Third, Service was more efficient and professional.  The mostly male staff was all in black, and  was attentive throughout the meal - refilling water glasses, removing plates, asking if we needed anything more.  All good flourishes from where the level of service was on last visit.  

Most importantly, the food was still good, although the prices were up fractionally, no doubt to cover the cost of renovations.  The Pho was comforting and fun.  The Summer Rolls stuffed with Shrimp, Pork and fresh cabbage; and the Peanut Dipping Sauce cool and tasty. The Grilled Chicken and Pork Banh Mis were loaded with meat, Diakon Radish, Carrot in a crunchy Baguette-styled torpedo roll.  Everything was passed around with enthusiasm.  Even our neighbors who also ordered a Chinese dish to play it safe, were satisfied.  

The improvements at Pho Palace were well conceived and executed.  

Kudos!

Quick stop for a couple of slices and a drink on the way to a meeting. 

The shop was nice in a slightly dated sort of way, and the kitchen was out front where everyone could see what was happening.  The service was friendly and prompt, as I told my waitperson I had a short time to get to my destination.  She complied. 

The plain pizza slices were decent, but no better than what would pass for average in my part of the world.  Crust was firm enough to hold up its weight, but not overly crisp.  The sauce and cheese were okay, but not distinct.  Certainly a reasonable place to have lunch in the Far Northeast.  The dinner menu would be worth a try if in the area.  

Thanks for lunch!

Taste King Restaurant is a generic Chinese restaurant established to satisfy the American palate. The house has been at this location for decades and has changed ownership at least once.  Of late, the neighborhood has taken on a distinct East European flavor, and Taste King certainly caters to it.  The night we were there a birthday party was in full swing with toasts and song in both Russian and English.  

The menu is what you would expect from experience in most other Chinese/American shops, with a few specials designed by the chef that still tend to be variations on the established theme.  Pick a protein and the desired flavor; surround with rice or noodles; add on wonton or hot & sour soup, and those broad fried noodles for dipping in duck sauce and/or hot mustard. Voila! Your platter appears ready to consume.  

We ordered lightly.  Hot & sour soup and chicken corn soup. Grandpa's chicken and a bowl of white rice.  We had just come from great foot massage down the road, and weren't overly hungry.  

The soups were good, but not exceptional.  The hot and sour should have been warmed up more. The taste was about right.  The chicken corn was better. Certainly hot enough, but the surface was covered with tiny bubbles suggesting some chemical process was at work under the surface.  The Grandpa Chicken was made up of large chunks of white meat bird, wokked and covered in a dark red amber glaze sauce that was mildly spicy and enjoyable to eat. Only downside was that the chicken needed cutting before eating, making use of chopsticks problematic.  We found a work around. 

Service was spotty.  Our waiter was attentive at times, and AWOL at others.  He delivered the soup and chicken with style, and then dropped the silverware on the table when he brought us ice cream after we received the check.  Whaaat?

There are more authentic Chinese restaurants a few miles farther down Bustleton, which compare favorably to Taste King. Try them all and decide for yourself which is preferable.

Most people who take the train north or south from the Trenton Transit Center would rather be someplace else. Although rebuilt and modernized in the fairly recent past, it is still an unpleasant place to visit even for five minutes. 

Yet, I was surprised to find Pizza-Grill.com in the back of the station near the exit doors.  It actually has a café feel to it, with a few tables and chairs (and umbrellas) for sitting while eating their grub. The food offerings were far more extensive than expected; with sandwiches, wraps, breakfasts and pizza all on the menu, and hours starting from 4 AM to midnight. Friday and Saturday they are full tilt for 24. 

It's not that the pizza I sampled was great - it was fair, at best. Even after requesting a well done reheat, it was still heavy with cheese than was warmed at its core, but far from hot.  The taste was okay, but in this capital city of tomato pie, that is not really good enough. There is so much awesome pizza around these parts that mediocre is just mediocre.

So, what it is, is, a pleasant surprise for Trenton train station, but beyond that, not a place atop your "Must Try" list. Nice enough if hungry while waiting for a train. Otherwise, not really worth the trip.

ART NOTE - There are some beautiful ceramic tiles placed around the Center (see photos) and a few right next to Pizza-Grill.  Really like the work, and would purchase a few of the local scenes if I knew where to find them. In fact, even Pizza Grill has murals painted on the walls of the shop that show talent.

Carrabba's Italian Grill on Street Road across from Parx Casino, is a roadhouse with large bar, and substantial dining room. Although claiming to be authentic Italiano cuisine, it is really more of a hybrid with modern Americano thrown in to keep things interesting. We showed up on Super Bowl Sunday evening, suspecting that the game might suck, and we should be prepared with Plan B - a meal we could enjoy without need of huge HDTVs on the walls that demanded to be watched. 

Well, we were half right. The game was not worth watching. The food was somewhat more entertaining, but definitely not Italiano robusto. We ordered the calamari and minestrone apps/sides, and entrees of chicken marsala and lasagna. There was a side salad in there somewhere, too. Have to say, that while everything was okay, none of it was kickass. 

The calamari had an unusual breading that made it quite salty, despite the better than decent dipping sauce. No complaints about the soup, but the salad with house dressing, was, well, dull. Not worth finishing. My lasagna was middle of the road, with decent gravy, but the mozza and added Romano-grate were salty. There was not enough heft in the sauce, nor the pasta to give it any tasty substance. Finally, the marsala mushrooms were pretty good, but although we appreciated the large grilled chicken breast, it was not designed to be balanced with the sauce and mushrooms. The chicken was the dominant feature, rather than a melding with thin medallions, tender enough to mix perfectly with the marsala reduction. It was all about the chicken, not the dish. 

We ate in the barroom. It was cozy and our server was a quality dude with excellent skills. I sort of felt sorry for him working beneath his rank at this not quite good enough and salty restaurant.

Munchie's Café was recommended to me by the phlebotomist who drew my blood for pre-op testing at Penn Med last week. I asked for a place to have a quick breakfast after fasting since midnight. She advised that Munchie's was popular with the staff because of a broad menu and reasonable prices. As she had just been expert in hitting an artery on the first attempt, I figured she'd be accurate on food choices as well. 

This long/deep shop sits just off the southeast corner of 7th and Chestnut. Ordering is done at the counter, and delivered to the table. I really felt the need for coffee stronger than for sustenance, so I ordered a breakfast wrap and large java. I got to pour the joe myself at the coffee service table, and sipped while waiting for the food. The drink was decent industrial strength drip that lost its joy of living as it cooled. Became more bitter the longer it sat. The wrap of bacon, egg and cheese in wheat, was just okay.  The bacon was unrecognizable, and had a odd taste. Perhaps, it was beef or turkey bacon without designation. 

So, while the grub served to abate my caffeine and hunger gnawings, it was not something I would return for. It was average at best, although the prices were about right for what was provided. There are far superior places in the neighborhood to bring mind, body and soul up to speed.

The best place to stop before a long drive north or south coming from Newtown, this DD is hidden in the office/hotel complex next to the Hampton Inn, right of Rt. 95.  

The coffee is decent (far better than the coffee @ the other DD in Newtown), and the staff organized and efficient.  While I am not a fan of their baked goods, push come to shove, I can be found with breakfast sandy or toasted bagel in my possession.  My 13 year old goes for milk and a couple of glazed rounders.  

All in all, a reasonably tasty coffee at a good price, with a smiling face.  I don't need more than that at a caffeine oasis.

While Jamison Pour House is a comfortable roadside stop for beer and light meals. I have the impression that it is fighting out of its weight class trying to be more than it is. I stopped in to catch the Sunday afternoon NFL games on the multiple HDTVs on the walls surrounding the square bar. Plenty of stools available and a friendly crowd. 

I selected Downeast Cider and their Jamison Patty Melt (medium), as the accompaniment to my entertainment. Service was prompt, efficient and friendly. I liked the tart apple taste of the hard cider, but $6.50 for a pint seemed hazardous to my health. One was enough at that price.

 Too, the burger, though large and the right finish, was not the most flavorful I've ever had, and it crumbled as it cooled. Needed knife and fork due to the slickness of the Russian dressing, gruyere and natural greasiness of the puck. It was slip 'n slide all the way from plate to mouth. The heavier gauge friction of real rye would have helped over the lighter loaf used. It was still okay, but could have been a contender with more faithfulness to the concept. For $13, more was reasonably expected. 

These folks should consider a weekend happy hour slot to draw people in with lower prices, just like during the week. It wasn't crowded this Sunday mid afternoon, and a little marketing might do the trick. No one minds saving a few bucks, even on the weekend.

Chili's has refurbished many of its stores, but basically maintained the same approach to fast casual cuisine and comfort.  Burgers, salads, ribs are the mainstays, with a reasonable bar.  

This one just off Oxford Valley Road across from the mall of the same name is no different.  We stopped in for lunch last Saturday, and found the space full of HDTVs on mute, and enjoyable rock & roll soundtracks.  Service was friendly and prompt.  Our server was a bit of a character, and had a fun shtick with running repartee.  

We ordered the Baked Potato Soup and the 4 Sliders app to share.  The Soup was fine, but we did not expect it to be more cheesy than creamy.  It actually detracted from the anticipated potato flavor.  The Sliders were the Medium finish requested, with long wooden spikes spearing them together.  They had sautéed onion and ein bissel cheese melted over the top.  They were pretty good, and exactly the right amount for light lunch and two stomachs to enjoy.  

The Sam Adams Rebel IPA draft was appropriately hoppy and cold.  Not my fave, but okay.  

Overall, this Chili's was about average for the genre.  No big complaints about the grub and drinks, but nothing to get wild about. 

PRO TIP - Be careful choosing your table, as they are not aligned with the low hanging light fixtures.  So easy to stand up and klonk your head on the heavy glass.  I was warned by our comedic waiter, but still gave myself a klep en vant.

Stopped by for breakfast this week and sat at an otherwise empty counter.  The place looked refreshed since the last time I was here several years ago.  My server was friendly, courteous and prompt with the large red coffee mug, keeping it full throughout my meal.  

The Sausage, Egg & Cheese on Croissant was a special this morning, and included a side of Hash Browns for a price under $6.  I was pleased that my waitperson pointed that out to me when she heard I was heading in that direction.  

The sandwich was constructed with double Sausage Patties, American Cheese, and a nicely Fried Egg.  The Croissant was fresh, and had a pleasant sweetness with every bite.  It was very good.  Yet, the half plate of Home Fries were room temperature at best.  They were overcooked and dry.  Add cool temperature to that, and I found them inedible.  Not sure why the grill chef didn't know that those taters were left in the corner of the iron for too long.  Just as well, as I didn't need the extra calories turning into sugars.  

The coffee came from a Bunn Double Drip.  It was a good bean, and I enjoyed having a large, heavy mug to sip from, rather than a smaller vessel to be constantly refilled.  

Overall, the environment was attractive and comfortable.  A little more attention to detail would certainly make Blue Fountain a more positively memorable experience.

Wings To Go in the Queen Anne Plaza, Fairless Hills, PA, is part of a regional chain of wing, burger, rib, wrap houses in the Bucks/Mercer area. They are clean, friendly, and reasonably priced for what they offer, and tend to be better than many of the other franchised wing-a-do shops around. 

I was there to grab a chicken sandwich and order two dozen wings for home consumption by the boys. I ordered at the counter, and walked into the dining area to await my light lunch. It arrived in a plastic basket, open faced, with a lightly coated breading on a large breast. A squirt from the ketchup table rocket and I was in business. It was a tasty chew, and I was pleasantly surprised by the thin coat and clean taste. Old oil was not used, and it was prepared just in time for me. Even the roll held up well to my gnawing assault. 

I brought the Asian Zing and Suicide wings home, and sat with my guys as they attacked the flaming appendages. Average sized wings, but with decent distinctive sauces that pointed out their relative advantages. The Asian Zing were hot, but with a Thai sauce sweetness to offset the conflagration. Liked them a lot. The Suicide were less forgiving, and stung all the soft membranes of the mouth and lips. They were okay, although number one son seemed to be more enthusiastic about them. To each his own. 

Both came with small containers of "sour cream." It wasn't, but they did chill the burn a bit as meat was scraped from bone by our incisors. Word to the wise, have your own sour cream in the fridge for such occasions to avoid unnecessary burn and blister.

We stopped in last weekend as the COVID crisis tightened its chokehold on small food outlets in Bucks and our governor was about to order most closed to enforce social distancing but for takeout. We were looking for dessert choices and coffee after a decent last supper down the road in Buckingham. 

Peddlers Village in Lahaska is a cutesy tourist center just outside New Hope, but where New Hope has a real community integrated among the beauty of an historic but tourist centric riverside town, Peddlers Village is all ersatz artificiality that looks dated and pretty, but lacks a human heart. So, it is not surprising to see all the poor reviews interspersed with a few positive ones. 

If you get there on or near a baking day when most of the inventory is still new and moist, you are going to be happy. If you pick things that are a bit older and approaching their invisible sell by date, you're out of luck. Your purchase will be dry and disappointing. Problem is you can't tell them apart. Management hasn't figured out how to (or decided not to) inform the public which is which. There is no "Day Old" shelf. 

Our experience appears to be somewhat typical. Their La Colombe java (a Philadelphia treasure) was hot and strong, although not at the peak of perfection at that hour, while the Lemon Cheesecake Cupcake we shared was pretty good, although plainly just a small cheesecake with a dollop of lemon buttercream swirled on top. It really stretched the meaning of "cupcake." Had it been creamier/softer it would have been fully satisfying, but as it was with the right taste yet wrong texture, it was just okay. 

There were many other choices possible in the substantial display cases, so another selection might have made us happier, but we'll never know because as it was, our experience was just mediocre.

This is not part if the Villa Rosa empire from Yardley PA, as it changed hands sometime in the past few years, although the name and design are the same. 

There are two operations here sharing a common kitchen. On the right is a pizza parlor with booths and small tables doing a slice, sandwich and takeout business, while on the left is a more formal dining room with similar menu and more comfort. Service is easily bilingual, and muy amable. 

I stopped in for a light dinner and opted for the parlor side as I know I didn't want a full meal, nor the attendant cost of table service. An eggplant parmesan on torpedo roll would do nicely, thank you. And it did. Very thin sliced melanzone sauteed to a soft textured in an olive oiled pan and lowered into the valley of a cut roll, with mozza and red gravy on top, and a final melt down in the pizza oven. 

The taste was right, but it would have been better if the cheese and sauce had been layered in with the eggplant. Without that, much of the middle was somewhat dry and monotonal, lacking the mix of tomato, garlic, salt and basil throughout to bring up the flavor. I tend to deconstruct these beauties and eat the contents with knife and fork to reduce carb intake. If the bread is exceptional, I will eat some of it as well. In this case I consumed half of it, meaning it was pretty good. 

Based on my experience, I think the chef knows the recipes and techniques, but may lack the savior faire to realize that the ingredients need to interact more.

Standard pizzeria on Mill Creek Road, Levittown, PA. This place is in a tiny commercial strip, a double wide storefront with kitchen/counter to the right and dining room to the left. Strictly a slice, pie and steak joint. Management is friendly and clearly happy for your business. 

The food is what you'd expect from a traditional northeastern Mexitalian pizza parlor. The pies are competently made and the cheesesteaks are loaded with chopped beef, cheese and whatever else you desire in terms of onions, peppers, mushrooms, etc. The roll is decent, too, but not particularly crispy. Prices are definitely on the low end of the scale, making for a good meal on a budget. My two slice lunch (mushroom and plain) were requested well done, and that was what I got. Firm points. Scorched undercarriage. Well remelted mozzarella. Quite solid with a sprinkle of crushed hot pepper. 

Not sure if Luigi is in the house anymore, but as a place to grab a couple of slices and a drink for lunch, this place is worthy of consideration.

Giovanni's is an Italian house along Woodbourne Road in Levittown, Pa.  It has been around for a long time and the layout and décor show how restaurants were put together twenty years ago.  Two small dining rooms with kitchen in the rear.  Comfortable booths and pleasant aromas, but in need of a little refreshing.  

Service was fine for most of the meal, except when our lone server was put to work elsewhere in the shop, and couldn't get back to us often enough to see we were finished eating and waiting for a box for the remaining pizza and our check.  

The food is decent.  The Tomato Pie comes with just spicy tomato gravy and no cheese, unlike across the Delaware where the mozza is spread across the top of the chunky sauce.  The different style requires a much heavier hand ladling out the sauce to compensate for the lack of balancing cheese.  The result is a wet pie whose middle crust cannot hold the weight and moisture from above.  If a crisp cracker-like dough is your hope, you won't get that here.  Even picking up the slices caused runoff.  On the other hand, the half pepperoni showed generosity, as half the pie was covered in quarter-sized coins of nicely sliced p-roni.  

The Caesar Salad was nice, with plenty of Romaine, Onions, Crutons, Tomatoes, but the small plastic container of dressing would have been so much nicer had it been presented in a small dish with a spoon.  No real complaints beyond style points.  

The Chicken Cheesesteak/Fries combo was hefty, and devoured without complaint.  Fries were average.  

Giovanni's is a nice family place with low cost menu.  Nothing stands out as exceptional, but everything we had was okay to pretty good.  It definitely has a place in the Italian restaurant continuum.

Red Lion Diner in Horsham gives the impression of having had better days. The decor is somewhat worn with torn vinyl seats and dirty wall to walls. The menu attempts to cover the traditional bases, but only in a limited way by offering expected categories with only a few options in each. For example, their breakfast menu fits on half a page of a four sided laminate, rather than running on forever with combinations of possibilities. 

My morning choices were a cup of Chicken Pastina Soup, which was quite good loaded with well cooked veggies, strips of chicken and tiny pastina pasta. Second, came a Sausage, Egg and Cheese on Kaiser, which while filling with two sausage patties, 2 eggs and lots of white gooey, came packaged in the sorriest looking ragged roll I've seen in years. Guess the budget didn't allow for decent bread provisions. It was crushed, dry and lifeless, and took most of the joy out of the substance of the meal. 

Service was fine, bit not exemplary, and managed to pick one of my nits - Asked for milk for my coffee, but got those mini moos, with unwanted and non-nutritious fat and empty calories. 

The soup was definitely the star of this show, leading to the reasonable conclusion that Red Lion was oriented toward lunch, much more than breakfast.

BREAKFAST @ TIFFANY (Diner on the Boulevard)
