Happy New Year (2022) Everyone!

My last Yelp of the old year was at this fine establishment in the Great Northeast, Philadelphia. It had been closed an extended period of time for renovations, and the effort appears to have been worthwhile. The facility has a new outer shell and the main dining hall is bright, attractively utilitarian and very clean. Staff from management to servers are courteous and helpful. The menu is a diner's long list of nearly infinite possibilities. 

But, I was there for a New Year's Eve Day breakfast, and while prepared to be tempted, knew what I wanted - French Toast & crisp bacon. There is a long counter along the back wall, and when I arrived it was unoccupied. I sidled down to the third from last spinner, past the last booth, and found myself in the perfect Covidly socially distance spot. No one with ten feet of me. I ordered coffee and my Frenchie. and perused my phone for the latest news while I waited. These days that is always a risky thing to do and expect to keep a good mood, but old habits die hard. (Good riddance 2021!)

So, my plate was delivered with a warm smile. I beheld two slices of thickish bread well grilled and sided by four slices of heat curled bacon. Both good to the naked eye. First bites told the tale. 

Although described as "Challah" bread, the texture was more a yellowish thick slice with extra sugar baked in. It lacked the rougher consistency and swirl of true Challah. Okay. I'm being picky, but the mental image of the real deal had excited my tastebuds and I was a little disappointed. Too, it came with those industrial corn syrup sweeteners, that are just empty calories and not conducive to good health. No Log Cabin nor Mrs. Butterworth in the house. True, it was edible and the bacon was fine, but these days I have reservations about putting such ersatz materials in my body, and would gladly pay extra for pure Grade B maple syrup. 

I get that corners must be cut to stay ahead of the game, but I would prefer the choice. 

But, that's just me. 

Let's have a better 2022! Lord knows we need and deserve it.

No doubt, Green Eggs Café on South 13th Street is someone's idea of paradise.  Full up at 3 in the afternoon, with a 30 minute wait for a table (or, restrooms), there was nary an empty seat in the house.  The sidewalk was crowded with more people waiting their entry into Valhalla. It's not that the staff wasn't friendly and accommodating, it was just that unless you were totally committed to having brunch on this corner, and had the rest of the day to make your way inside, you might have considered the practical and humane limits of participating in this exercise in mass impulse run amok. Rather than the gates of green heaven, it felt more like Dante's purgatory on an empty stomach. 

The promised thirty soon became 45, without realistic estimate of when a table would be available.  We were welcome to wait with name on list, and add to the aura of the last ship to sail before the invasion, but to do so meant that the rest of the day was shot, and the cost of parking would become exponentially higher; making this a very expensive meal indeed.

It just wasn't worth it. 

So, we ordered a couple of joes to go, and once received, took our leave.  They were very good, and I imagine that used as a washdown for red velvet pancakes or some other overwrought sweet platter, would do quite nicely.  

Can't hold success against the establishment, but neither do we have to suffer its consequences without reservation.

This Einstein Bagel shop in the Big Oak Shopping Center, Lower Makefield, PA, (No. It's not in Yardley), is well set up for Covid Protocols. It is clean, prepared for ordering and takeaway transactions, and even prebags the tops and stirrers for coffee cups. First time I've seen that. The service was prompt and friendly, and I saw no sign of the negativity referenced in other reviews. 

Unfortunately, unlike their namesake Albert E., the bagels themselves are not as intelligently conceptualized. Their skin is soft rather than offering a crispness found in more traditional NY style bagels. This suggests the boiling in lye or brine was skipped or inadequate to foster the differing texture signature of the better bagels in the Universe. The overall taste is decent, and they do cover the surface with plenty of toppings (roasted onion flakes for me). Yet, missing a key step in the process relegates their product to strictly second tier status, when it would have been so easy to get it right. 

They do have plenty of options and can throw together a reasonably good sandwich. So, if you don't mind the lack of textural differentiation, you will find the grab, bite and chew satisfying. Otherwise, you will discover yourself wishing for a more complete effort. 

Their coffee is actually better than the bagels.

Osaka Japanese/Chinese Restaurant has been around for a while. It is operated by a friendly Chinese couple who have degrees from Sushi University. Their shop is dimly lit with subtle Asian decor, with small fish bar and large dining room. Staff wears black T shirts and slacks and have been working there for a long time, indicating that it is probably a decent place to work. 
Given the cultural orientation of management, I opted to try the Chinese side of the menu first. Although the lunch offerings were limited, I ordered General Tso's Chicken, which came with cup of wonton soup, small fried egg roll (surprisingly) and pork fried rice. 

It arrived on a large white ceramic plate. This was much more than normally seen for a lunch special. I could only eat half, and they packaged the rest for me to take home. The volume of food was the most memorable part of the meal. The chicken was all dark meat, although the sauce was nicely spiced. The wontons were thick skinned and the consomme was also darker and more savory than usual. The rice wasn't bad, but had been sitting around for a while. 

Overall, I might return to sample the Japanese side of the menu, but the Chinese elements were no better than average.

Stopped in for a late afternoon slice to hold off hunger for a few hours. Nice shop with a half dozen booths and broad Italian menu. HDTVs playing Mexican talk shows. 
I asked for a slice of sausage pie "well done," from those under the display glass. 

It arrived hot and steaming, and certainly what I asked for.  Sadly, all the heat had not helped rigidify the chassis. It still collapsed under its own weight. The crust was soggy from an approach that put too much on top and didn't allow enough moisture to escape in the oven. The taste was there, but the texture was AWOL. 

There aren't many pizza joint in this area that understand the right balance between ingredients and strong crust that results in a pie that is crisp, tasty and light on its feet. Loading up on cheese at the expense of sauce and other toppings just misses the mark. 

 The secret is that when it comes to great pizza, less is more.
